The Goldman Sachs Group

column27:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2013 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded today
column32:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column33:
Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call.

"
column34:
"

Today\u2019s call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm\u2019s belief regarding future events that by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm\u2019s control. The firm\u2019s actual results and financial condition may differ
column36: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm\u2019s future results
column37:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our fiscal year ended December 2012.

"
column38:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column39: particularly as it relates to our investment banking transaction backlog
column40: capital ratios
column41: risk weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com. This audio cast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column42: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column45:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column46: Harvey Schwartz
column47:
will now review the firm\u2019s results. Harvey?

"
column48:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column50:
Dane and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I\u2019ll walk you through our full year and fourth quarter results then I am obviously happy to answer any questions.

"
column51:
"

Let\u2019s start with the annual results. We had firm wide net revenues of $34.2 billion
column52: net earnings of $8 billion
column53: earnings per diluted share of $15.46 and a return on common equity of 11%. This is a solid result and a modest improvement over last year\u2019s performance despite what at times was a difficult operating environment. With regard to the fourth quarter
column55:
net earnings were $2.3 billion and earnings per diluted share were $4.60.

"
column56:
"

In looking at the broader operating environment
column57: many of the global themes had dominated 2012
column58: for example
column59: improving economic debt in the United States
column60: central bank activity and political uncertainty continued into 2013. Starting with U.S. economic data
column61: we saw relatively consistent improvement over the course of the year reported GDP consensus estimates in each of the last two quarters. U.S. unemployment rate declined by over 100 basis points to 6.7%
column62: it\u2019s lowest level since October of 2008 and housing prices as reflected by the Case-Shiller Housing Price Index increased by 14% through October. 2013 represented a slow
column63: steady improvement in the U.S. economy
column64:
which had roughly a quarter of global GDP naturally served at a stabilizing and positive improvements on global market sentiment.

"
column65:
"

2013 was also marked by significant Central Bank activity. In Japan the Central Bank announced unprecedented monetary risk [ph] and was to achieve stated inflation targets. Japanese credit spreads tightened and the yen weekend throughout the year. In addition the Nikkei enjoyed it's largest annual game since 1972.

"
column66:
"

In the U.S. initial commentary from the Federal Reserve about tapering at bond buying program ultimately translated into a December announcement of a $10 billion monthly reduction in the reprogram leading the marketplace to contemplate the world without quantitative easing.

"
column67:
"

Finally political risk and uncertainty were constant during the year
column68: starting with the Italian elections in the first quarter
column69:
continued unrest in the Middle East and the 16 day U.S. government shutdown. This created an environment that requires qualities to constantly reassess their outlook for the global economy. For example what are the implications of Central Bank activity on the global economy? Individual regional economies and specific industry sectors? What are the pushes and poles associated with monetary policy versus fiscal policy? Rising rates and tapering a head win for the U.S. economic recovery or return to a more traditional supply and demand driven economy.

"
column70:
"

Not surprisingly our client\u2019s activity fluctuated over the course of the year as they were constantly digesting new information. When you boil it all down the 2013 environment it's just one where the world took two steps forward followed by one step back. A dynamic which you could see reflected in both price movements in the markets and client activity. To sum it up while we wouldn\u2019t characterize the last two years as a normal cyclical environment given all the items I previously listed it shouldn\u2019t be lost on us that the long term trend is slowly and steadily improving.

"
column71:
"

Now I will discuss each of our businesses
column72: in invest banking we produced fourth quarter net revenues of $1.7 billion up 47% from the third quarter. Three factors drove the increase
column73: a robust IPO calendar
column74:
higher completed M&A volumes and debt financing activity that remained strong. For the full year investment banking net revenues was $6 billion up 22% from 2012 on the back of solid underwriting activity.

"
column75:
"

Breaking down the components in investment banking advisory revenues were 585 million in the fourth quarter. The 38% increase relative to the third quarter reflects the increase in industry wide completed M&A. Goldman Sachs continue to be ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A for 2013. We advise on a number of significant transactions that closed during the fourth quarter including Vivendi
column76:
$8.2 billion sale of it's controlling stake in Activision. Ingersoll-Rand\u2019s $5.3 billion Allegion and a $2.9 billion sale off Saks to Hudson\u2019s Bay.

"
column77:
"

We also advise on a number of important transaction that were announced during the fourth quarter including Sysco\u2019s $8.2 billion acquisition of U.S. Foods
column78:
ViroPharma\u2019s $4.2 billion sale to Shire and Deutsche Telekom\u2019s 2 million euro sale of Scout 24 to Hellman & Friedman.

"
column79:
"

Moving to underwriting net revenues were record $1.1 billion in the fourth quarter up 52% sequentially at equity issuance improved significantly. Equity underwriting revenues of 622 million were more than double our third quarter results largely due to an increase in IPOs and convertibles. Goldman Sachs continues to be ranked first in worldwide equity
column80:
equity related and common stock offerings for 2013. Debt underwriting revenues increased 9% to 511 million.

"
column81:
"

During the fourth quarter we actively supported our clients financing needs participating in Darling International
column82:
$2.7 billion debt and equity offering. Twitter\u2019s $2.1 billion IPO and Moncler\u2019s $1.1 billion IPO. Our investment banking backlog further improved from third quarter levels which you will recall were already at our highest level in five years.

"
column83:
"

Turning to institutional client services which comprises both our FICC and equity businesses. Net revenues were 3.4 billion in the fourth quarter up 19% compared to the more challenging environment in the third quarter. For the full year 15.7 billion of net revenues were down 13% relative to 2012. FIC client execution net revenues were 1.7 billion in the fourth quarter or 1.9 billion excluding DVA losses of a 163 million. Excluding DVA
column84: revenues were up 46% sequentially. In particular
column85:
currency revenues increased significantly compared to a challenging third quarter. Credit was up on stronger client activity that was supported by tighter credit spreads and solid issuance trends. Commodities revenues were largely flat sequentially and remains a threat by lower volatility in client activity levels. Rates and mortgages declined as client activity levels remained low.

"
column86:
"

For the full year
column87: fixed client execution net revenues were $8.7 billion or $8.9 billion excluding $220 million in DVA losses. Excluding DVA
column88:
revenues were down 14% relative to 2012 at macro uncertainty particularly around central bank policies and lower volatility levels impacted client risk appetite and activity. The decline was more pronounced for rates and mortgages.

"
column89:
"

In equities
column90: which includes
column91: equities client execution
column92: commissions and fees and security services
column93: net revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.7 billion
column94: up 4% sequentially and included $43 million in DVA losses. Equities client execution revenues increased 9% sequentially to $598 million. Commissions and fees were $747 million
column95:
up 3% relative to the third quarter supported by rising equity markets and strong issuance trends. Security services generated net revenues of $337 million largely consistent with the third quarter.

"
column96:
"

For the full year
column97: equities produced net revenues of $7.1 billion
column98: down 14% relative to 2012. This decline was due to the sale of our Americas reinsurance business in 2013 and the sale of our hedge fund administration business in 2012. In our equity business during 2013
column99: stronger performance in cash products was offset by weaker derivative revenues. Turning to risk
column100: average daily VAR in the fourth quarter was $81 million
column101:
down from $84 million in the third quarter.

"
column102:
"

Moving on to our investing and lending activities
column103: collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $2.1 billion in the fourth quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $1.4 billion
column104: primarily reflecting company specific events
column105: including initial public offerings and gains in public equity investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $423 million and benefited from net gains and net interest income. Other revenues of $234 million include the firm\u2019s consolidated investments. For the full year
column106: investing and lending generated net revenues of $7 billion driven by $3.9 billion in gains from equity securities
column107:
$1.9 billion of net revenues from debt securities and loans and $1.1 billion of other investments.

"
column108:
"

In investment management
column109: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion
column110: up 31% from the third quarter primarily as a result of $333 million in incentive fees generated largely from the firm\u2019s alternative asset products. Management and other fees were up 5% sequentially of $1.1 billion. For the full year
column111: investment management net revenues were $5.5 billion
column112: up 5% from 2012 on stronger management and other fees
column113:
which benefited from growth in assets under supervision.

"
column114:
"

During the fourth quarter
column115: assets under supervision increased $51 billion to a record $1.04 trillion. This growth was driven by long-term net inflows of $13 billion largely in fixed income assets. We also had market appreciation of $20 billion largely in equity assets. On a full year basis
column116: $41 billion of long-term net inflows and $40 billion of market appreciation drove these record levels of assets under supervision. When it comes to investment management
column117:
we all know that performance is critical. We are intensely focused on delivering returns for our investment management clients and have seen improvement in our multi-year performance. The $41 billion of long-term net inflows in 2013 were the highest annually since the onset of the crisis. We will continue to focus on delivering performance for our clients and have confidence that the rest will follow in due course.

"
column118:
"

Now
column119: let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column120: which includes salaries
column121: bonuses
column122: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column123: decreased 3% to $12.6 billion for 2013 and translated into a compensation to net revenues ratio of 36.9%. Fourth quarter non-compensation expenses were $3 billion
column124:
40% higher than the third quarter and up slightly compared with the fourth quarter of 2012. Other expenses were significantly higher reflecting net provisions for litigation and regulatory proceedings of 561 million more than 400 million higher than the third quarter. Depreciation and amortization included a 196 million impairment charges primarily related to consolidated investments. Finally the fourth quarter also included a $155 million donation to Goldman Sachs Gives our donor-advised charitable fund.

"
column125:
"

For the full year non-compensation expenses were down 2%. Total staff at year end was approximately 32
column126: 900 up 2% from year end 2012. Our effective tax rate was 31.5% for 2013. Before moving on to capital it's worth taking a step back to review our improvement operating efficiency over the past few years. In the first half of 2011 we announced a comprehensive expense initiative. If you look at our cost structure this year versus 2010 before we launched our expense initiative. Total expenses are lower by $3.8 billion. As a result our pretax margin in 2013 increased a 140 basis points to it's highest level in the last four years
column127:
this despite having $5 billion less in revenues.

"
column128:
"

Delivering more operating efficiency is never easy and requires a real focus on striking the right balance. By balance I mean making sure that our actions positions us to deliver for all of our constituents. Our clients
column129: our regulators
column130: our employees
column131:
the broader financial system and of course for our shareholders. We believe it's early and ongoing focus on our expense structure has not only benefited recent performance but more importantly also serves as a basis for better results in the future particularly as the opportunity set expands.

"
column132:
"

Now regarding capital
column133: we repurchased 8.5 million shares of common stock for total cost of $1.4 billion during the fourth quarter. For the full year we repurchased 39.3 million shares for a total cost of $6.2 billion. With respect to our regulatory capital ratios our Basel III Tier I common ratio on a fully loaded basis was 9.8% using the advance approach. Under the standardized approach our ratio was 9.2% of course it's important to note that our transitional ratios are both more than a 100 basis points higher. Risk weighted assets are on the advance approach are approximately $595 billion
column134: $350 billion in credit risk
column135:
$160 billion in market risk and about $85 billion in operational risk. Our estimate for the proposed supplementary leverage ratio under U.S. rules remains approximately 5% for the firm and approximately 6% for the bank. These were our best estimates subject to change depending on regulatory clarifications.

"
column136:
"

Of course last month we also gained regulatory clarity on the Volcker Rule. Most importantly the final Volcker Rule explicitly permitted market making
column137: lending and investing on balance sheets. Regulators permitted these activities given the essential that they plan supporting healthy capital markets and economic growth. Although we only received a finalized Volcker Rule last month. We have obviously been preparing to comply with certain portions of the rule for nearly three years. In 2010 we began closing down our proprietary trading operations
column138:
specifically Goldman Sachs principal strategies and our Global Macro Proprietary Trading desk.

"
column139:
"

In addition we announced in 2012 our intention to redeem certain hedge fund investments. Since 2012 we have redeemed approximately $2.2 billion of hedge fund investments and we will continue to redeem our interests. Now that we have a final rule the first thing that we did was established a Volcker implementation team comprised of senior leaders with expertise across a wide variety of controlling business functions. They are focused on making sure that we\u2019re in the position to effectively and efficiently meet the numerous requirements outlined under this new and intense compliance regime.

"
column140:
"

In summary as I mentioned earlier while we\u2019re still not at what I would describe that normalized cyclical environment
column141: the underlying macro trend is being improving. To maximize our opportunity set and drive shareholder value we need to continue to focus first and foremost on our clients. Their activity and our connectivity to their needs is our highest priority. We need to continue to recruit and retain a high caliber and dedicated global workforce. We need to leverage our technology expertise to adapt to new regulations and evolving market structures and we need to remain focused on improving our efficiency both from a cost and a capital perspective. Our goal is not only to enhance returns in the current environment
column142: but more importantly over the long-term to position this firm for significant operating leverage as the opportunities that improves. We believe that we have the competitive position
column143: the diversity of businesses
column144: the caliber of people and the institutional will to capture and maximize these opportunities as they present themselves for the benefit of you
column145:
our shareholders.

"
column146:
"

Thank you again for dialing in. And now I am happy to answer any questions.

"
column147:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column148:
"

Operator

"
column149:
"

(Operator Instructions) Your first question is from the line of Glenn Schorr with ISI. Please go ahead.

"
column150:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column151:
"

Thanks very much.

"
column152:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column153:
"

Good morning
column154:
Glenn.

"
column155:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column156:
"

Good morning. Just a quickie follow-up. I heard all your comments on Volker just making sure the hedging component
column157: you mentioned about market-making lending investment
column158:
anything different on the verb it\u2019s related to hedging in your ability to just manage risk across the desks?

"
column159:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column160:
"

No. We don\u2019t see anything in the rule that prevents us from continuing to hedge. I think the early concern before the final rule came out with its reference to portfolio hedging
column161: but we hedge within the business as there is no hedging at the firm wide level
column162:
so hedges are hedges.

"
column163:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column164:
"

Good
column165: good. Also the Fed recently just put out a quick whitepaper that had a testimony on commodities
column166: I think a lot of that was expected
column167: but I am curious to get your update as to what\u2019s on plans for the business
column168: but there was a piece in that that threw me for a loop a little bit on the merchant banking and I wasn\u2019t sure if it relates to your entire merchant banking business or merchant banking within commodities businesses. So
column169: if you could get quick thoughts on that
column170: I know it just came out
column171:
that would be helpful?

"
column172:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column173:
"

No
column174: fine. It\u2019s an important question. So
column175: as you know
column176: the commodity business has been an important business for Goldman Sachs and quite important for our clients for an extended period of time. I think to simplify it I would break down the business growing into two parts. There is \u2013 our activity there relate to investing activities. And then there is our franchise business where we are working with clients in a market-making activity. Then in that function
column177: we are essentially providing the same services as anyone would
column178: working with a Treasurer or a CFO on any risk that they would be hedging. So
column179: in terms of a corporate treasurer
column180: if they need to manage their exposure to dollar yen
column181: they will work with us in our currency business. And if they need to manage their exposure to a cost input in commodities
column182: they will work with us on the same hedging profile. So that\u2019s a high level as the business breaks down. And on the investing side
column183: we\u2019ve been an important provider of capital and working with our clients to a capital intensive industry. I think it relates to the whitepaper
column184: I think it\u2019s a good step. It\u2019s another step in the regulatory process
column185: where people reviewing the businesses. I think the questions make sense. These are things that we consider all the time in our businesses from the safety incentive [ph] perspective. So I think it\u2019s a healthy exercise and we will work the regulators
column186:
but certainly no change in strategy from Goldman Sachs as it relates to commodity. It\u2019s just too important business for our clients.

"
column187:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column188:
"

I appreciate that. The merchant banking component within that paper
column189: it seemed to be chucked in at the end
column190:
is that questioning whether we limit bank holding companies\u2019 ability to do merchant banking in totality or it\u2019s within the commodity space?

"
column191:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column192:
"

Don\u2019t know. Don\u2019t have any special insight in terms of that.

"
column193:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column194:
"

I know it\u2019s early.

"
column195:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column196:
"

So we will see as it moves along. I don\u2019t want to minimize it
column197:
but it\u2019s a question.

"
column198:
"

Glenn Sure - ISI

"
column199:
"

Okay. Moving on to FEA
column200: you guys have been doing this for a while
column201: some banks are catching up. I am just curious on if more of the competition is accounting for the credit spreads and pricing
column202: does that make the business on more equal footing
column203:
does it \u2013 is it that do you envision an impact on the actual pricing of the business than the competitive landscape?

"
column204:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column205:
"

No. Obviously
column206: there has been a lot of attention to FEA over the last couple of days just so obviously you are aware of this
column207: Glenn
column208: but we incorporated FEA into our pricing methodologies back in 2010. And if you take the step back for a second
column209: just from the general risk management perspective in the way that we think about risk parameters and inputs
column210: if we identify our cost or parameter we try incorporate as quickly as possible and so we adopted this in 2010. In terms of it's implications I think there is probably two one is really more for you and folks on your side of the table which is obviously it has some degree of distorting effect when you look at things like revenue market share and it's one reason why we look at revenue market share but we don\u2019t emphasize it as much as you do necessarily because these pricing inconsistencies they can lead to anomalies in certain points in time. I think the more important issue really in terms of how we run the business is the one that you have mentioned which is regardless of the particular assay class is
column211: if one firm I say Goldman Sachs in this particularly case ends being the one from that\u2019s actually pricing our parameter and all the other competitors aren\u2019t. It leads to challenging conversations with the clients because you look like an outlier and so you know to get to the gut of your question the extent to which the playing field is level and everyone is pricing on the same terms and managing the risk the same way
column212:
obviously we prefer that.

"
column213:
"

But in the end we\u2019re always going to prioritize the risk management over things like market share.

"
column214:
"

Operator

"
column215:
"

Your next question is from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank. Please go ahead.

"
column217:
"

The question I get asked most often when I talk to clients about you guys is how you can improve the ROE over time? And you know to be fair the 11% for the year is above that appears especially if you adjust for the business mix but as we think about you know obviously revenue is a driver but if revenue stays kind of in this type of environment what can you do to optimize the capital and there is still some expense opportunities even after all the progress you\u2019ve made today?

"
column218:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column219:
"

So if you go back again a couple of years ago you know we really were focused on building operating leverage into the enterprise and I think in the end of last year you saw that reflected in the response sort of our performance with a 10.7% ROE and this year you\u2019re seeing increasing operating leverage but obviously it's important to see the back to back consistency. Now we\u2019re always looking to be more efficient. We can certainly do things you know far from corporate [ph] we can certainly do things in terms of capital efficiency and expenses and we\u2019re constantly looking at how to leverage technology particularly as we get more visibility into finalized rules so we can adapt. I would say you know my comments before about finding balance. As we have been doing this the most important thing is we want to make sure we\u2019re well positioned for our clients when revenue opportunities do look better and I think you see it kind of across the board in terms of market share and investment banking
column220: reachable [ph] presence
column221:
growth and asset management all across of our businesses you\u2019re seeing it we will try to find that balance and look we always get these things right but that\u2019s what we\u2019re trying to do.

"
column222:
"

Matt O'Connor - Deutsche Bank

"
column223:
"

And I guess as a follow-up
column224:
this is just a general question for you and the industry that when people look at the fixed income environment I think there is a lot of focus in all the structural changes occurring and concerned that there will be revenue pressures but I also get the sense that there hasn\u2019t been maybe an entire adjustment to that franchise or to the platform as people wait to see what all the new rules are and kind of when Fed that of buying bonds what happens to that market? So I\u2019m just wondering like is that an area where there might be some capacity adjustments because if you see for the industry as a whole?

"
column225:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column226:
"

It's a really good question; I\u2019m going to break it down in two part. On the first part in terms of the impact of regulation I think it's early you know we haven't even really seen the launch of things like swap execution facilities and the real impact is in ultimately how market structures adjust. I do think though that the big impact from a regulation perspective is the fact that the entire industry is carrying more capital and I think implicating [ph] in your question but you should correct me if I\u2019m not appearing correctly
column227:
it would appear that perhaps there is excess capacity in the industry. Now we have been building a lot of operating leverage into our fixed income franchise over the last couple of years and at the same time we feel very comfortable with our relative position in all of our businesses and so to the extent to which capacity comes out we think we will benefit from that in terms of our competitors exiting businesses but we will have to see. We\u2019re just focused on doing what we can with our opportunity set.

"
column228:
"

Operator

"
column229:
"

Your next question is from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

"
column231:
"

Good morning
column233:
"

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column234:
"

Good morning. Thanks a lot. Maybe first question just getting back to the ROE given that you have more clarity on some of these rules
column235: whether its RWA leveraged Volcker
column236: you just spent a few years trying to kind of reposition the business. I guess what inning do you feel like you are in terms of repositioning? And then at some point
column237: you sold some of the U.S. reinsurance business
column238: I think the Europeans there
column239:
I guess some point you need to be able to either redeploy more than your earnings in terms of capital or are you seeing enough opportunities globally as the economy and the macro environment improves that you can start reinvesting to generate high returns?

"
column240:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column241:
"

So it\u2019s a great question. So obviously we have taken a number of steps over the past several years to in terms of selling businesses that because of rule changes were quite frankly just better held than other people and when you provide the proper return
column242: then as I said going to the hood
column243: we have been building in as much operating flexibility into
column244: for example
column245: our fixed income franchise as we can during this fortune environment. So I guess I would say with respect to capital first and foremost
column246: we just want to make sure that firm is positioned safely and defensively and at the same time we can be offensive when opportunities present themselves
column247: but it\u2019s really going to be determined by client activity
column248: economic growth
column249: confidence that will be the opportunity set and will just adjust. It will always be incremental. So you will see us make incremental steps. You have seen us take some move selling things
column250: but you will see us make incremental steps
column253:
because we don\u2019t want to forgo the upside.

"
column254:
"

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column256: that\u2019s helpful. And then just on the banking side
column257: you mentioned pipeline remains strong. It feels like we are coming off a very strong 2013 just given particularly on the equity side and even on the debt side
column258: but when you look at the outlook and you look at the conversations
column259: is it possible to have multiple years meaning \u201814/15 with an improving economy
column260:
where the investment banking revenues are continuing to grow off this base and maybe partially it\u2019s because we had five years of pretty anemic activity in some areas. I just want to get your outlook is this some view that \u201813 was a great year and some spot and so the growth rate from here might be tougher?

"
column262:
"

It\u2019s a good question. So if you sort of just think about our investment banking franchise and you break it down between let\u2019s just say underwriting on one side and advisory services
column263: the merger business on the other. The underwriting activities clearly there is a market component to that in terms of tightening credit spreads people looking to put capital to work and then obviously you saw it in the fourth quarter a big uptick in equity underwriting
column264: the market was there. The advisory business for a CEO making a decision on a merger
column265: it\u2019s a career defining decision and against the backdrop. Again
column267: against the backdrop in one quarter you are contemplating what is tapering mean and then two quarters later
column268:
you are contemplating a government shutdown at that difficult backdrop to make a career defining decision. And so it\u2019s going to lack that client and you are going to see pickup in M&A activity in sectors where you see global confidence and so not surprising to us at all and we have been very protective about franchise obviously a leading franchise.

"
column269:
"

Now
column270: as it relates to some of the other markets like for example take the debt market
column271: one thing I have learned in the past year
column272: because I think one of the most frequently asked questions I got at the end of the last year was what is the debt underwriting looking like in the environment in 2013? I couldn\u2019t have told you that there will be as much activity as there was. We just respond to when we look to deliver for our clients in it. Now
column273: you could paint a picture of a declining debt environment
column274: but also you could see debt transactions of significant swing to mergers. We have seen some of that Europe recovery and a long-term shift to the capital markets
column275: growth markets shifting more towards capital markets due to very long-term trends that are in place. Simple
column276:
we will say.

"
column277:
"

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column278:

Your next question is from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities. Please go ahead.

Devin Ryan - JMP Securities

So I just have a question on the FICC business. I asked a similar question last quarter but we have now seen outflows out of bound

So no change in behavior that then I would come in touch with. You know the behavioral changes have been more response to the news dynamic during the course of the year. The issues that I talked about you know what does tapering mean versus QE? What are the government shutdown mean? Those were the kind of things that were little paralyzing at times for clients I think as they contemplated the implications. Obviously over very long periods of time fund flows have an impact potentially in the short one they can when there are dramatic controls [ph] whether it's in the matter with those bond funds or equity flows but I don\u2019t think yet we\u2019re seeing any major change in behavior.

"
column770:
"

And then just a question on comp
column771: can you give any color on the mix of cash versus restricted shares and whether there is any meaningful change from last year in terms of how you thought about that and then just more broadly what the competitive environment
column772:

Harvey Schwartz

column774:

No. So we don\u2019t disclose details on the competition there

column777: we thought about it for a long time. With respect to talent

column779: but certainly the last year and a half we have seen the ability to acquire talent when needed. And so now having said that

column1:
{"Goldman Sachs Group's Management Discusses Q1 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (NYSE:GS)

"
column7:
"

Dane Holmes - Head of Investor Relation

"
column8:
"

Harvey Schwartz - Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

"
column12:
"

Christian Bolu - Credit Suisse

"
column13:
"

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column20:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column22:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs first quarter 2014 earnings conference call. This call is being recorded today
column27:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column28:
Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call.

"
column29:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column31: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column32:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 2013.

"
column33:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column34: particularly as it relates to our investment banking transaction backlog
column36:
risk weighted assets and global core excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column37:
"

This audio cast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column38: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column39:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column40:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column41: Harvey Schwartz
column42:
will now review the firm's results. Harvey?

"
column45: Dane
column46:
and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through our first quarter results. I am obviously happy to answer any questions.

"
column47:
"

Net revenues were $9.3 billion
column48: net earnings $2 billion
column49: earnings per diluted share were $4.02 and our annualized return on common equity was 10.9%. The first quarter reinforced two consistent themes that we have seen over the past few years. First
column50: the continued uncertainty around the strength of the global economic recovery; and second
column51:
the dominant role that central banks play in driving broad economic activity and capital market sentiment.

"
column52:
"

With respect to the first
column53: market participants struggle to reconcile mixed economic data across different regional economies that weigh the prospect of a strengthening U.S economy against an improved
column54: but still relatively weak European economy and a slowing economy in Asia. As it relates to the second theme
column55:
discussions among market participants are also centered on the potential for additional central bank activity.

"
column56:
"

In United States
column57: the focus remain on the pace and potential magnitude of further tapering to the Federal Reserves bond buying program. In Europe
column58: the market attempted to weigh the potential for either negative interest rates or the introduction of an asset purchasing program. In Asia
column59:
market participants questioned whether the upcoming hike in Japan's consumption tax would weaken positive momentum and require the Bank of Japan to boost its quantitative easing.

"
column60:
"

Given the uncertainty surrounding the outlook for central bank activity
column61: it is understandable that overall client sentimental risk appetite was subdued. With this backdrop
column62: we are all reminded of the importance of a strong and diversified business. With respect to the client franchise at Goldman Sachs
column63:
we continue to see strong relative positioning and performance across all of our businesses.

"
column64:
"

Within investment banking
column65: we maintained our market leading position in completed M&A. We advised on 31 value transactions
column66: valued at $1 billion or more
column67: the highest number in the industry. We helped underwrite $55 billion in global equity offerings during the quarter
column68: making us the market leader. We also helped to bring a $194 billion of high yield and investment grade debt offerings to market
column69:
which is a quarterly record for debt underwriting volume.

"
column70:
"

Within investment management
column71: total assets under supervision reached a record $1.08 trillion
column72: up 12% over the past year. Despite market headwinds
column73: our performance within FICC demonstrates the benefits of offering our clients a diversified product suite
column74: meeting their needs across rates
column75: credit
column76: currencies
column77: mortgages and commodities. Whether it's from a business
column78: products or regional perspective
column79:
the value of diversity was reinforced in the first quarter of 2014.

"
column80:
"

Now
column81: I'll discuss each of our businesses. In investment banking
column82: we produced first quarter net revenues of $1.8 billion
column83: up 4% from the fourth quarter. This was our highest quarterly performance since 2007. While investment banking backlog declined from yearend levels
column84:
it is up significantly compared to this time last year.

"
column85:
"

First quarter advisory revenues were $682 million
column86: up 17% sequentially. We advise on a number of significant transactions that closed during the first quarter
column87: including Vodafone's $130 billion disposal of its U.S. group
column88: whose principal asset is its 45% interest in Verizon Wireless. Cole Real Estate Investments' $10.9 billion sale through American Realty Capital Properties and Bristol-Myers Squibb sale of its global diabetes business to AstraZeneca for up to $4.3 billion
column89:
plus future royalties.

"
column90:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the first quarter. These include Safeway's $9.2 billion sale to an investor group
column91: led by Cerberus Capital Management
column92:
Hutchison Whampoa's $5.7 billion sale of a 25% stake in A.S. Watson to Temasek and Foster Wheeler's $2.9 billion sale to Amec.

"
column93:
"

Moving to underwriting. Net revenues were $1.1 billion in the first quarter
column94: down 3% compared to record fourth quarter results. Equity underwriting revenues of $437 million was 30% lower
column95: as industry-wide activity declined in the first quarter
column96: particularly for IPOs. Year-to-date
column97:
Goldman Sachs ranked first in global equity and equity-related common stock offerings in IPOs. Debt underwriting revenues increased 29% sequentially to $660 million due to higher issuance activity in both investment grade and leverage finance markets.

"
column98:
"

During the first quarter we were committed to meeting our clients' diverse financing needs. Whether it was McKesson's $5.5 billion bridge loan and $4.1 billion investment grade notes offering or Hong Kong Electric Investments' $3.1 billion IPO or X2 Resources' $2.5 billion private placement.

"
column99:
"

Turning to institutional client services
column100: which comprises both our FICC and equity businesses
column101: net revenues were $4.4 billion in the first quarter
column102: up 31% compared to the weaker fourth quarter. FICC client execution net revenues were $2.9 billion in the first quarter. Excluding DVA
column103:
net revenues were up 50% sequentially.

"
column104:
"

Rates and mortgages were both up significantly relative to the weak forth quarter
column105: although client activity and volatility remain relatively muted. Credit improved slightly and was supported by stable credit markets. Commodities revenues improved significantly relative to a weak fourth quarter
column106:
as market volatility and client activity increases. Currency was modestly lower sequentially.

"
column107:
"

Equities includes equities client execution
column108: commissions and fees and security services. Net revenues for the first quarter were $1.6 billion. Excluding DVA
column109: results were down 7% sequentially. Equities client execution net revenues
column110: up $416 million
column111: were down significantly due to less favorable market condition in certain areas
column112: including emerging markets in Asia
column113:
particularly Japan.

"
column114:
"

Commissions and fees were $828 million
column115: up 11% relative to the fourth quarter on solid cash volumes. Security services generated net revenues of $352 million
column116: up 4% sequentially. Turning to risk
column117: average daily VaR in the first quarter was $82 million
column118:
roughly consistent with fourth quarter levels.

"
column119:
"

Moving on to our investing and lending activities. Collectively
column120: these businesses produced net revenues of $1.5 billion in the first quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $702 million
column121: primarily reflecting company-specific events
column122:
including divestitures and pending IPOs.

"
column123:
"

Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $597 million and benefited from net gains on certain investments and net interest income. Other revenues of $230 million include revenues from the firm's consolidated investments.

"
column124:
"

In investment management we reported first quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion. Management and other fees were roughly flat sequentially at $1.2 billion. Incentive fees were largely driven by performance fee related to the sale of an investment.

"
column125:
"

During the first quarter
column126: assets under supervision increased $41 billion to a record $1.08 trillion. This growth was driven by record long-term net inflows of $40 billion
column127: largely in fixed income assets. During the quarter
column128: long-term net flows were strong across each of our client distribution channels
column129: institutional
column130: high net worth and third party. During the quarter
column131: we also had market appreciation of $14 billion
column132:
largely in fixed income and equity assets.

"
column133:
"

Now
column134: let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column135: which includes salaries
column136: bonuses
column137: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefit
column138: was accrued at a compensation to net revenues ratio of 43%
column139:
which is consistent with the accrual in the first quarter of 2013.

"
column140:
"

First quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.3 billion
column141: 24% lower than the fourth quarter and down modestly from the first quarter of 2013. The fourth quarter included higher litigation and regulatory expenses
column142:
higher charitable contributions and higher impairment charges on consolidated investment entities.

"
column143:
"

Total staff at the end of the first quarter was approximately 32
column145:
down 1% from yearend 2013. Our effective tax rate was 32.7% for the first quarter.

"
column146:
"

In terms of capital
column147: there are a number of items to cover. First
column148: during the quarter we repurchased 10.3 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.7 billion. These repurchases reflected the completion of our 2013 capital plan. As previously announced
column149:
the Federal Reserve did not object to our revised 2014 proposed capital actions.

"
column150:
"

With respect to our regulatory capital ratio
column151: the Federal Reserve has approved the firm to come off the parallel run. And therefore
column152: starting in the second quarter
column153: our capital ratios are determined under the transitional provisions of Basel III. As a result
column154: the transitional ratios are not only the most relevant
column155:
but also a better assessment of our risk-based capitalization.

"
column156:
"

Our Basel III common equity Tier I ratio on a transitional basis was 11.3%
column157: using the advanced approach. Under the standardized approach
column158: our transitional ratio was 10.9%. Risk-weighted assets under the advanced approach are approximately $600 billion
column159: $355 billion in credit risk
column160:
$155 billion in market risk and $90 billion in operational risk.

"
column161:
"

Let me make a few brief points on the supplementary leverage ratio. Given that the proposed rule hasn't been finalized and won't take effect until 2018
column162: to date
column163: we have not taken any significant actions. When we have a final rule
column164:
there are multiple options that we can pursue.

"
column165:
"

On the capital side of the equation
column166: our regulatory capital levels benefit from a natural tailwind over time as we comply with the Volcker Rule. As you know
column167: we have investments and funds
column168: where we invest alongside our clients. Under the Volcker Rule
column169: we are required to significantly reduce our level of fund investments
column170:
which currently creates an approximately $9 billion capital reduction.

"
column171:
"

With respect to the asset side of the equation
column172: there are also steps we can take if needed. For example
column173: as of yearend
column174:
we had over $260 billion of asset associated with secured client financing activities. These are generally lower-risk collateralized assets. We can ultimately decide if needed to reduce the lower returning portion within these balances.

"
column175:
"

Regarding the new proposal
column176: our best estimate today is 4.2%
column177: including the capital impact of reducing our fund investments to comply with the Volcker Rule
column178:
we estimate it would be 4.7%.

"
column179:
"

To sum it up
column180: we feel confident about our ability to comply in advance of 2018
column181: given the variety of actions that we can take. And we look forward to working with regulators to pursue the goal of enhanced safety and soundness
column182:
while continuing to serve our clients and support economic growth.

"
column183:
"

Before I take questions
column184: let me leave you with some closing thoughts. Our performance in the first quarter is reflective of the ongoing challenges facing the broader marketplace
column185:
as the global economy continues its slow recovery. This is being counterbalanced by the continued strength and diversity of our global client franchise.

"
column186:
"

A sluggish
column187: yet steady improvement in the global economy should drive greater confidence and the durability of the recovery. In response
column188: we would anticipate that market sentiment would improve
column189:
which should ultimately drive from our client activity and greater risk appetite.

"
column190:
"

And the management team
column191: we're focused on two primary goals. First
column192: to focus the bulk of our resources on serving our clients and in the process grow our single-most valuable asset
column193:
our global franchise.

"
column194:
"

Our second goal is to take a disciplined approach to adjusting and reengineering our businesses
column195: so that we are well-position to protect returns in the current environment
column196: and more importantly maximize returns
column197: when a more favorable environment emerges. Simply stated
column198: the goal is to consistently provide superior results for you
column199: our shareholders
column200:
across the cycle.

"
column201:
"

Thank you again for dialing in. And now
column202:
I'm happy to answer your questions.

{"Goldman Sachs (GS) Q3 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

The Goldman Sachs Group
column7:

Dane Holmes - Investor Relations

Glenn Schorr \u2013 ISI Group Inc.

Devin Ryan - JMP Securities

"
column24:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Third Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded today
column29:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column30: Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call. Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that
column32: are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column34:
from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements.

"
column35:
"

For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column36: please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 2013. I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column37: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column38: capital ratios
column39:
risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column40:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column41: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column42:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column45:
will now review the firm's results. Harvey?

"
column46:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column47:
"

Thanks
column48: Dane
column49: and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through our third quarter results
column50:
then I'm obviously happy to answer any questions.

"
column51:
"

Third quarter net revenues were $8.4 billion; net earnings
column52: $2.2 billion; earnings per diluted share
column53: $4.57. Core to our strategy over the past few years has been a consistent focus on strengthening our relative position within the industry. Our success begins with a fundamental approach of engaging our clients
column54:
understanding their challenges and then addressing their needs. That is the foundation for expanding the breadth and depth of our existing relationships and the basis for building new ones.

"
column55:
"

For the first nine months in 2014
column56: revenues are 1.4 billion higher than this time last year. The increase reflects the combination of greater client activity in certain businesses and a strong market position. For example
column57: as client activity picked up in global M&A
column58:
you saw an increase in our market share. Our global market share in announced M&A for the year-to-date of 29% is up 300 basis points compared to 2013. Our volume advantage to our next closest peer is more than $100 billion.

"
column59:
"

We have also been focused on making sure that we are well positioned to deliver operating leverage as client activity increases. In 2011
column60: we announced an operating efficiency initiative. This initiative was subsequently increased twice and ultimately reached nearly $2 billion. We continue to expand upon that prior initiative to grow margins and increase returns. The benefits of those efforts are demonstrated in our year-to-date results. We had 1.4 billion of incremental revenues and nearly $1 billion of incremental pre-tax earnings. Ultimately
column61: the embedded operating leverage contributed to an improvement in our year-to-date annualized return on common equity to 11.2%. We have also achieved this result by being a prudent allocator of our global resources. Getting this right not only drives positive results for our clients
column62:
but also for our shareholders.

"
column63:
"

Now let me take you through the quarterly results for each of our businesses. In Investment Banking
column64: we produced third quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion
column65: down 18% compared to a strong second quarter. Importantly
column66: our investment banking backlog increased again during the quarter
column67: reaching its highest level since 2007. Third quarter advisory revenues were 594 million
column68: up 17% from the second quarter on an increase in completed activity. Year-to-date Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the third quarter
column69: including Hillshire Brands' $8.6 billion sales to Tyson Foods
column70: InterMune\u2019s $8.3 billion sale to Roche Holdings and Gates Corporation\u2019s $5.4 billion sale to Blackstone. We're also an advisor on a number of significant announced transactions. For example
column71: we\u2019re advising on TRW Automotive's $13.5 billion sale to ZF Friedrichshafen
column72:
Siemens' $7.6 billion acquisition of Dresser-Rand and Corio's \u20ac7.2 billion sale to Kl\u00e9pierre.

"
column73:
"

Moving to underwriting. Net revenues were 870 million in the third quarter
column74: down 32% compared to record second quarter results. Equity underwriting revenues
column75: up 426 million
column76: were 22% lower sequentially as industry wide activity decline in the third quarter across secondary offerings. Year-to-date
column77:
Goldman Sachs ranked first in global equity and equity related and common stock offerings. Debt underwriting revenues decreased 39% from a record second quarter to 444 million due to reduced activity particularly within leverage finance.

"
column78:
"

During the third quarter
column79: we remained committed to meeting our clients' diverse finance needs
column80: whether it was Alibaba\u2019s $25 billion IPO
column81:
Sysco\u2019s $5 billion financing in support of its acquisition of US Foods or ADP's $1.6 billion high-yield offering.

"
column82:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services. Net revenues were $3.8 billion in the third quarter with FICC Client Execution of 2.2 billion and Equities of $1.6 billion. ICS includes a one-time $270 million gain related to the tender of a portion of our trust preferred security. Excluding the fixed portion of the one-time gain in DVA
column83: FICC Client Execution net revenues were $2 billion in the third quarter
column84: down 11% sequentially. Mortgages declined quarter-over-quarter as clients were less active amid a relatively stable backdrop of prices. Credit declined significantly as increased volatility
column85: wider credit spreads and lower issuance provided a more difficult backdrop. Currencies
column86:
interest rates and commodities were all higher sequentially as volatility and volumes generally increased from relatively low levels.

"
column87:
"

When you exclude equities portion of the one-time gain in DVA
column88: the results within this segment were as follows. Total Equities net revenues were $1.5 billion
column89: down 10% sequentially; Equities Client Execution net revenues of $372 million were down 26% quarter-over-quarter reflecting lower net revenues in cash products; commissions and fees were 745 million
column90: relatively flat with the second quarter; securities services generated net revenues of 343 million
column91:
down 8% sequentially from the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column92:
"

Turning to risk. Average daily VaR in the third quarter was 66 million
column93: down 14% relative to the second quarter
column94:
mostly driven by interest rates.

"
column95:
"

Moving on to our Investing & Lending activities. Collectively they produced net revenues of $1.7 billion in the third quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of 876 million
column96: primarily reflecting company specific events including IPOs and net gains in public equities. For example
column97: one of our investments
column98:
Mobileye went public and our investment generated 285 million in net gains during the third quarter. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were 606 million and benefited from net gains on certain investments due to asset sales and net interest income. Other revenues of 210 million include revenues from the Firm\u2019s consolidated investments.

"
column99:
"

In Investment Management
column100:
we reported third quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion. Management and other fees reached a record 1.21 billion. During the quarter total assets under supervision increased $8 billion to a record $1.15 trillion.

"
column101:
"

Let me quickly walk you through the long-term flows. Long-term assets under supervision had net inflows of $13 billion with 7 billion in equity assets and $6 billion in fixed income assets. This was largely offset by foreign currency translation which drove net market depreciation of $12 billion. As we have discussed before
column102: the key to long-term success is delivering strong and consistent performance for our Investment Management clients. Across the global platform
column103:
81% of our client mutual funds' assets ranked in the top two quartiles on a three-year basis and 76% ranked in the top two quartiles on a five-year basis.

"
column104:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column105: which includes salaries
column106: bonuses
column107: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column108: was accrued at a compensation-to-net revenues ratio of 40%. This is 300 basis points lower than the Firm's accrual in the first half of the year. The lower compensation accrual reflects stronger year-to-date revenues
column109: greater clarity on full year compensation levels and our continued efforts to improve operating efficiency across the firm. Third quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.3 billion
column110:
down 4% sequentially.

"
column111:
"

Now let me quickly run you through some key stats. Total staff at the end of the third quarter was approximately 33
column112: 500. This is up 3% from the second quarter due to summer hiring. Our effective tax rate was 31% year-to-date. Our global core excess liquidity ended the quarter at $180 million. Our Basel III common equity Tier 1 ratio was 11.8% using the advanced approach. It was 11.1% under the standardized approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished the quarter at 4.9% based on the final rules. We repurchased 7.1 million shares of common stock for $1.25 billion during the quarter. And finally
column113:
we announced an increase in our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.55 to $0.60 per share.

"
column114:
"

Before we turn to Q&A
column115: let me leave you with some concluding thoughts. A constant in our history as a public company is an unrelenting desire to provide world class service to our clients and superior returns to our shareholders. Given the dynamic nature of our industry
column116: meeting that objective requires adaptability. Since we went public in 1999
column117: there are several examples that are readily available. We went from 250 billion assets in 1999 to 1.2 trillion in 2008 and then back to approximately $870 billion today. And along the way we made Goldman Sachs a stronger firm. We increased our common equity from $10 million to over $70 billion and substantially increased our liquidity pool which now fits at $180 billion. We have expanded our global footprint and increased the diversity of our franchise. Our number of offices is up by more than a third to over 50 with one quarter of our staff located in Bangalore
column118: Salt Lake City
column119:
Singapore and Texas.

"
column120:
"

Back in 1999
column121: we had approximately 3
column122: 000 people in our technology division. Now we have nearly 8
column123: 000. They represent close to a quarter of the firm. We also built an Asset Management business
column124: largely organically
column125: from a few hundred million assets under supervision to 1.15 trillion today. By adapting
column126: we\u2019ve fundamentally improved the strength of our Firm
column127: our opportunity set and as a result our ability to deliver for our clients and our shareholders. Going forward
column128: we will make any necessary changes to continue our history of providing superior client service and generating industry leading returns. It\u2019s what our clients
column129:
our shareholders and our culture demands.

"
column130:
"

Now just before I take your questions
column131: I\u2019d like to make one additional closing comment about the market environment we\u2019ve seen over the past week and particularly yesterday and this morning. It\u2019s clearly an environment that reminds all of us about the power of investor sentiment and how fragile it can be at times. Yesterday in particular
column132: it was clearly a market in the morning where investors were
column133: quite frankly
column134: shooting first and asking questions later. We've seen this market reaction in the past. And while painful
column135:
it\u2019s somewhat a normal part of how markets function. Clearly investors are now debating whether we\u2019ll see lower rates for longer and more importantly whether the global economy is slowing or continuing to grow. These are questions that the market has certainly debated before. We\u2019ve always believed that over the long term markets follow fundamentals.

"
column136:
"

In speaking with our economists only yesterday
column137: they would argue that nothing has fundamentally changed in the past few weeks or certainly the last 24 hours regarding the long-term outlook for the global economy. That doesn\u2019t mean it will continue to grow
column138: but it certainly doesn\u2019t mean it will stall. For us
column139: in any environment
column140:
it\u2019s always about staying close to our clients. Yesterday was a difficult day for many of them. Our focus is being there for them. We have the intellectual capital and the financial capital to help address their needs and we remain committed to doing it.

"
column141:
"

With that
column142:
I\u2019m happy to take any of your questions.

column753: increases in risk-weighted assets reductions in balance sheet globally in terms of the entire industry and what that means for market liquidity. And we\u2019ve certainly seen areas where people \u2013 I haven't looked at all the data
column754: but most firms at this stage have actually shrunk their match books. I think I\u2019m pretty accurate in saying that. And so all market participants
column756:
have been asking themselves the question of when we were seeing increases in sales and treasuries whether how much of that was driven by market makers' inability or lack of appetite or not being able to position balance sheet in terms of providing that liquidity at important times.

"
column757:
"

We'll have to see again how all this evolves. When you look at Goldman Sachs today given the level of our capital ratios
column758: which I described earlier in the call
column759:
we certainly have the capacity to deliver for our clients when they need it.

"
column762:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column763:
"

Thank you.

"
column764:
"

Operator

"
column765:
"

Your next question comes from the line Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW. Please go ahead.

"
column766:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl - KBW

"
column768:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column770:
Brian.

"
column771:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl - KBW

"
column773: when you look at some of the regulations coming down the road here and also funding surcharge being one of them and the NSFR
column774: both of those would benefit from a greater level of deposit funding on the balance sheet in effect. Are you thinking about growing deposits currently? And if you are
column775:
kind of are you thinking about organically or through acquisition or are you just not going to think about it at all?

"
column776:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column777:
"

So we obviously focus on -- I think in the context at the moment
column778: this will be very interesting because
column779: you mentioned NSFR so let's just use that as an example. I think as an example of a rule and a concept
column780:
I think again that falls into the bucket of a good concept because you want good asset liability management across the industry. We spend a huge amount of time on asset liability management the way that we look at secure funding and how we manage our balance sheet and we run a very conservative profile in terms of how we manage that.

"
column781:
"

With respect in this rule
column782: it will be very interesting because we haven\u2019t even seen the Basel rule yet. I think the big question will be again
column783: when you add this rule on to other rules if there are some long term impact on market liquidity so obviously clients and we will be very focused on that. As this goes to the rule-making process because you specifically make just a deposit
column784: it will be very interesting when you get to the U.S. because as you know in the U.S. it\u2019s a different legal structure in terms of your ability to use deposit funding for certain businesses. And so not only do we need to wait to see the Basel rule
column785:
but then we\u2019ll need to see the U.S. rule and how they incorporate just a different legal structure that exists in the U.S. So we\u2019ll have to see how it goes.

"
column786:
"

Brian Kleinhanzl - KBW

"
column787:
"

Okay. And just a separate question on the ECM backlog. Is there any specific reason that\u2019s kind of driving strength there? I think you said last quarter Europe was strong in underwriting but this quarter has that changed?

"
column788:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column789:
"

No
column790:
it's just a normal part of the marketplace in terms of people coming to the markets and raising capital for a variety of needs. But there is no key driver.

"
column792:
"

Okay
column793:
great. Thanks.

"
column794:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column795:
"

Thanks.

"
column796:
"

Operator

"
column797:
"

And at this time there are no further questions. Please continue with any closing remarks.

"
column798:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column799:
"

So again
column800: since there are no more questions
column801: I would like to take a moment to thank all of you for joining the call. Hopefully I and other members of the senior management will get to see you many of you in the coming months. Certainly if there is any additional questions
column802: please don\u2019t hesitate to reach out to Dane. And otherwise
column803:
enjoy the rest of your day. Look forward to speaking with you on the fourth quarter call. Take care.

"

Operator

this does conclude the Goldman Sachs Third Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.

column1:
{"Goldman Sachs (GS) Q4 2014 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

The Goldman Sachs Group
column7:
"

Harvey Schwartz - CFO

"
column10:
"

Glenn Schorr with - Evercore ISI

"
column11:

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column12:
"

Christian Bolu - Credit Suisse

"
column18:

Fiona Swaffield - RBC Capital Markets

"
column20:

Chris Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co.

"

"
column25:

Douglas Sipkin - Susquehanna Financial Group

"
column28:
