Richard Bove - Rafferty Capital Markets.

"
column31:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis and I\u2019ll be your conference facilitator today. I\u2019d like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded today
column34:
you may begin your conference.

"
column36:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column37: Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call. Today\u2019s call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the Firm\u2019s belief regarding future events that
column38: by their nature
column39: are uncertain and outside of the Firm\u2019s control. The Firm\u2019s actual results and financial condition may differ
column40: possibly materially
column41:
from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements.

"
column42:
"

For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the Firm\u2019s future results
column43: please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 2013. I\u2019d also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column44: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column45: capital ratios
column46:
risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our Web site at www.gs.com.

"
column47:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column48: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column49:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column50:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column51: Harvey Schwartz
column52:
will now review the Firm\u2019s results. Harvey?

"
column53:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column55: Dane
column56:
and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through the fourth quarter and full-year results. Then I\u2019m obviously happy to answer any questions.

"
column57:
"

Briefly on the fourth quarter
column58: net revenues were $7.7 billion. Net earnings were $2.2 billion and earnings per diluted share were $4.38. With respect to our annual results
column59: we had firm-wide net revenues of $34.5 billion
column60: net earnings of $8.5 billion
column61:
earnings per diluted share of $17.07 and a return on common equity of 11.2%.

"
column62:
"

Revenues were roughly consistent with last year. We grew net earnings by 5%
column63: book value per share by 7%
column64: and earnings per diluted share by 10%. If we take a step back and assess 2014
column65:
there have been challenges to the global economy and therefore the operating environment for our clients.

"
column66:
"

We have seen a global economy that has been grinding itself towards growth. Different countries are naturally at different stages of the economic cycle and the interconnectedness of these different economies has made the transition to growth somewhat extended
column67: choppy
column68:
and oftentimes unpredictable.

"
column69:
"

Having a global client footprint means that we\u2019re impacted by both global and regional fluctuations. Most importantly
column70: it also means that we're a diversified enterprise. The consistency of our annual revenues is a testament to both the products and geographic diversity of our operations
column71:
and the stability they collectively provide.

"
column72:
"

Weakness in Asia or Europe can be offset by strength in the U.S. Headwinds in institutional client services can be offset by strength in investment banking or investment management. Ultimately
column73:
our shareholders own a combination of industry-leading global businesses that have collectively generated superior returns.

"
column74:
"

We've also achieved our results in the face of significant regulatory change. The financial services industry and our Firm specifically
column75: have been responding to unprecedented levels of new regulation. The regulators and the industry have done a tremendous amount of work here and as a result have made the system stronger
column76:
and significantly safer.

"
column77:
"

Since 2012
column78: we undertook several strategic initiatives to respond to new regulations and at the same time derisk the firm. This included a $55 billion balance sheet reduction over the past year. In addition
column79: we sold our Americas reinsurance business
column80: we sold our European insurance business and we liquidated our investment in ICBC. Along with those actions
column81:
we also sold our hedge fund administration business and our ready platform.

"
column82:
"

In 2012
column83: the businesses and investments that I just listed produced $2.3 billion in revenue. As a result
column84:
since then we had to replace in excess of $2 billion of revenues in 2014 just to match 2012 levels.

"
column85:
"

As I said
column86: the last three years have required us to adapt and source new revenue opportunities at attractive returns. Between 2012 and 2014
column87: investment banking and investment management generated $2.4 billion of incremental revenues. This achievement demonstrates the strength of our client franchise
column88: the diversity of our operations
column89:
the commitment and quality of our people and our culture of adaptability.

"
column90:
"

Now I\u2019ll discuss each of our businesses starting with Investment Banking. Before digging into the details here
column91: it\u2019s worth noting a few achievements from 2014. We were number one in M&A
column92:
advising on more than $1 trillion in announced transactions. We also ranked first in global equity and equity-related and common stock offerings.

"
column93:
"

As it relates to the quarter
column94: Investment Banking produced net revenues of $1.4 billion
column95: slightly lower than the third quarter. A decline in underwriting activity offset a pick up in completed M&A. For the full-year
column96: Investment Banking net revenues were $6.5 billion
column97:
up 8% from 2013 on the back of a significant improvement in advisory revenues and modestly higher equity underwriting revenues. This was slightly offset by lower debt underwriting revenues following record results in 2013.

"
column98:
"

Breaking down the components of Investment Banking in the fourth quarter
column99: advisory revenues were $692 million; the 16% increase relative of the third quarter reflects the increase in industry-wide completed M&A. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the fourth quarter
column100: including Walgreen\u2019s $15.3 billion acquisition of the remaining 55% interest in Alliance Boots
column101: Royal KPN\u2019s 8.4 billion euro of E-plus to Telefonica
column102:
Deutschland and Athlon Energy\u2019s $7.1 billion sale to Encana.

"
column103:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the fourth quarter
column104: including Allergan\u2019s $66 billion sale to Actavis
column105:
Baker Hughes $38 billion sale to Halliburton and Talisman Energy\u2019s $13 billion sale to Repsol.

"
column106:
"

Moving to underwriting
column107: net revenues were $748 million in the fourth quarter
column108: down 14% sequentially with both equity and debt issuance slowed. Equity underwriting revenues of $342 million
column109:
were down 20% compared to third quarter results largely due to a decrease in secondary offerings and private placements. Debt underwriting revenues decreased 9% to $406 million due to a significant decline in leverage finance activity.

"
column110:
"

During the fourth quarter
column111: we actively supported our clients' financing needs
column112: participating in Becton Dickinson\u2019s $7.2 billion financing to support their purchase of CareFusion
column113:
ICBC\u2019s $5.6 billion debt offering and Fiat Chrysler\u2019s $4 billion common stock and convertible offering. Our Investment Banking backlog improved from third quarter levels and finished at its highest level since 2007.

"
column114:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column115: which comprises both our FICC and equities businesses. Net revenues were $3.1 billion in the fourth quarter
column116: down 17% compared to the third quarter. For the full-year
column117: $15.2 million of net revenues were down 3% relative to 2013. FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.2 billion in the fourth quarter and include a $55 million of DVA gains. Excluding DVA
column118: and last quarter\u2019s gain related to our trust preferred tender
column119:
revenues were down 41% sequentially as certain businesses were impacted by either lower client activity or more difficult market making conditions.

"
column120:
"

Interest rates were lower sequentially as client activity declined amid a challenging environment. Credit decreased as the market was characterized by widening high-yield spreads and low levels of liquidity.

"
column121:
"

Mortgages declined versus the third quarter
column122: as volatility and client activity were generally low. While currencies was lower than a very robust third quarter
column123: volatility remain high and client activity were still solid. Even higher volatility and energy markets
column124: commodities improved sequentially and were supported by stronger client activity levels. For the full-year
column125: FICC client execution net revenues were $0.5 billion
column126: down 2% year-over-year. Excluding DVA
column127: the gain related to our trust preferred tender
column128: and the impact of the 2013 European Insurance sale
column129:
revenues were down 5% relative to 2013.

"
column130:
"

In equities
column131: which includes equities client execution
column132: commissions and fees and security services
column133: net revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.9 billion
column134:
up 21% sequentially and included $27 million in DVA gains. Equities Client Execution revenues increased 75% sequentially to $751 million due to a more favorable backdrop with higher equity prices and increased client activity.

"
column135:
"

Commissions and Fees were $829 million
column136: up 11% relative to the third quarter supported by an increase in client volumes. Security Services generated net revenues of $351 million
column137:
up 2% sequentially adjusting for last quarter\u2019s gain related to our trust preferred tender.

"
column138:
"

For the full-year
column139: equities produced net revenues of $6.7 billion
column140: down 5% year-over-year. Excluding DVA
column141: the gain related to our trust preferred tender and the 2013 sale of our reinsurance business
column142:
results were down 4% relative to 2013.

"
column143:
"

Turning to risk. Average daily VaR in the fourth quarter was $63 million
column144:
down from $66 million in the third quarter with the largest decrease coming from interest rates.

"
column145:
"

Moving on to our Investing & Lending activities. Collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $982 million
column146: primarily reflecting company specific events including initial public offerings and gains in public equity investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $358 million
column147:
which was relatively balanced between net interest income and net gains on certain investments. Other revenues of $192 million include the Firm\u2019s consolidated investments.

"
column148:
"

In the fourth quarter
column149: we sold our investment in Metro International. For the fourth quarter and full-year
column150: Metro contributed $70 million and $325 million respectively to other revenues. For the full-year
column151: Investing and Lending generated net revenues of $6.8 billion
column152: driven by $3.8 billion in gains from equity securities
column153:
$2.2 billion of net revenues from debt securities and loans and $847 million of other revenues.

"
column154:
"

In Investment Management
column155: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion
column156: up 7% from the third quarter primarily as a result of $200 million in incentive fees largely from alternative asset products. Management and other fees were up 1% sequentially to a record $1.23 billion. For the full-year
column157: Investment Management net revenues were a record $6 billion
column158: up 11% from 2013 on record management and other fees which benefited from growth in our assets under supervision. During the fourth quarter assets under supervision increased $28 billion to a record $1.18 trillion
column159:
due to net inflows into liquidity products.

"
column160:
"

On a full-year basis
column161:
we have long-term fixed income inflows of $58 billion and equity inflows of $15 billion. Alternative inflows were $1 billion and included $6 billion from fund of funds offset by net outflows from other private equity and credit funds.

"
column162:
"

Moving to our performance
column163: across the globe
column164:
83% of our client mutual fund assets ranked in the top two quartiles on a three-year basis. And 75% ranked in the top two quartiles on a five-year basis.

"
column165:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column166: which includes salaries
column167: bonuses
column168: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column169:
remain roughly flat at $12.7 billion for 2014 and translated into a compensation-to-net revenues ratio of 36.8%.

"
column170:
"

Fourth quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.5 billion
column171: 11% higher than the third quarter
column172: reflecting $137 million donation to Goldman Sachs Gives
column173: our donor advised charitable fund. For the full-year
column174: non-compensation expenses were down 4%
column175:
primarily due to lower provisions for litigation and regulatory expenses.

"
column176:
"

Total staff at year-end was approximately 34
column178:
up 3% from year-end 2013. Our effective tax rate was 31.4% for 2014. Our global core excess liquidity end of the quarter at $183 billion. Our Basel III Common Equity Tier 1 ratio was 12.2% using the advanced approach. It was 11.3% under the standardized approach.

"
column179:
"

Our supplementary leverage ratio finished the quarter at 5%. The Firm is now compliant with the 2018 minimum.

"
column180:
"

We repurchased 6.6 million shares of common stock for $1.25 billion during the quarter. For the full-year
column181: we repurchased $5.5 billion helping to reduce our average fully delivered share count by 26 million shares year-over-year. In addition
column182: we increased our quarterly dividend to $0.60 per share in the fourth quarter and paid out approximately $1 billion of common dividends during the year. In total
column183:
we return $6.5 billion of capital to shareholders while at the same time continuing to grow our regulatory capital ratios.

"
column184:
"

Now before I take your questions
column185: let me offer some closing thoughts. Looking back on our performance in 2014
column186: the Firm continued to execute on its operating strategy. We remain committed to our clients
column187: providing superior service and execution which is central to building any long-term relationship. The strength of our client franchise is reflected in our returns and our leading market position. For example
column188:
we ended the year as the global leader M&A with more than $1 trillion in announced transactions. This is nearly $250 billion greater than our next closest competitor.

"
column189:
"

We were ranked first in global equity
column190: and equity related and common stock offerings for 2014. We helped deliver nearly $300 billion in equity capital from our investing clients to our corporate clients. We executed more than 2 billion transactions for our institutional investing clients across equities
column191: fixed income
column192: currencies
column193:
and commodities. And we\u2019re the trusted investment manager for in excess of $1 trillion in assets. Our track record of performing for our clients has translated into a leading market position within each of our businesses.

"
column194:
"

Another area of focus has been on our efficiency
column195: well operating efficiency and capital. We announced an expense initiative from a position of strength in 2011. We believe this was an important step
column196:
which positioned us to remain externally focused over the past three years. Continued discipline on compensation levels and focus on non-compensation expenses has contributed to 300 basis points of pre-tax margin expansion since 2012.

"
column197:
"

Our capital philosophy is also clear. Having a strong capital base
column198: not only allows our firm to be front footed in helping our clients capturing opportunities
column199: but also provides protection in more difficult operating environments. The existence of multiple capital regulations has materially increased the need for robust capital planning tools. To try better capital efficiency and comply with new regulatory requirements
column200: we\u2019ve developed critical technology and operating infrastructure to inform our allocation decisions. While they can never replace good judgment
column201:
these tools certainly help to inform it.

"
column202:
"

In closing
column203: Goldman Sachs is essentially made up of our clients
column204: your capital
column205:
and our people. Our Firm stands ready to use its financial and intellectual capital to serve our clients through this evolving period in the global economy. We are committed to consistently delivering the Firm and its entirety to our clients and maximizing our impact. And we\u2019re equally committed to generating superior returns for our shareholders through the cycle.

"
column206:
"

Thank you again for dialing in. And now I'm happy to answer any questions.

"
column207:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column208:
"

Operator

"
column209:
"

[Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI. Please go ahead.

"
column210:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column211:
"

Hi. Thanks very much.

"
column212:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column213:
"

Hey
column214: good morning
column215:
Glenn.

"
column217:
"

Good morning. First one on Investing and Lending. You had mentioned that there are a bunch of sales inside the equity piece. Would you mind just updating us on what\u2019s left in the book equity wise that eventually has to be liquidated for Goldman? And in conjunction with that
column218:
have you been replacing on balance sheet to backfill?

"
column220:
"

So we will just take a step back. You remember from the third quarter
column221: the Investing and Lending balance sheet was roughly $76 billion
column222: which broke down roughly 14 -- $4 billion of public equity
column223: $18 billion of private equity and the balance really -- the vast majority of the balance sheet in that north of $50 billion. And so in terms of the -- in the equity line
column224: I think what you\u2019re continuing to see is just really the idiosyncratic performance of the portfolio. We\u2019ve guided you over time that over long periods the portfolio will correlate with the MSEI [ph] or other public indices and -- but there will still be times where we will outperform that or under-perform that. And in this particular quarter
column225: there were -- really the vast majority of the gains in the portfolio were driven by things that we refer to as event driven. So it was either the potential for very near-term IPO we took something public where there was a refinancing event. We don\u2019t look at this of course on a quarterly basis
column226: but you will remember I highlighted to you in the last quarter that when we\u2019ve taken Mobileye public it had contributed $285 million in revenues and that would be an example of something that it was down during the course of the quarter
column227: that was down a bit more than $70 million. In terms of reinvesting and the portfolio
column228: our strategy here is unchanged in terms of our philosophy
column229: in terms of how we think about the capital. Where we can deploy capital to our clients and where we can find attractive returns
column231: but we\u2019re going to be very disciplined about the kind of returns that we can gain out of the marketplace. And so you will continue to see us do this one good thing in the quarter that you saw was that the regulators finalized the extension of the Volcker Rule and so there will be two one year extension there. So that was good to see as -- I think it was thoughtful by the regulators
column232:
because it will -- would have otherwise we might have seen fire sales across the marketplace.

"
column233:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column235: Goldman\u2019s equity piece left? I think it went from 9 to 8 to 6
column236:
if my memory serves me correctly. Where are we at now?

"
column237:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column238:
"

So are you talking about sort of -- there is two things that sometimes I didn\u2019t get [indiscernible]. I think if you\u2019re firmly [indiscernible] where the -- our investment is in terms of the private equity portfolio that was -- we were discussing under Volcker before the extensions
column239: that\u2019s roughly around $8 billion. There was some harvesting
column240: but that was offset by some gains. Again
column241: now that\u2019s an extended two years. If you're talking about the significant financial institution reduction which is a separate number that relates to our Basel III capital ratios
column242:
that\u2019s now roughly about $5 billion.

"
column243:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column244:
"

Okay
column245:
perfect. That's what I was looking for.

"
column246:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column247:
"

Sorry
column248:
I wasn\u2019t sure exactly. I probably should have gotten there faster.

"
column249:
"

Glenn Schorr

"
column251: I probably should have worded it better. So then a big picture question
column253: we are all bumming out that every volatility chart points down. Now rates
column256: FX volatility
column257: credit volatility all thumbs up
column258:
and all the banks get beaten up on inventories that we thought were a lot less. So could we talk about good vol versus bad vol and what we are supposed to root for?

"
column259:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column260:
"

Yes
column261: it\u2019s I don\u2019t know it\u2019s a little -- I guess it\u2019s -- what is it? Is it a Goldilocks? Its too cold
column262: its too hot? We can\u2019t find the right temperature. I think when you look -- I find it very interesting to sort of juxtapose the third quarter and the fourth quarter
column263: because I think it really highlights what you\u2019re saying. We came into the third quarter and as you said everybody bemoaning knew the fact that there was nothing happening in the world in July and then we got into the summer doldrums of August. And then we came back and foreign exchange was very active. There was a lot of momentum and you saw big uptick in client activity in certain parts of the business. Now we come into the fourth quarter and I don\u2019t know if you want to call it unhealthy volatility
column264: but in October we had our -- whatever you want to refer to in markets
column265: now referred to as the Treasury Flash Crash. And then
column267: the continuation of Russia
column268: a huge decline in the oil price
column269: which of course it started in June
column270: but nearly came into frame in the fourth quarter which weighed heavily on credit markets. And so
column271: I don't think when you look back in the fourth quarter
column272: any of this should be particularly surprising. When you see that much pressure on credit markets
column273: in terms of the ability as a market maker on the course of the quarter
column275: I don\u2019t think its particularly surprising
column276: particularly the stress that came under high-yield as a result of the energy decline. Now for us
column277: there were some real bright spots in the quarter in fixed income

column646:

column647: but in our dialogue with our clients we felt that in commodities this year. We\u2019ve seen it in other parts of the business. I guess
column648: what I would say is in an environment like this
column649: in terms of the competitive dynamic
column650: I think if you want to be in these businesses through the whole cycle
column651: I think some of the takeaway\u2019s are you have to have scale. It\u2019s very hard just to be in cash equities or to be in a very small component of the foreign exchange market. And you have to be able to leverage that scale really across the full franchise. It\u2019s not really just about the equity business
column652: the prime brokerage business or the commodity business. You need technology scale to really be effective through the whole cycle and then you need the diversity because as we\u2019ve seen some pistons will fire sometime and sometimes they won't at other points as we go through this. And so
column653: I know that\u2019s why we feel good about our competitive position because we know our clients still want to trade bonds
column654: and we know they still want to hedge FX and we know they still want to manage their commodity risk. As we work through this part of the cycle it\u2019s just about us being well positioned and having that scale
column655:
and we feel like we have it.

column1040:
"

That\u2019s fair enough. Thank you.

column1042:
"

Your next question is from the line of Douglas Sipkin with Susquehanna. Please go ahead.

"
column1045: thank you. Good morning. Two questions
column1046: first on fake and I\u2019m just curious for your guys perspective and opinion Harvey. I mean
column1047: given the sort of change in liquidity that\u2019s come to these markets in the last
column1048: lets call it five or six years since the credit crises. I mean
column1049: is your guys position that credit is maybe a little bit more vulnerable to smaller shocks given the lack of liquidity
column1050: i.e. I guess energy feels like it was the catalyst really for credit to weaken
column1053: its bigger but its only like 14%
column1055:
is it more pronounced now credit events given the lack of liquidities at your guy\u2019s perspective or it was just kind of a tough quarter?

"
column1057:
"

It will be very difficult to anticipate whether or not this is kind of a new credit regime in terms of liquidity trading or it is -- these are sort of one off factors. Its always hard to assess that when you\u2019ve had multiple years of timing credit spreads
column1058:
very low default rates. I will say when you look to the data I don\u2019t have it on top of my head particularly in Europe where liquidity was little challenged in the third quarter and then it got worse in the fourth quarter. I think because if market moves in terms of price movements they were pretty significant. More significant than you would have thought in terms of the underlying credit itself. And so clearly liquidity played a role in terms of the degree of price movement. But I wouldn\u2019t say at this stage you could draw any firm conclusions from that in terms of any long-term structural changes.

"
column1061: great. And then shifting to asset management
column1062: obviously a great year for you guys. I was little surprised to see sort of the fixed income bucket on the flow side a little flattish for the fourth quarter and I was wondering
column1063: did you guys close some strategies or did something change just given how strong you guys have done obviously with performance and some of your competitors struggling throughout the year
column1064:
and it still looked like fourth quarter industry wide that phenomena still played out. So I was just curious as to why you guys didn\u2019t sort of have the same flow dynamic you had throughout the first three quarters?

"
column1067: I even had a chance to dig through sort of competitor results and maybe get more transparency over time than we do
column1068:
but when we look at it over the course of the year which is really how we think about it. We took in $74 billion of long-term flows of which you highlighted $58 billion came in at fixed income. This could just be the timing of how various mandates that are rewarded arrive. We feel quite good about our performance and our ability to continue to gather assets on the back of that performance.

"
column1071:
great. Thanks for taking my questions.

column1082:

column1085:
that\u2019s the question. So I mean if those investigations go away is that kind of with the expense savings or be it was kind of more of a normalized level of litigation [ph]?

"

As we work through legacy costs

"

"

column1101:
"

Your next question comes from the line of your next question comes from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Securities. Please go ahead.

column1103:
"

Good morning. Please check your line to see if you\u2019re on mute.

column1111: how are you? That\u2019s only like the fifth time I\u2019ve done that in this earning cycle. So you -- I just wanted to follow-up on the RWA discussion and see Harvey

if you could just help me kind of understand what the puts and takes of it might be over the course of this year?

column1114:
"

Are you saying on a going forward basis?

column1120: again I would say there is two things that underscore. The first is we\u2019re going to continue to be very focused on further rule compliance and being efficient about the capital. But a lot of it will be driven by client activity. Obviously
column1121: we are well positioned from a capital perspective. And so
column1122: we really want to stay front footed at as we to the extent to which clients demand are capital. And so we feel well positioned. Hard for me to tell you what those demands are going to be as we sit here in January
column1123: but we feel very well positioned
column1126:
"

And in terms of the very broad based reduction in assets that you undertook over the course of this year. Is that -- should we view that as being largely completed or is that something that is still under consideration for you over the course of this coming year.

"
column1128:
"

So immediately\\ we have no media plans to reduce the balance sheet from here
column1129: but again that's going to be subject to review continuously. And so again
column1130: it will be dynamic. If we feel like we are not getting the proper returns
column1131: then we will look to reduce. Its really just about discipline
column1132:
at the same time making sure that we invest strategically for the long run.

"
column1135: if I guess get a transition for a moment and in terms of the M&A pipeline
column1136: could you give us any sense of the complexion of it is that primarily in country as it more across board. Are we seeing any changes
column1138: the real question is are we singing any changes in terms of the complexion of M&A activity

relative to what we\u2019ve seen over the -- this past year?

"
column1142: look in terms of year-over-year as you would expect the growth specifically in terms of the backlog

column1146:
"

And I mean what is the -- I guess I'm trying to understand is the strategic rational changing at all among corporate Boards and terms of growth orientation versus cost savings orientation or any kind of that kind of strategic level discussion.

column1149: when we talked to our M&A team
column1150: what they will tell you is very industry specific. It can be geographic
column1151: but the moment level is quite high and so I guess when you look back at it
column1152: I said earlier there were a number of folks who would say look we never see M&A again a couple of years ago and that was just where we want in a cycle
column1153: but I think that in a world which generally increasingly stable
column1155: but stable CEO\u2019s and boards will look to grow revenues and a strategic opportunity. The one thing that we\u2019ve seen as part of this past cycle

column1157:
look this is all cost driven or this is all top line driven. It\u2019s a mix of factors that will drive action. The momentum feels quite good.

column1163:
"

Your next question is from the line of Richard Bove with Rafferty Capital Markets. Please go ahead.

"
column1167:
"

Good morning. This is kind of a broad question. So I apologize
column1169: but over the past couple of days having getting questions on both sides of Goldman Sachs
column1170: if you will. While in terms of structure
column1171: one is given everything hat you\u2019ve mentioned about capital and constraints on the business placed by the regulators. Should in fact Goldman Sachs be broken up? And if not
column1172: why should it be kept together? The other side being asked
column1173: given the high level of cyclicality in the two main businesses of the company
column1174: should Goldman Sachs make a major acquisition either an asset management company
column1176: which we give the company a recurring stream of revenue to eliminate some of the [indiscernible] volatility and its revenues and earnings. I don\u2019t know is it the same question basically which is what should the structure
column1177:
Goldman Sachs be over the next 4 to 5 years?

"
column1180: so it\u2019s a good question and obviously there has been a lot of focus on there. So
column1182: we first have to say -- so
column1183: if anything what\u2019s changed today because I think prior to the crisis there was a belief that obviously it benefits to scale and you can get scale and you can have synergies. I think the change that people are focused on now is obviously there is a cost
column1184: a capital cost that the regulators are putting on side and so its very natural that the question that you're asking. Now
column1186: I would highlight a couple of things. First of all
column1187: we\u2019re just significantly smaller than many of the other firms and our balance sheet at $850 plus billion. Many of our competitors are more than twice our size and we\u2019ve 34
column1188: 000 employees and they may have hundreds of thousands of employees
column1189: and so we are smaller and we are less complex. And as a result
column1190: we're somewhat simpler. So what I would say is when we look at the collection of businesses that we have
column1191: the way we answer the synergy question is first and foremost through the eyes of the clients. Do we think we provide more value to our clients by having a collection of businesses together or not? It doesn't matter to us when in any given quarter the stock markets may be not valuing one of our businesses as perfectly as we would like it to be. It's really a question of over the long run can we drive shareholder value by having that benefit to our clients. So let's take fixed income and equity as one example. In an environment where its technology driven and the clients increasingly get larger
column1192: you need to scale across those businesses. We started running those businesses as a collective shortly after 2000 I think. And so the ability to deliver one technology platform across those businesses have one risk management system
column1193: all those things provide us with scale and we think we\u2019re able to execute better. It then feeds into our ability to adapt and develop technology tools around capital
column1194: and hopefully we are able to perform well in terms of deploying the firms\u2019 capital. When you think about investment banking
column1195: you bundle in. Think about the merger business today. And what we\u2019re able to do for our clients by having the ability to commit the capital and actually deliver to the capital markets and connect investors with issuers. Well
column1196: all of these things are very synergistic. Our private wealth business
column1199: these are all things that we think we have synergies in. Now
column1200: in terms of smaller or bigger
column1201: I think it's going to be environment driven for us. You saw us
column1202: you have seen us shrink the balance sheet pretty dramatically thinking you have known us for long time
column1204: 1.2 trillion. We\u2019ve been around 900 and now well below that for quite a while and so you\u2019re going to see us be dynamic about this. If we thought
column1205: we could drive more value for our clients and get more scale then we would consider things. I will say now it\u2019s harder obviously because there is the explicit pricing end
column1206: if you want to call it tax of incremental capital. You have to be very confident that you can get those synergies in that scale. That answer okay
column1207:
given the breadth of your question.

"
column1210: I think it makes a great deal of sense. What about the other foot side of the question
column1211:
which is where can you come up with a recurring revenue stream that would lower the volatility in your current business mix.

"
column1213:
"

It\u2019s funny. I can\u2019t help myself big. I know you say there a lot of volatility in our current revenue mix
column1214: but we have actually produced $34 billion in revenues for three years running. And we\u2019ve grown the ROE and we shrunk the balance sheet and we\u2019ve increased the pre-tax and we replaced $2.5 billion of revenues that didn\u2019t disappear because of volatility
column1215: it disappeared because we sold them. So I\u2019m not telling you its going to always be this stable
column1216:
but touch wood it feels pretty stable last couple of years.

"
column1218:
"

Okay. Thank you very much.

"
column1222:
"

Your next question is from the line of Andrew Limb with Societe Generale. Please go ahead.

"
column1229:
"

I\u2019ve just got a -- good morning. I\u2019ve got a question on the trading book review that mostly the Basel committee is undertaking and whether you could give anymore color on what kind of impacts it might have on the industry on an absolute basis
column1230:
and also how you stack up relative to your peers?

"
column1232:
"

So on the trading book review we think it\u2019s very important obviously and we\u2019re in active dialogue. There\u2019s been the QIS and -- so again its very early on that. So I don\u2019t have any specific comments on the trading book review. I think what I would say is that
column1233: and again I think you have to give credit and kudos to the regulators. They have been incredibly productive over the last several years. If we paused a list out for all the regulatory changes
column1234: its incredible in terms of the impact on capital
column1238: one of the things I think we all need to consider is market participants
column1239: and when I say that I mean clients
column1240: folks like ourselves and regulators is we need to maybe at least think about pausing a bit and digesting the impact of these rules. There\u2019s no doubt that these rules make the system stronger and safer as I said before. I do think there\u2019s a benefit to absorbing how they interact over the long periods of time
column1241:
because you can't get all those benefits without some cost. We can't necessarily always identify those costs immediately. And so that would be my very high level comment on that. But I don\u2019t have any specific comments on any proposed revisions for the rules.

"
column1243:
"

And is it something that you\u2019re running internally just to see what the impact is at the moment or is that too early to do that?

"
column1246: we\u2019re very consistent on our philosophy and yes in terms of proposed rules. It follows a very normal course protocol for us. We work as constructively as we can with the regulators in terms of trying to provide them with data and dialogue on the impact of overrule. So we\u2019re always active participants and we dedicate a lot of time and people and system and math to the QIS as they come out whether with any rule and we always try and be an active participant in terms of giving good balanced feedback to the regulators in terms of the benefits and cause of any proposed rule
column1247:
which is very early in this potential rewrite. It\u2019s just too early to comment on it.

"
column1249:
"

Okay. And then just carrying on to another regulation the NSFR. I know you said that was early as well
column1250:
but any thoughts about how that might impinge on your prime brokerage business and in terms of like incumberment to your balance sheet assets?

"
column1252:
"

Now again too early to tell. We\u2019ll see how it ultimately evolves when we get a local regulation. As I said
column1253: a big part of the discussion will be around the treatment of deposits. But look
column1254: I think what you\u2019re going to see the world do as they adjust is all firms
column1255: not just Goldman Sachs. All firms will look for what we\u2019ll call net stable funding ratio funding
column1256: whatever that ends up being defined as. And so
column1257: we\u2019ll see how the rule evolves. But look
column1258: we\u2019ll adapt. You\u2019ve seen us do it whether it\u2019s the Basel III ratio
column1260:
all these things. We\u2019ll just -- we still need to see a rule.

"
column1262:
"

Okay. And then just one final question. Is that target SLR that you\u2019re aiming for heading into the CCAR at all?

"
column1264:
"

No. At this stage not. As you saw into the SLR right at this stage
column1265: as you saw we\u2019re at 5%. That\u2019s up about 80 basis points in the course of the year
column1266: so now we\u2019re complying with 2018. One of the things is we\u2019ll continue to review this. There are whole lots of factors that could improve that ratio from here
column1267: but again we\u2019ll be assessing all of our buffers as we get the final capital rules. Again we all interact
column1269:
you really want to get to a point of stability of rule making and then you can really set the parameters and dial them in more tightly.

"
column1273:
"

Thank you. I appreciate you dialing in.

"
column1275:
"

At this time there are no further questions. Please continue with any closing remarks.

"
column1278: hey everyone. Since there are no more questions
column1279: I just want to take a moment to thank all you for joining the call. Hopefully myself and other members of senior management will see many of you in the coming months. If there is any additional questions arise
column1280: please don\u2019t hesitate to give Dane a call
column1281:
otherwise enjoy the rest of your day and a long weekend and look forward to speaking with you our first quarter earnings call coming up in April. Take care everyone. Thank you.

"

column28:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis and I'll be your conference facilitator today. I'd like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded today
column34:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column35: Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call. Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the Firm's belief regarding future events that
column36: by their nature
column37: are uncertain and outside of the Firm's control. The Firm's actual results and financial condition may differ

column39:
from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements.

"
column40:

For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the Firm's future results
column41: please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 2014. I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column42: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column45: Global Core Liquid Assets
column46: and supplementary leverage ratio
column47: and you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that's posted on the Investor Relations portion of our web site at www.gs.com. This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column48: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column49:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column50:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column51: Harvey Schwartz
column52:
will now review the Firm's results. Harvey?

"
column53:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column54:
"

Thanks Dane and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I will walk you through the first quarter results
column55:
and I am happy to answer any questions.

"
column56:
"

Net revenues were $10.6 billion; net earnings $2.8 billion; earnings per diluted share
column57: were $5.94
column58: and our annualized return on common equity was 14.7%. The first quarter was dominated by one primary theme
column59: central bank policies. In the United States
column60: the market heavily debated whether 2015 would be the year that the Federal Reserve raises rates. On the other hand
column61:
the European Central Bank announced the creation of a \u20ac1.1 trillion quantitative easing program that kicked off in March.

"
column62:
"

The prospect of two of the world's largest economies
column63: implementing divergent monetary policies had a significant impact. Market participants reassess the implications for both global economic growth
column64: and as a consequence
column65:
the performance of various financial assets.

"
column66:
"

Regarding the economic outlook
column67: on one hand
column68: low rates are viewed as providing an important economic stimulus to the United States. On the other hand
column69:
a return to normalized rates would be consistent with a strong underlying economy.

"
column70:
"

Looking at the bigger picture
column71: the degree of conviction around a slow but stable U.S. recovery continued to gain support for most of the quarter. The weaker recent jobs report in the U.S. has sparked some debate around the timing and magnitude of potential rate hikes. However
column72: the long term expectation of slow
column73: but steady growth and higher rates
column74:
remains intact.

"
column75:
"

Across the Atlantic
column76:
the announcement of quantitative easing in Europe provided some stability and the basis for greater economic growth in the region. The launch of a \u20ac60 billion per month purchasing program provided greater confidence to market participants on the Eurozone outlook. The impact was immediately felt across European financial markets.

"
column77:
"

If you take the European government bond market for example
column78: more than a quarter of the bonds are trading with negative yields today. The equity markets in Europe rallied
column79: as demonstrated by the 18% increase in the Euro Stoxx 50 Index during the quarter
column80: and the Euro reached its lowest level versus the dollar in 12 years. As a result
column81:
there was greater activity as clients responded to heightened market volatility.

"
column82:
"

Given the scope
column83: complexity and significance of these two different monetary policies
column84: it isn't surprising
column85:
that there continues to be a robust discussion around the potential impacts.

"
column86:
"

For our firm
column87: the focus continues to be our clients and serving their needs. Our clients are placing a greater premium on both intellectual and financial capital
column88: given market dynamics and an evolving competitive landscape. We are committed to providing our clients with superior advice
column89: investment performance
column90: content
column91: market liquidity
column92: and certainty of execution. We believe that our extensive capabilities favorably position us to meet a variety of client needs
column93:
in what is certainly a dynamic market environment.

"
column94:
"

Now I will discuss each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced first quarter revenues of $1.9 billion
column95: up 32% from the fourth quarter. Our Investment Banking backlog decreased since the end of the year
column96: but its still up significantly
column97:
relative to a year ago.

"
column98:
"

Breaking down the components of Investment Banking in the first quarter
column99: advisory revenues were $961 million
column100: the highest since 2007. This 39% increase relative to the fourth quarter reflects both the increase in completed M&A
column101: and the strength of our leading global franchise. In the quarter
column102: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the first quarter
column103: including Allergan's $71 billion sale to Activis; RWE's \u20ac5.1 billion sale of RWE-DEA
column104: [indiscernible] Group
column105:
and Dai-ichi Life Insurance Company's $5.7 billion acquisition of Protective Life Corporation.

"
column106:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the first quarter; these include
column107: MeadWestvaco's merger with Rock-Tenn for a combined enterprise value of $20 billion; Charter Communications' $10.4 billion acquisition of Bright House Networks; and Dow Chemicals' $5 billion separation of its chlor-alkali and downstream businesses
column108:
to Olin Corporation.

"
column109:
"

Moving to Underwriting
column110: revenues were $944 million in the first quarter
column111: up 26% sequentially as equity issuance improved. During the quarter
column112: we ranked first in Global Equity and Equity Related and Common Stock offerings. Equity Underwriting revenues of $533 million rose 56% compared to the fourth quarter
column113:
largely due to an increase in secondary offerings. Debt underwriting revenues were essentially unchanged at $411 million.

"
column114:
"

During the first quarter
column115: we actively supported our client's financing needs
column116:
leading Santander's \u20ac7.5 billion follow-on equity offering; Chevron's AUD4.7 billion sale of its stake in Caltex Australia; and Berkshire Hathaway's \u20ac3 billion investment grade issuance.

"
column117:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column118: which comprises both our FICC and Equities businesses
column119: net revenues were $5.5 billion in the first quarter
column120: up significantly compared to the fourth quarter. FICC client execution net revenues were $3.1 billion in the first quarter
column121: and included $32 million of DVA losses. Net revenues were up more than 2.5 times sequentially
column122: as client activity increased in a number of our businesses
column123: in response to higher volatility and improved market conditions. Interest rates and currencies were both significantly higher sequentially
column124:
as client activity improved amid diverging central bank policies.

"
column125:
"

Credit increased significantly from a more challenging fourth quarter
column126: as credit spreads generally tighten during the first quarter. Mortgages also rose versus the fourth quarter
column127: although volatility and client activity remained generally low. Given continued trends in the energy markets
column128: commodities improved sequentially
column129:
with higher levels of client activity.

"
column130:
"

In Equities
column131: which includes equities client execution
column132: commissions and fees and security services
column133: net revenues for the first quarter were $2.3 billion
column134: up 20% sequentially and include $12 million in DVA losses. Equities client execution net revenues increased 50% sequentially to $1.1 billion due to a favorable market-making backdrop with higher levels of client activity
column135: particularly in derivatives. Commissions and fees were $808 million
column136: down 3% relative to the fourth quarter. Security services generated net revenues of $393 million
column137: up 12% sequentially
column138:
reflecting higher customer balances.

"
column139:
"

Turning to Risk; average daily VaR in the first quarter was $81 million
column140:
up from $63 million in the fourth quarter. The move up was primarily due to increased market volatility across all categories.

"
column141:
"

Moving on to our investing and lending activates; collectively
column142: these businesses produced net revenues of $1.7 billion in the first quarter. Following a sale of our investment in Metro International in the fourth quarter
column143: we made a decision that the remaining revenue related to consolidated investments within the other line
column144: was not significant in the context of the I&L segment. As a result
column145:
we are now reporting the other I&L revenues within the equity and debt lines.

"
column146:
"

Equity Securities generated net revenues of $1.2 billion
column147: primarily reflecting strong corporate performance and company-specific events in private equity
column148: as well as net gains in public equities. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $509 million
column149:
with roughly $200 million in net interest income and the balance coming from net gains.

"
column150:
"

In Investment Management
column151: we reported first quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion
column152: essentially unchanged versus the fourth quarter. Management and other fees were down 3% sequentially to $1.2 billion. Assets under supervision remain flat at $1.18 trillion. $7 billion of long term net inflows
column153: driven by fixed income and equity products
column154:
and net market appreciation of $6 billion were offset by net outflows of $14 billion in liquidity products.

"
column155:
"

Moving to performance; across the global platform
column156: 82% of our client mutual fund assets were in funds ranked in the top two quartiles on a three year basis
column157:
and 73% in funds ranked in the top two quartiles on a five year basis.

"
column158:
"

Now let me turn to expenses; compensation and benefits expense
column159: which include salaries
column160: bonuses
column161: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column162: was accrued at a compensation to net revenues ratio of 42%. This is the lowest first quarter accrual in our public history
column163:
and 100 basis points lower than the accrual in the first quarter of 2014. Our lower accrual rate reflects our strong 14% year-over-year net revenue growth and the positive operating leverage embedded in our firm.

"
column164:
"

First quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.2 billion
column165: 12% lower than the fourth quarter
column166:
and slightly lower than the first quarter of 2014. The fourth quarter included higher charitable contributions and higher impairment charges on consolidated investment entities.

"
column167:
"

Now I'd like to take you through a few key statistics for the first quarter; total staff was approximately 34
column169: up 1% from year end 2014. Our effective tax rate for the first quarter was 27.7%
column170: that is down from a 2014 rate
column171: primarily due to changes in geographic earnings mix. Our global core liquid assets ended $175 billion. Our common equity tier-1 ratio was 11.4% using the standardized approach
column172: it was 12.6% under the advanced approach. Starting this quarter
column173:
the lower of these two ratios is our binding regulatory constraints.

"
column174:
"

Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 5.3%
column175: 30 basis points above the minimum requirement that begins in 2018. And finally
column176:
we repurchased 6.8 million shares of common stock for $1.25 billion in the first quarter. These repurchases reflected the completion of our 2014 capital plan.

"
column177:
"

As previously announced
column178: the Federal Reserve Board did not object to our revised 2015 capital plan
column179: which includes share repurchases
column180: dividends and other capital actions. In terms of this year's CCAR test
column181: we announced an increase in our quarterly dividend to $0.65 per share beginning in the second quarter. As it relates to our share repurchase capacity
column182: one point I want to highlight
column183: is that any potential share repurchases over the next five quarters
column184: will be heavily back-end weighted. As you all know
column185: we do not publicly disclose the approved size of our repurchase capacity. Again
column186: we take this approach for a very specific and practical reason. We don't want our shareholders to view the approved buyback amount as a commitment to return that capital. For us
column187: capital allocation is a dynamic process. If we see opportunities to deploy the capital attractively to support client activity
column188: we want the flexibility to do it
column189: and conversely
column190: if our clients are less active
column191: we will certainly look to return it. our track record on this one
column192:
is well established.

"
column193:
"

Now
column194: before I take your questions
column195: let me offer some closing thoughts. The first quarter has served as a strong start to 2015. The year-over-year increase in net revenues reflects
column196: not only the strength of our franchise
column197: but also our ability to provide high quality advice and certainty of execution for our clients. Our performance this quarter
column198: well just a quarter
column199: reflects numerous efforts over the last several years to adjust our business. We sold several businesses due to regulatory capital implications. We transformed our financial profile
column200: significantly improving our risk based capital. We revamped our capital allocation processes
column201: improving our decision-making and efficiency. We took a hard look at our operating cost
column202: fundamentally changing our expense structure by eliminating costs
column203: reallocating resources
column204: and leveraging technology. We made all these changes
column205: while at the same time
column206:
continuing to invest in our global client franchise.

"
column207:
"

We know that our success in many ways begins and ends with our clients. It\u2019s the trust they place in us and our ability to execute on their behalf that drives our franchise
column208: and we believe that our steady commitment
column209: particularly through these more difficult years
column210: has been critical to creating stronger client relationships. And there is one important thing that we didn't change
column211: our focus on creating shareholder value
column212: our efforts are ultimately a reflection of our commitment to you
column213: our owners. We understand that to create shareholder value
column214: we need to have strong financial footings
column215: be an efficient allocator of capital
column216: and have a world class client franchise. Ultimately
column217: our efforts over the past several years have meant that a 14% increase in year-over-year revenues can contribute to a 40% increase in net earnings
column218: a 48% increase in earnings per share
column219: a 380 basis point improvement in ROE
column220:
and finally 9% growth in book value per share over the past year.

"
column221:
"

Thank you again for dialing in
column222:
and I am happy to answer your questions.

Harvey M. Schwartz - Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President

"
column55: Dane
column56:
and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through the second quarter and year-to-date results then I'm happy to answer any questions.

"
column57:
"

Net revenues were $9.1 billion
column58: net earnings $1 billion
column59: earnings per diluted share $1.98
column60: and our annualized return on common equity was 4.8%. For the year-to-date
column61: net revenues were $19.7 billion
column62: net earnings $3.9 billion
column63: earnings per diluted share $7.93
column64:
and our annualized return on common equity was 9.7%.

"
column65:
"

In the second quarter
column66: we recorded net provisions for mortgage related litigation and regulatory matters of $1.45 billion. Despite these charges
column67: book value per common share was up 4% relative to year-end 2014. Excluding these litigation charges
column68: net earnings were $2.3 billion
column69: earnings per diluted share were $4.75
column70:
and our annualized return on common equity was 11.5%.

"
column71:
"

The second quarter of 2015 was another example of the benefits that come with having a diversified global client franchise. Certain businesses showed year-over-year strengths while others faced headwinds.

"
column72:
"

Investment Banking and Investment Management net revenues increased year-over-year by 13% and 14% respectively. The increase in net revenues within these primarily fee-based business s largely offset net revenue declines and are more capital-intensive businesses with a 6% year-over-year decline in Institutional Client Services and a 13% year-over-year decline in Investing and Lending.

"
column73:
"

The benefits of diversity were even demonstrated at a business level. For example
column74: strength in advisory and equity underwriting more than offset the year-over-year decline in debt underwriting
column75: which was lower versus a record last year. And for Institutional Client Services
column76: revenue strength within equities helped offset a difficult operating environment for FICC. Ultimately
column77:
we continue to benefit from our diverse set of market leading businesses.

"
column78:
"

If you look at our first half results
column79: excluding the $1.45 billion litigation charge in the second quarter of 2015
column80: you can see the embedded operating leverage
column81:
with expenses flat relative to revenues that are up 7% compared to last year. You can also see the improvement in several underlying performance metrics.

"
column82:
"

These include a 440 basis point improvement in pre-tax margin
column83: a 27% increase in net earnings
column84: a 31% increase to diluted earnings per share
column85: and finally
column86: a 220 basis point improvement in ROE
column88:
"

Now I will discuss each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced second quarter revenues of $2 billion
column89: 6% higher than a strong first quarter. We continue to see the benefit of our leading global franchise
column90:
with second quarter revenues at the highest level since 2007.

"
column91:
"

Our Investment Banking backlog was down slightly compared to the first quarter and remained higher year-over-year. Breaking down the components of Investment Banking in the second quarter
column92:
advisory revenues were $821 million. The 15% decrease relative to the first quarter reflects a decrease in completed M&A.

"
column93:
"

Year-to-date
column94: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the second quarter
column95:
including BHP Billiton's $12.7 billion demerger of South32; Synageva Biopharma's $8.4 billion sale to Alexion Pharmaceuticals; and Imperial Tobacco Group's $7.1 billion acquisition of certain cigarette brands and other assets of Reynolds American and Lorillard.

"
column96:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the second quarter. These include BG Group's \u00a347 billion acquisition by Royal Dutch Shell; Altera Corporation's $16.7 billion sale to Intel Corporation; and Pall Corporation's $13.8 billion sale to Danaher Corporation.

"
column97:
"

Moving to underwriting
column98: revenues were $1.2 billion in the second quarter
column99: up 27% sequentially
column100: primarily due to debt issuance. This was our second highest quarterly performance in underwriting. Year-to-date
column101:
we ranked first in global equity and equity-related and common stock offerings.

"
column102:
"

Equity underwriting revenues of $595 million rose 12% compared to the first quarter
column103: due to an increase in IPOs. Debt underwriting revenues of $603 million improved 47% quarter-over-quarter
column104:
largely driven by an increase in leverage finance activity.

"
column105:
"

During the second quarter
column106: we actively supported our client's financing needs. Leading Qualcomm's $10 billion debt IPO
column107: Daiichi Sankyo's $3.2 billion sale of its stake in Sun Pharmaceutical
column108:
and AIG's $3.5 billion sale of its stake in AerCap.

"
column109:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column110: which comprises both our FICC and Equity businesses
column111: net revenues were $3.6 billion in the second quarter
column112: down 34% compared to the seasonally-stronger first quarter. FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.6 billion in the second quarter
column113:
and include $153 million of DBA gains.

"
column114:
"

Net revenues were down substantially from the first quarter
column115: as client activity declined across our businesses and market-making conditions were more difficult. Within interest rates and currencies
column116: a shifting macro backdrop negatively impacted client activity and results. While currency has experienced a significant decline
column117: client activity and interest rates
column118: though sequentially lower
column119:
remain solid.

"
column120:
"

Credit was significantly lower
column121: as credit spreads generally widened during the second quarter and activity levels declined. Mortgages also declined versus the first quarter
column122: as volatility and client activity remained generally low. Commodities decreased significantly
column123:
with reduced levels of volatility and client activity.

"
column124:
"

In Equities
column125: which includes Equities Client Execution
column126: commissions and fees
column127: and security services
column128: net revenues for the second quarter were $2 billion
column129:
down 14% quarter-over-quarter and included $32 million in DBA gains.

"
column130:
"

Equities Client Execution net revenues decreased 30% sequentially
column131: to $787 million. Client activity levels remained high this quarter
column132: though not as high as the first quarter. Commissions and fees were $767 million
column133: down 5% relative to the first quarter. Security services generated net revenues of $443 million
column134: up 13% sequentially
column135:
reflecting seasonally-stronger client activity and higher customer balances.

"
column136:
"

Turning to risk
column137: average daily VaR in the second quarter was $77 million
column138: down from $81 million in the first quarter
column139:
reflecting a decrease in commodities and interest rates.

"
column140:
"

Moving on to our Investing and Lending activities
column141: collectively
column142: these businesses produced net revenues of $1.8 billion in the second quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $1.3 billion
column143: primarily reflecting strong corporate performance and company-specific events in private equity
column144: as well as net gains in public equities. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $547 million
column145: with roughly $225 million in net interest income
column146:
and the balance coming from net gains.

"
column147:
"

In Investment Management
column148: we reported second quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion
column149: up 4% from the first quarter. This represented the second highest quarterly performance for Investment Management. Management and other fees were up 4% sequentially
column150:
to a record $1.25 billion.

"
column151:
"

Revenues benefited from a higher average mix of long-term fee-based products relative to liquidity products. Assets under supervision increased $5 billion
column152: to a record $1.182 trillion. Long-term net inflows of $14 billion
column153: largely driven by fixed income products
column154:
were somewhat offset by net market depreciation of $3 billion and net outflows of $6 billion in liquidity products.

"
column155:
"

Moving to performance
column156: across the global platform
column157:
76% of our client mutual fund assets were in funds ranked in the top two quartiles on a three-year and a five-year basis.

"
column158:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column159: which includes salaries
column160: bonuses
column161:
amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as benefits was again accrued at a compensation to net revenues ratio of 42%. Second quarter non-compensation expenses were 59% higher than the first quarter. Substantially all of the increase was related to litigation charges.

"
column162:
"

Now
column163: I'd like to take you through a few key statistics for the second quarter. Total staff was approximately 34
column164:
900 up 1% from the first quarter. Our effective tax rate for the year-to-date was 31.2%. Our global core of liquid assets averaged $181 billion. Our common equity tier 1 ratio was 11.8% using standardized approach. It was 12.5% under the Basel III Advanced approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 5.7%.

"
column165:
"

And finally
column166: we repurchased 1.2 million shares of common stock for $245 million in the second quarter. As discussed last quarter
column167: related to our share repurchase capacity
column168:
any potential share repurchases over the next four quarters will be back-end weighted.

"
column169:
"

In closing
column170: a few comments. The second quarter of 2015 provided its share of opportunities and challenges. On one hand
column171: our results reflect a continuation of some positive macro trends. Our Investment Banking clients remain focused on their strategic alternatives. There is also a strong demand for financing solutions. We see solid client activity in equity products
column172: particularly outside of the United States
column173:
and there was a growing need for active investment management options.

"
column174:
"

On the other hand
column175: the operating environment for our FICC clients was more challenged in the second quarter. The combination of current concern surrounding Greece's widening credit spreads and the reversal of certain macro trends led to lower client activity and a more difficult operating environment. More recently
column176:
market participants have been focused on the Chinese economy. This follows the more than 30% decline in the Shanghai Index during the early part of July from peak levels in June.

"
column177:
"

Against this mixed backdrop
column178: we remain focused on driving value for our shareholders. Year-to-date
column179: excluding litigation charges
column180: we have posted strong results in many of our key investor metrics
column181: including earnings per share
column182: ROE
column183:
and book value per share.

"
column184:
"

As we have mentioned many times before
column185: our management team isn't overly focused on any one quarter or
column186: for that matter
column187: any six month period. Our focus is on the strength of our global client franchise
column188: the quality of our people
column189:
and the long term trends driving our businesses.

"
column190:
"

Regarding trends
column191: we see many opportunities ahead. For example
column192: the competitive landscape is in significant flux. In addition to strengthening the banking system
column193:
one of the positive things the regulation has achieved is leveling the competitive playing field.

"
column194:
"

The world changed after 2008. We began to adapt to this new world immediately
column195:
and particularly to comply with new regulations. As part of this process we also scrutinized each of our businesses with the goal of both improving the client experience and our ability to generate appropriate shareholder returns.

"
column196:
"

We started early
column197: we cut costs
column198: we on-boarded new regulations
column199: we sold businesses
column200: and we developed a new capital framework. At the same time
column201:
we have been able to both expand and deepen our global client franchise.

"
column202:
"

As much as we are focused on the present
column203: we are also focused on the future
column204: and we enter it knowing we have a great set of businesses
column205: we have tremendous client relationships
column206: we have world-class people and execution capabilities
column207: and last but not least
column208:
we have an improving competitive and operating landscape.

"
column209:
"

Thank you again for dialing in
column210:
and I'm happy to answer your questions.

Harvey M. Schwartz - Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President

column870: there has been a whole host of discussion around liquidity in the markets. And I think in the end

I think it leaves us quite frankly all with more questions more than answers. I think you can point to some very specific parts of the market where you can say regulation has impacted liquidity.

"
column873: the best example of that is the government bond repo market. I think it's hard after that to point to a specific regulation and say
column875: this regulation has impacted liquidity in this market. That doesn't mean it's not happening. I think it's just hard to quantify. I think the repo market you can easily quantify it. You can see the reduction in repo commitment from various banks
column877:
and you can see over quarter-end how repo spreads react.

column879:
to me that looks like that's an intended desire by the regulators. They wanted people to either reprice or shrink that business. And so I think away from that the reason why this is difficult is because it's a question of really what is the multi-year accumulation of regulation?

column880:

column881: inability to hold as much balance sheet
column883: all these things so vocal. But I think these things reveal themselves over many years. But obviously

column920: feels like volatility is picking up in a healthy way
column921:
but that doesn't mean from time to time we're not going to hit these kind of pockets.

column922:

Devin P. Ryan - JMP Securities LLC
