Thanks
column53: Dane
column54: and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I\u2019ll walk you through the third quarter and year-to-date results
column55: and I\u2019m happy to answer any questions. Net revenues were $6.9 billion. Net earnings $1.4 billion. Earnings per diluted share $2.90
column56:
and our annualized return on common equity was 7%.

"
column57:
"

For the year-to-date
column58: net revenues were $26.5 billion. Net earnings $5.3 billion. Earnings per diluted share $10.84
column59: and our return \u2013 our annualized return on common equity was 8.8%. Book value per share is up 5% relative to year-end 2014
column60: despite recording net provisions for litigation and regulatory matters
column61:
up $2.1 billion for the year-to-date. These provisions largely from legacy issues reduced our annualized return on common equity for the first nine months of the year by approximately 3 percentage points.

"
column62:
"

Moving to the third quarter
column63: parts of our franchise performed quite well
column64: while others operated against a more challenging backdrop. Our M&A franchise continued to deliver robust results and our outlook remains positive. We continue to see net inflows in our investment management business. Of course
column65: they\u2019re the usual seasonal drivers due to the summer slowdown
column66:
but in addition the third quarter also had more than its fair share of significant macroeconomic developments.

"
column67:
"

Both the Chinese economy and the country\u2019s monetary policy came into focus. Our clients evaluated the potential implications of a slowing Chinese economy
column68: the decision by the People\u2019s Bank of China to devalue its currency
column69: and the resulting volatility in global markets. As it relates to the U.S. economy
column70: our clients remain focused on the Federal Reserve\u2019s interest rate policy. Over the course of the third quarter
column71: client\u2019s expectations for an interest rate hike began to shift. Mixed economic indicators drove uncertainty about the pace of U.S. economic growth. Ultimately
column72:
there was doubt about the timing and magnitude of the future rate increase.

"
column73:
"

Another significant macroeconomic theme in the third quarter
column74: commodities. Prices fell across a number of different products. WTI was down 24%. Copper and natural gas were both down approximately 10%. The price slump let the market to focus on the credit risk of commodity producers
column75: trading houses
column76: and those economies with significant commodity exports. These concerns drove an increase in credit spreads
column77:
particularly across the energy sector. The sum impact of these various events led to lower levels of client activity and a significant repricing of the equity and credit markets.

"
column78:
"

The S&P was down nearly 7%
column79: the MSCI world was down almost 10%
column80: and the Shanghai Composite was down close to 30%. In the credit markets
column81: European high yield spreads were 107 basis points wider and U.S. high yield spreads were 153 basis points wider. Not surprisingly
column82: we produced lower quarterly revenues across many of our businesses
column83:
given both declining asset prices and reduced level of client activity.

"
column84:
"

Now
column85: I will discuss each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced third quarter revenues of $1.6 billion
column86: 23% lower than a strong second quarter as underwriting slowed. Although issuance declined during the quarter
column87:
our Investment Banking backlog remains strong and was up compared to both the second quarter and the end of 2014.

"
column88:
"

Breaking down the components of Investment Banking in the quarter
column89: advisory revenues were $809 million
column90: roughly consistent with the second quarter. Year-to-date
column91: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. During this period
column92: we served as an advisor on nearly $900 billion of completed transactions. This is roughly $350 billion more than our next closest competitor. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the third quarter
column93: including DirecTV\u2019s $67.1 billion sale to AT&T
column94: eBay\u2019s $46.8 billion spin-off of PayPal
column95:
and Baxter\u2019s $20.3 billion spin-off of Baxalta.

"
column96:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the third quarter. These include Energy Transfer Equity\u2019s $37.7 billion acquisition of the Williams Companies
column97: Humana\u2019s $37 billion sale to Aetna
column98:
and Procter & Gamble\u2019s $12.5 billion merger of its beauty business into Coty.

"
column99:
"

Moving to underwriting
column100: revenues were $747 million in the third quarter
column101: down 38% sequentially
column102: primarily due to a significant decline in equity issuance. Although global activity was weaker
column103:
our franchise remains strong with a number one ranking in global equity and equity related and common stock offerings for the year-to-date.

"
column104:
"

Equity underwriting revenues were $190 million. This was down substantially compared to the second quarter
column105: due to a decrease of industry wide IPOs and secondary offerings
column106: as higher volatility and a decline in prices reduced activity. Debt underwriting revenues of $557 million were down 8% quarter-over-quarter
column107:
a decrease of industry wide issuance volumes was partially offset by acquisition related financing.

"
column108:
"

During the third quarter
column109: we actively supported our client\u2019s financing needs leading HP Enterprises $14.6 billion debt offering related to a spin-off from HP
column110: Biogen\u2019s $6 billion debt offering
column111:
and Simporno\u2019s [ph] $1.4 billion rights offering.

"
column112:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column113: which comprises both our fixed and equities businesses. Net revenues were $3.2 billion in the third quarter
column114: down a 11% compared to the second quarter. Within the number of our businesses
column115:
the macro concerns I have already talked about impacted both client conviction and activity.

"
column116:
"

FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.5 billion in the third quarter and included a $147 million of DVA gains. Net revenues were down 9% from the second quarter and market-making conditions continue to be challenging.

"
column117:
"

Currencies improved sequentially
column118: as the devaluation in the Chinese yuan sparked significant client activity within our emerging market franchise. Commodities increased relative to a more challenging second quarter
column119:
as declining commodity prices and higher volatility benefited results.

"
column120:
"

Interest rates was significantly lower
column121: as uncertainty related to the direction of U.S. interest rates impacted activity. Credit decreased
column122: as client activity remains generally low amid continued spread widening. Mortgages was significantly lower as conditions remained challenged with limited client activity. In equities
column123: which includes equities client execution
column124: commissions and fees and security services
column125: net revenues for the third quarter were $1.8 billion
column126:
down 12% quarter-over-quarter and included $35 million in DVA gains. Equities\u2019 client execution net revenues decreased 29% sequentially to $555 million.

"
column127:
"

Broadly speaking
column128: client activity declined versus the second quarter
column129: as higher volatility and global equity market weakness impacted investor conviction and risk appetite. However
column130: as is often the case in more volatile markets
column131: we did see activity pickup in our lower touch electronic channels
column132: as a result commissions and fees were up 7% quarter-over-quarter to $818 million. Security services generated net revenues of $379 million
column133: down 14%
column134:
compared to the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column135:
"

Turning to risk
column136: despite an increase in volatility
column137:
average daily bar in the third quarter was down $3 million sequentially to $74 million.

"
column138:
"

Moving onto our investing and lending activities
column139:
collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $670 million in the third quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $370 million. The declining global equity markets negatively impacted net revenues and public equities during the quarter. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $300 million with the majority coming from net interest income.

"
column140:
"

The Investment Management reported third quarter net revenues of $1.4 billion
column141: down 14%
column142: excuse me
column143: 14% from the second quarter
column144: as incentive fees declined. Management and other fees were down 3% sequentially to $1.2 billion. Assets under supervision reached a record $1.19 trillion
column145:
as long-term net inflows more than offset market depreciation.

column146:

column148: which added $18 billion of assets. This represents our 7th acquisition since the beginning of 2012. Over that timeframe
column149:
total long-term net inflows were $195 billion. $71 billion of these net flows came from acquisitions.

column150:
"

column151: 72% of our client mutual fund assets were in funds ranked in the top two quartiles on a three-year basis
column152:
and 70% in funds ranked in the top two quartiles on a five-year basis.

"
column153:
"

Now
column154: let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column155: which includes salaries
column156: bonuses
column157:
amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as benefits was accrued at a compensation to net revenues ratio of 40% for the year-to-date. This is 200 basis points lower than the firm\u2019s accrual in the first-half of this year and consistent with the year-to-date compensation ratio at the end of the third quarter of 2014.

"
column158:
"

Third quarter non-compensation expenses were 30% lower than the second quarter. Substantially all the decrease was driven by a larger litigation charge taken in the second quarter. In the third quarter
column159:
net provisions for litigation and regulatory expenses were $416 million.

"
column160:
"

Now
column161: I\u2019d like to take you through a few key statistics for the third quarter. Total staff increased by 2
column162: 000 to approximately 36
column164: which was up 6% quarter-over-quarter. Roughly half of the new staff was from the federation
column165:
largely technology and operations. The other half was primarily spread across Investment Banking and Investment Management. The increase was dominated by campus hires and reflects both the activity levels in certain businesses and our continued investment in regulatory compliance.

"
column166:
"

Our effective tax rate for the year-to-date was 31%. Our global core liquid assets averaged $193 billion during the quarter. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 12.4% using the Standardized approach
column167: it was 12.7% under the Basel III Advanced approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 5.8%. And finally
column168: we repurchased 5.4 million shares of common stock for $1.1 billion in the third quarter. As we have discussed related to our share repurchase capacity
column169:
any potential share repurchases over the next three quarters will be more back-end weighted compared to the last two quarters.

"
column170:
"

Before we turn to Q&A
column171: I\u2019ll share some thoughts around the market and industry broadly. The third quarter served as a reminder of the fragility and sensitivity of markets
column172: investor sentiment
column173: and the path to strong global economic growth. As you know over the last several years
column174: the financial services industry has faced a series of headwinds. These pressures have forced many within the industry to rethink their footprint or their level of commitment to a variety of businesses
column175: particularly within the more capital intensive businesses of fixed income
column176: currencies
column177:
and commodities.

"
column178:
"

At Goldman Sachs
column179: our strategy remains intact to be the leading advisor
column180: underwriter
column181: liquidity provider
column182: financier
column183: and investment manager. To that end
column184: we are always looking for ways to deliver more differentiated value to our clients. We\u2019re also keenly aware of the challenges facing the industry. While some of our businesses are experiencing year-to-date growth
column185: for example
column186: Investment Banking and Investment Management
column187:
other parts of the business are in a more difficult part of the cycle.

"
column188:
"

However
column189: we\u2019re hardly complacence. For example
column190: within FICC
column191: we are proactively responded to industry wide challenges
column192: including asset sales
column193: expense initiatives
column194: and balance sheet reduction. The goal of these various efforts is to maintain margins
column195: improve returns
column196: prudently manage risk
column197: and protect the global client franchise. We will always look for additional opportunities to improve our FICC operations. However
column198:
we will also never lose sight of the tremendous value that we can bring to our FICC clients over the long term.

"
column199:
"

In closing
column200: we believe that our long-term prospects are quite favorable. Our global pipe franchise

column202: we have the people

column205: our shareholders

particularly as the environment improves.

column207:
"

Thank you

column209:
for dialing in. And I\u2019m happy to answer your questions.

column876: how are you? Just to follow up on the I&L discussion. Can you give us a sense of how we should think about sort of the quarter-to-quarter risk management practices within that unit

column882: one of the \u2013 I think one of the things to point out is

column884: it has changed pretty significantly. The composition today
column885: as I said earlier is really 75% debt. And roughly two-thirds of that is HFI accounting
column886: which is just good old-fashioned bank accounting. The balance is equities and if you compare that to
column890:
I think the whole portfolio was more than 50% equities. And so the composition of the portfolio has changed significantly.

column892: if you\u2019re going to have $4 billion public equity portfolio

column895: if the markets decline for extended periods of time or increase for extended periods
column896: obviously that drives value of underlying assets and it drives activity for all businesses in all industries. But the portfolio composition has changed pretty dramatically over the last several years. And when you talk about the volatility
column897: I can\u2019t help to remind you that over long periods of time

column904: my \u2013 I\u2019m trying to make sure I sort of fully understand

column912:
so look if we see a number of quarters of back to back declining in market that may be the right time to actually being to put capital to work which is why we run with excess capital and we run with excess liquidity because we want to be there for those opportunities and we want to be there for our client. So we size the risk of the investment at the point of making it. Once you have it you can certainly do things but prudent risk management really is the point of the initial decision.

because it is much about the asset footing as it\u2019s about liabilities.

column970: we just like that having a diversified geographic client base
column972: we just think that\u2019s prudent risk management. When you think about it
column973: it\u2019s all really about where various investors want to provide capital to the firm and so that\u2019s how we think about it. So we haven\u2019t set a target. The reason we don\u2019t set targets and things like that is we always are concerned about building up too much of a warehouse of liquidity
column974: we obviously hold a very significant liquidity cushion at $193 billion. Like you don\u2019t want to feel yourself getting pressed into deploying those liabilities
column975: you don\u2019t want the liabilities to drive your asset strategy
column976:
you want your liabilities to inform it and you want to have diversified safe funding.

column46: Dane
column47: and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through the fourth quarter and full year results and I'm happy to answer any questions. Before outlining our results
column48: I would like to discuss the previously announced settlement for legacy mortgage activities. As you know we took a total net provision for litigation and regulatory matters in the fourth quarter of $1.95 billion. The RMBS Working Group matter
column49: was the most significant outstanding piece of litigation facing the firm. As you would expect
column50: following a settlement
column51:
there has been a significant decline in our recently possible loss number. We are currently estimating a more than 60% decline compared to third quarter levels of $5.3 billion.

"
column52:
"

Now turning to the fourth quarter
column53: net revenues were $7.3 billion. Net earnings were $765 million and earnings per diluted share were $1.27. With respect to our annual results
column54: we had Firm wide net revenues of $33.8 billion
column55: net earnings of $6.1 billion
column56: earnings per diluted share of $12.14 and a return on common equity of 7.4%. Revenues were down slightly compared with last year and expenses were significantly higher due to approximately $4 billion of net provisions for litigation and regulatory matters. Despite these headwinds
column57:
we grew book value per share by 5%.

"
column58:
"

The growth combined with our risk reduction efforts
column59: strengthened all of our regulatory capital ratios. Excluding the litigation charges related to the RMBS Working Group
column60:
our 2015 return on common equity would've been 380 basis points higher.

"
column61:
"

2015 presented both challenges and opportunities. The challenges were more acutely felt in the back half of the year
column62: as concerns about global growth intensified
column63: which is reflected in public equity markets
column64: with the MSCI rolled down
column65: 5.7% over the last six months of the year. Credit markets also reflected these concerns
column66: particularly within the non-investment grade space and most acutely within the commodity sector. For example
column67: U.S. high yield spreads were 157 basis points wider in the second half of 2015. And at the end of 2015
column68:
the trailing 12 month default rate for U.S. non-investment grade bonds more than doubled year-over-year climbing to 4.3%.

"
column69:
"

These factors negatively impacted the broader opportunity set for our clients and as a consequence for the Firm. To varying degrees
column70: the firm faced headwinds within certain of our FICC businesses
column71: underwriting within investment banking and our investing and lending activities. However
column72: these significant headwinds were largely offset by client activity in other businesses. Many of our clients decided to pursue M&A as the best means for creating shareholder value. And now M&A volumes for the industry increased by 47% in 2015. The Firm's volumes increased by 81%
column73:
a significant expansion of our market share.

"
column74:
"

Our global equities franchise also posted strong results for the year. Clients continue to place significant value on the integration of our various services; electronic
column75: cash
column76: derivatives and prime brokerage as well as our global footprint. Our performance in 2015 highlighted these strengths. In addition
column77: the combination of continued strong performance for our clients and the diversified set of offerings drove a record year for our Investment Management business. We ended the year with record assets under supervision of $1.25 trillion and robust net inflows
column78:
which totaled $94 billion.

"
column79:
"

Ultimately
column80: 2015 reinforced a long standing operating principle
column81: that there is tremendous value to having a diversified set of global businesses. More importantly
column82:
it is the value of being a leader in these businesses that really counts.

"
column83:
"

Now let's discuss the individual businesses in greater detail. As it relates to the quarter
column84: Investment Banking produced net revenues of $1.5 billion
column85: slightly lower than the third quarter. A pickup in M&A was offset by a decline in underwriting activity. For the full year
column86: Investment Banking net revenues were $7 billion
column87:
up 9% from 2014 on the back of a 40% increase in financial advisory revenues. This was partially offset by lower equity and debt underwriting revenues.

"
column88:
"

Our franchise remains very strong. 2015 was our second highest annual revenues for Investment Banking. We ended the year ranked 1st in global and announced and completed M&A. Our completed M&A volumes were approximately $350 billion higher than our next closest competitor. A record gap
column89:
since we've been a public company. We were also ranked 1st in global equity and equity related and common stock offerings for 2015.

"
column90:
"

Breaking down the components of Investment Banking in the fourth quarter; advisory revenues were $879 million
column91: a 9% improvement relative to the third quarter reflects an increase in a number of completed M&A transactions. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the fourth quarter
column92:
including SunGard's $9.1 billion sale to Fidelity National Information Services. General Electric Capital Corporation's $9 billion sale of its Transportation Finance business to BMO Financial Group and HCC Insurance Holding's $7.5 billion sale to Tokio Marine Holdings.

"
column93:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the fourth quarter
column94: including DuPont's combination with Dow Chemical in a $130 billion merger of equals
column95:
Newell Rubbermaid's $20 billion acquisition of Jarden Corporation and SanDisk's approximately $19 billion sale to Western Digital.

"
column96:
"

Moving to underwriting
column97: net revenues were $616 million in the fourth quarter down 11% sequentially as debt issuance slowed. Equity underwriting revenues of $228 million were up 20% compared to the third quarter as IPOs increased from very low levels last quarter. Debt underwriting revenues decreased 21% to $440 million due to a decline in leveraged finance activity. During the fourth quarter
column98: we actively supported our clients' financing needs
column99: participating in Visa's $16 billion investment grade offering to support its purchase of Visa Europe
column100:
McDonald's $6 billion investment grade offering and Worldpay Group's $3.8 billion IPO. Our Investment Banking backlog improved from third quarter levels and finished at its second highest level.

"
column101:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column102: which comprises both our fixed and equities businesses; net revenues were $2.9 billion in the fourth quarter
column103: down 10% compared to the third quarter. For the full year
column104: $15.2 billion of net revenues were roughly consistent with 2014. FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.1 billion in the fourth quarter down 23% sequentially and included $54 million of DVA losses. Excluding DVA
column105: revenues were down 10% quarter-over-quarter as many businesses were impacted by either lower client activity or more difficult market making conditions. Credit decreased significantly
column106:
as the market was characterized by widening high yields spread in the U.S. and low levels of liquidity.

"
column107:
"

Interest rate in currencies were lower sequentially as client activity declined. Mortgages continue to be challenged as spread widened and the prospect for higher rates and client activity remained generally low. Commodities was essentially unchanged as client activity was muted and energy prices remained under pressure. For the full year
column108: FICC Client Execution net revenues were $7.3 billion down 13% year-over-year
column109: where challenging market conditions and lower levels of client activity in our micro businesses
column110: credit and mortgages
column111: offset stronger client activity and a favorable backdrop for our macro businesses
column112:
particularly rates and currencies.

"
column113:
"

In equities
column114: which includes equities client execution
column115: commissions and fees and securities services
column116: net revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.8 billion
column117: flat sequentially and included $14 million in DVA losses. Equities client execution revenues were roughly consistent sequentially at $562 million. Commissions and fees were $763 million
column118:
down 7% relative to the third quarter as global client volumes declined. Securities services generated net revenues of $430 million up 13% sequentially.

"
column119:
"

For the full year
column120: equities produced net revenues of $7.8 billion up 16% year-over-year. In 2015
column121: we benefited from several factors
column122: a better market backdrop and a more favorable environment from securities services. Turning to risk
column123:
average daily VaR in the fourth quarter was $71 million down from $74 million in the third quarter.

"
column124:

Moving on to our investing and lending activities
column125: collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $1.3 billion in the fourth quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $1 billion
column126: primarily reflecting the company's specific events
column127: including financings
column128: sales and gains in public equity investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $299 million which was largely driven by net interest income. For the full year
column129:
Investing & Lending generated net revenues of $5.4 billion driven by $3.78 billion in gains from equity securities and $1.66 billion of net revenues from debt securities and loans.

"
column130:
"

In Investment Management
column131: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion. This was up 9% from the third quarter
column132: primarily as a result of $190 million in incentive fees largely from alternative asset products. Management and other fees were up 2% sequentially to $1.24 billion. For the full year
column133: Investment Management net revenues were a record $6.2 billion
column134: up 3% from 2014
column135: on record management and other fees and higher transaction revenues. During the fourth quarter
column136: assets under supervision increased $64 billion to a record $1.25 trillion
column137: primarily due to net inflows into liquidity products. On a full year basis
column138: we had long term fixed income flows of $41 billion
column139: equity inflows of $23 billion
column140:
and alternative inflows of $7 billion.

"
column141:
"

Moving to our performance
column142:
73% of our client mutual fund assets ranked in the top two quartiles on a three year and a five year basis.

"
column143:

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column144: which includes salaries
column145: bonuses
column146: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column147: remained roughly flat at $12.7 billion for 2015 and translated into a compensation to net revenues ratio of 37.5%. Fourth quarter non-compensation expenses were $4.1 billion and incorporated $1.95 billion in litigation and regulatory expenses. The quarter also included a $123 million donation to Goldman Sachs Gives
column148:
our donor advised charitable fund.

"
column149:
"

For the full year
column150: non-compensation expenses were up 30% due to $4 billion in provisions for litigation and regulatory matters. Excluding litigation provisions
column151:
non-compensation expenses would have been down 4% year-over-year.

"
column152:
"

Now I'd like to take you through a few key statistics for the end of the year. Total staff at year end was approximately 36
column154: up 8% from year end 2014. This is a significant increase
column155: so let's breakdown the drivers. Of the 2
column156: 800 of incremental staff
column157: a little more than half was due to our continued investment in regulatory compliance and other federation initiatives
column158: largely in technology and operations. The remainder was focused on business growth initiatives
column159:
particularly with Investment Management.

"
column160:
"

Our effective tax rate was 30.7% for 2015. Our global core liquid assets ended the year at $199 billion. While our balance sheet was roughly flat year-over-year
column161: Level 3 assets declined by 33% to $24 billion. Our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio was 12.4% under the Basel III advanced approach. It was 13.6% using the standardized approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 5.9%. With respect to our method to G-SIB surcharge
column162: we currently estimate that we are at or near the lower bucket
column163:
given a decline in Level 3 assets and derivative notionals over the course of the year.

"
column164:
"

And finally
column165: we repurchased 8.9 million shares of common stock for $1.65 billion in the quarter. For the full year
column166: we repurchased $4.2 billion. Year-over-year
column167: our average fully diluted share count declined by approximately [15 million]. In addition
column168: we increased our quarterly dividend to $0.65 per share in the second quarter and paid out approximately $1.2 billion of common dividends during the year. In total
column169:
we returned $5.4 billion of capital to shareholders in 2015.

"
column170:
"

Before taking questions
column171: a few closing thoughts. Clearly
column172: it has been a challenging environment for the entire industry. 2015 marks the fourth consecutive year that we have posted revenues of approximately $34 billion. Excluding litigation charges related to the RMBS Working Group
column173: it is also the fourth consecutive year that we have produced strong relative results and returns that exceeded our cost of capital. We have been able to post consistent
column174: strong relative results despite the difficult operating environment
column175: which is a statement of the strength of our global client franchise
column176:
the caliber of our people and our culture of teamwork and adaptability.

"
column177:
"

Over the past four years
column178: we've also grown book value per share by 7% per annum
column179: returned nearly $25 billion in capital to our shareholders and reduced our basic share count by 75 million shares or 14%. And most importantly we've been able to accomplish these things while maintaining leading positions across all of our businesses
column180: transforming our financial profile
column181: prudently managing our risks
column182: adapting to regulatory change
column183:
continuing to invest in our future and positioning the Firm to provide significant operating leverage when the environment improves.

"
column184:
"

There's no doubt that the second half of 2015 had its fair share of challenges
column185: which significantly impacted market sentiment and client activity. It's quite natural for all of us to be influenced by recent events and we maintain a healthy respect to them. We certainly don\u2019t control the opportunities set
column186: however we do control several things; how we build our client relationships
column187: how we invest in our people
column188: how we adapt to change
column189: how we allocate our capital
column190: manage our risks and control our costs
column191: and finally
column192:
how we invest in the future. We believe our Firm's commitment to excellence in these areas has been and will continue to be what drives our performance over the long term.

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column35:
and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call.

"

This call is being recorded today
column39:

column40:
you may begin your conference.

"
column41:
"

Dane E. Holmes - Head-Investor Relations

"
column42:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column43:
Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call.

"
column44:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that

For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column46:
please see the description of Risk Factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 2015.

"
column47:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column48: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column50: risk-weighted assets
column51:
global core liquid assets and supplementary leverage ratio. You should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that's posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"

This audiocast is copyrighted material to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and may not be duplicated
column53:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column55: Harvey Schwartz
column56:
will now review the firm's results. Harvey?

"
column57:
"

Harvey Mitchell Schwartz - Chief Financial Officer & Executive Vice President

"
column58:
"

Thanks
column59: Dane
column60:
and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through the first quarter results and I'm happy to answer any questions.

"
column61:
"

Net revenues were $6.3 billion; net earnings
column62: $1.1 billion
column63: and earnings per diluted share
column64:
$2.68. Net earnings to common included a $161 million benefit related to the successful tender of our APEX securities. The tender added $0.36 per diluted share.

"
column65:
"

The first quarter of 2016 was challenging. It started with renewed uncertainty about the global economic outlook
column66: with the possibility of a recession even being raised. These concerns included growth prospects from China
column67: plummeting oil prices
column68: a strengthening U.S. dollar
column69: and multiple geopolitical events
column70:
to name a few. All these came into focus during an eventful first quarter.

"
column71:
"

These concerns translated into significant price pressure at the beginning of the quarter across both equity and fixed income markets. The Dow declined by 6% in the first week. This is the worst start in its nearly 90-year history. The index ultimately reached its low point in mid-February
column72: declining 10%. Equity markets in other geographies endured even more material declines during the quarter
column73: with the Shanghai down as much as 25% and the Nikkei down as much as 21%. Credit spreads also widened significantly intra-quarter
column74:
particularly for high yield and energy-related issuers.

"
column75:
"

Global Central Bank activity was front and center again during the quarter. After raising rates in December for the first time in more than nine years
column76: the market heavily debated the Federal Reserve's future actions. In the eurozone
column77: the European Central Bank took additional stimulus measures well beyond what was initially expected by the market. And finally
column78:
the Bank of Japan moved interest rates into negative territory.

"
column79:
"

With all these factors at work
column80: it isn't surprising that it resulted in a difficult operating environment for our clients and
column81: by extension
column82: constrained opportunities in each of our business segments. Within Investment Banking
column83: for example
column84:
industry-wide equity underwriting volumes declined by 57% year-over-year.

"
column85:
"

Performance was challenged for many of our ICS clients. For example
column86: nearly 80% of the largest active U.S. equity mutual funds underperformed their benchmarks in the quarter. As you would expect with markets flat-to-down worldwide
column87: our equity investing business was negatively impacted. And finally
column88:
incentive fees declined during the quarter due to limited harvesting opportunities.

"
column89:
"

With that as a backdrop
column90: let's now discuss individual business performance in greater detail. Investment Banking produced first quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion
column91:
5% lower than the fourth quarter as we saw lower client activity across M&A and equity underwriting. Our Investment Banking backlog decreased since the end of the year but is still up relative to a year ago.

"
column92:
"

Breaking down the components of Investment Banking in the first quarter
column93: Advisory revenues were $771 million. 12% decline relative to the fourth quarter reflects a decrease in the number of completed M&A transactions. Year-to-date
column94:
Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced M&A.

"
column95:
"

We advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the first quarter
column96:
including Syngenta's $43.6 billion cash tender offer from ChemChina; Valspar's $11.3 billion acquisition by Sherwin-Williams; and ADT's $12 billion acquisition by Apollo.

"
column97:
"

We also advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the first quarter
column98:
including BG Group's \u00a347 billion acquisition by Royal Dutch Shell; BT Group's\u00a312.5 billion acquisition of EE Limited; and PETCO Animal Supplies' $4.6 billion sale to a consortium of investors.

"
column99:
"

Moving to Underwriting
column100: net revenues were $692 million in the first quarter
column101:
up 4% sequentially as a pickup in debt underwriting more than offset a slowdown in equity issuance. Equity underwriting revenues were $183 million. This was down significantly compared to the fourth quarter due to a decrease in offerings industry-wide. Debt underwriting revenues were up 16% to $509 million and benefited from strong investment-grade issuance.

"
column102:
"

During the first quarter
column103: we actively supported our clients' financing needs
column104: participating in Newell Rubbermaid's $8 billion financing to support its acquisition of Jarden
column105: Vista's $4 billion loan and bond offering to support its acquisition of Solera
column106:
and Devon Energy's $1.5 billion follow-on offering.

"
column107:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column108: which comprises both our FICC and Equities businesses
column109: net revenues were $3.4 billion in the first quarter
column110: up 20% compared to the fourth quarter. In the quarter
column111: we early-adopted the new accounting standard for DVA
column112: which is now captured in other comprehensive income. DVA for the current quarter was immaterial. FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.7 billion in the first quarter
column113: up 48% sequentially
column114:
as client activity improved in many businesses from weak fourth quarter levels.

"
column115:
"

As I mentioned
column116: the operating environment across the FICC complex was quite difficult due to macro uncertainty and volatile markets. This led to a challenging backdrop for our clients with weak investment performance and drove difficult market-making conditions for the firm. The environment in the first quarter of 2016 stands in stark contrast to the environment in the first quarter of last year. Consequently
column117:
there was a substantial downward revenue pressure year-over-year.

"
column118:
"

Interest rates and currencies were significantly lower. Client activity and interest rates held up relatively well. However
column119:
activity within currencies declined compared to a strong first quarter of last year.

"
column120:
"

Credit also decreased significantly as market conditions remained difficult
column121:
particularly in Europe. Commodities was weaker as client activity was muted with energy prices remaining low. Mortgages continue to be challenged as spreads widened for some products and client activity remained low.

"
column122:
"

In Equities
column123: which includes equities client execution
column124: commissions and fees
column125: and security services
column126: net revenues for the first quarter were $1.8 billion
column127:
up 1% sequentially. First quarter results in Equities were roughly consistent with the back half of last year but significantly weaker compared to a robust performance in the first quarter of 2015. Net revenues declined 23% year-over-year and reflected the impact of a challenging environment for our clients and the firm.

"
column128:
"

Equities client execution net revenues of $470 million were down significantly year-over-year. Higher volatility and global equity market weakness at the beginning of the quarter impacted investor conviction and risk appetite.

"
column129:
"

Commissions and fees were $878 million
column130: up 9% year-over-year as client activity increased in our lower touch electronic channels. Security services generated net revenues of $432 million
column131:
up 10% year-over-year on improved spreads.

"
column132:
"

Turning to risk
column133: average daily VaR in the first quarter was $72 million
column134:
up slightly from $71 million in the fourth quarter.

"
column135:
"

Moving on to our Investing & Lending activities
column136: collectively
column137: these businesses produced net revenues of $87 million in the first quarter. In equity securities
column138:
markdowns on public investments entirely offset net revenues in private investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $87 million. Revenues were driven by net interest income. This was partially offset by increased provisions on our corporate energy exposures.

"
column139:
"

In Investment Management
column140: we reported first quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion. This was down 13% from the fourth quarter
column141: primarily as a result of lower incentive fees and management and other fees. During the quarter
column142:
management and other fees were down 6% sequentially to $1.2 billion due to a change in the mix of client assets and strategies.

"
column143:
"

Assets under supervision increased $35 billion sequentially to a record $1.29 trillion
column144: primarily due to net inflows into liquidity and long-term fee-based products. We had $16 billion of net inflows into liquidity products
column145: $10 billion of long-term net inflows
column146: primarily driven by fixed income and equity products
column147:
and $9 billion of market appreciation.

"
column148:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column149: which includes salaries
column150: bonuses
column151: amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column152:
declined by 40% versus the first quarter of 2015. The significant reduction in compensation and benefits expense reflects the more challenging revenue environment and translated into a compensation to net revenues ratio of 42%.

"
column153:
"

First quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.1 billion
column154:
significantly lower than the fourth quarter and 6% lower than the first quarter of 2015. This is the lowest quarterly level since the second quarter of 2009.

"
column155:
"

Now I'd like to take you through a few key statistics for the first quarter. Total staff was approximately 36
column157: down 1% from year-end 2015. Our effective tax rate for the first quarter was 28%. Our global core liquid assets ended the first quarter at $196 billion and our balance sheet and level 3 assets were $878 billion and $24 billion
column158: respectively. Our Common Equity Tier 1 ratio was 12.2% under the Basel III Advanced approach. It was 13.4% using the Standardized approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 6%. And finally
column159:
we repurchased 10 million shares of common stock for $1.55 billion in the quarter.

"
column160:
"

In conclusion
column161: the first quarter was obviously a difficult period for our clients
column162: the markets and our opportunity set. While clearly we don't control the opportunity set
column163: we proactively took action in key areas that we do control: our cost structure and our capital. In addition
column164: this is the first quarter in a while that we faced significant headwinds across each of our business segments. Given that we operate in a cyclical industry
column165:
it shouldn't be surprising that there will be difficult quarters.

"
column166:
"

That being said
column167: we don't create deep client relationships in a quarter
column168: we don't hire our people for a quarter
column169: and we certainly don't build businesses for a quarter. Our success has been predicated on having a strong culture that promotes both a long-term perspective
column170:
while simultaneously being very focused on managing to the current environment. That long-term focus has been the foundation for building a leading global investment bank and creating superior results for our shareholders.

"
column171:
"

As we look forward
column172: we are committed to remaining nimble and efficient operators
column173:
disciplined capital allocators and prudent risk managers. Our commitment to these principles has been and will continue to be the basis for our performance over time.

"
column174:
"

Thanks again for dialing in
column175:
and I'm happy to answer your questions.

"
column176:
"

column39:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column40: particularly as it relates to our investment banking transaction backlog
column41: capital ratios
column42: risk-weighted assets
column45:
and you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that\u2019s posed on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column46:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of the Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and may not be duplicated
column47:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column48:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column50:
will now review the firm\u2019s results. Harvey?

"
column51:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column52:
"

Thanks Dane
column53: and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I\u2019ll walk you through the second quarter results
column54: then I\u2019m happy to answer any questions. Net revenues $7.9 billion
column55: net earnings $1.8 billion
column56: earnings per diluted share $3.72
column57:
and our annualized return on common equity was 8.7%.

"
column58:
"

As you all remember
column59:
the first quarter of 2016 was dominated by renewed uncertainty regarding the global economic outlook. This impacted prices across various asset classes and drove macro headwinds in each of our businesses. Many of the concerns that existed in the first quarter moderated as we started the second quarter. This was a better environment for our clients and our performance.

"
column60:
"

This was also reflected in equity markets; for example
column61: the S&P 500 was relatively unchanged for most of April and May. In addition
column62: we saw sequential improvements in global investment banking volumes. Activity for the first two months of the quarter was on pace to be up over 20% for equity offerings and nearly 15% for announced M&A; however
column63: as we approached June
column64: the market became increasingly focused on Brexit. The focus was on both the economic uncertainty surrounding the potential outcome and the potential economic implications of leaving the EU. These concerns negatively impacted client sentiment
column65:
risk appetite and activity levels heading into the vote.

"
column66:
"

In response to the Leave vote on June 23
column67: market volatility spiked and global equity markets declined significantly
column68: with the MSCI World down roughly 7% in two days. While equity markets largely reversed those losses in the last three days of the quarter
column69:
clients and the border marketplace continue to wrestle with the Brexit vote and related uncertainty.

"
column70:
"

With that as a backdrop
column71: let\u2019s now discuss individual business performance in greater detail. Investment banking produced second quarter net revenues of $1.8 billion
column72:
22% higher than the first quarter as we saw increased client activity across equity and debt underwriting. Our investment banking backlog decreased relative to the end of the first quarter and the year ago.

"
column73:
"

Breaking down the components of investment banking in the second quarter
column74: advisory revenues were $794 million
column75: up 3% from the first quarter. Year-to-date
column76: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advised a number of important transactions that were announced during the second quarter
column77: including NorthStar Asset Management\u2019s $16.9 billion tri-party merger with Colony Capital and NorthStar Realty Finance; Great Plains Energy\u2019s $12.2 billion acquisition of Westar Energy
column78:
and Hewlett Packard Enterprises\u2019 $8.5 billion spinoff and merger of its enterprise services business with Computer Sciences Corporation.

"
column79:
"

We also advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the second quarter
column80: including Charter Communications\u2019 $78.7 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable and $10.4 billion acquisition of Bright House Networks; Visa Inc.\u2019s \u20ac18.7 billion of Visa Europe
column81:
and Airgas Inc.\u2019s $13.4 billion sale to Air Liquide.

"
column82:
"

Moving to underwriting
column83: net revenues were $993 million in the second quarter
column84:
up 43% sequentially as capital markets activity picked up from the first quarter. Equity underwriting revenues were $269 million. This was up significantly compared to weak activity in the first quarter due to an increase in IPOs. Debt underwriting revenues were up 42% to $724 million and benefited from asset-backed issuance and strong leveraged finance activity.

"
column85:
"

During the second quarter
column86: we actively supported our clients\u2019 financing needs
column87:
participating in Mylan\u2019s $6.5 billion investment-grade offering to support its acquisition of Meda AB; U.S. Foods\u2019 $1.2 billion IPO; and the approximately \u20ac850 million IPO of Philips Lighting.

"
column88:
"

Turning to institutional client services
column89: which comprises both our FICC and equities businesses
column90: net revenues were $3.7 billion in the second quarter
column91: up 7% compared to the first quarter. FICC client execution net revenues were $1.9 billion in the second quarter
column92: up 16% sequentially as market making conditions improved in many businesses from the first quarter. Credit and mortgages increased as the backdrop for providing liquidity was more normalized compared to the first quarter. Rates was also higher sequentially given better market making conditions. Currencies declined relative to solid client activity levels in the first quarter
column93:
and commodities declined slightly during the quarter.

"
column94:
"

In equities
column95: which includes equities client execution
column96: commissions and fees
column97: and securities services
column98: net revenues for the second quarter were $1.8 billion
column99: down slightly quarter over quarter. Equities client execution net revenues of $587 million were up 25% sequentially. Better market making conditions for most of the quarter and select corporate activity drove improved performance. Commissions and fees were $745 million
column100: down 15% quarter over quarter as client activity decreased following heightened volumes in the first quarter. Securities services generated net revenues of $422 million
column101:
down 2% relative to the first quarter as seasonally stronger client activity was offset by slightly lower customer balances and spreads.

"
column102:
"

Turning to risk
column103: average daily borrowing in the second quarter was $62 million
column104:
down from $72 million in the first quarter.

"
column105:
"

Moving on to our investing and lending activities
column106: collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $1.1 billion in the second quarter. Equities securities generated net revenues of $626 million primarily reflecting company-specific events
column107: sales
column108: and gains in public equity investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $485 million and included more than $250 million of net interest income. In investment management
column109: we reported second quarter net revenues of $1.4 billion
column110: consistent with the first quarter. During the quarter
column111:
management and other fees were roughly flat sequentially at $1.2 billion.

"
column112:
"

Assets under supervision increased $23 billion sequentially to a record $1.31 trillion. The $23 billion increase was substantially driven by $19 billion of net market appreciation. We also had $4 billion of net inflows with $3 billion from liquidity products
column113:
and the remainder from long-term fee-based products.

"
column114:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense for the year to date
column115: which includes salaries
column116: bonuses
column117: amortization of prior year equity work and other items such as benefits
column118: was accrued at a compensation to net revenues ratio of 42%
column119: consistent with the first half of last year. To respond to the more challenging backdrop
column120: we completed an expense initiative during the first and second quarter. The run rate expense savings will be roughly $700 million. In 2016
column121: these expected savings will be partially offset by severance and other related costs. Second quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.1 billion
column122:
up slightly compared to the first quarter.

"
column123:
"

Now I\u2019d like to take you through a few key statistics. Total staff was approximately 34
column125: down 5% from the first quarter. Our effective tax rate for the year to date was 26.8%. Our global core of liquid assets ended the second quarter at $211 billion and our balance sheet was $897 billion. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 12.2% under the Basel III advanced approach. It was 13.7% using the standardized approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 6.1%. All of our capital ratios are well in excess of regulatory requirements. This reflects our multi-year effort to de-risk the firm and strengthen our financial profile. Given robust capital ratios
column126:
the firm is well positioned to return excess capital to shareholders.

"
column127:
"

In the quarter
column128: we repurchased 11.1 million common shares of common stock for $1.7 billion. For the five quarter CCAR cycle for 2015
column129: we provided shareholders with $6.2 billion in share buybacks and $1.5 billion in common stock dividends. In terms of this year\u2019s CCAR test
column130:
we announced that the Federal Reserve Board did not object to our plan.

"
column131:
"

In conclusion
column132: the first half of 2016 has certainly presented its fair share of challenges and concerns. At the core of these concerns is the outlook for the global economy. As you have heard us state many times before
column133: confidence in economic growth is the most important long-term driver of our business. Confidence incentivizes client activity
column134: which increases demand for our advice
column135: our content and our execution capabilities. While like the rest of the world we would welcome more robust economic growth
column136:
ultimately we have to manage the firm for both the current environment and potential future opportunities.

"
column137:
"

How we\u2019ve navigated the difficult environment in the first half of 2016 demonstrates both the strength and resilience of our culture. We remain vigilant regarding our cost structure
column138: our capital usage and our risk profile
column139:
and at the same time we have maintained the necessary commitment to ensure that we can meet our clients\u2019 needs as they grow.

"
column140:
"

Being in a position to deliver for our clients and our shareholders requires ongoing investment and a long-term perspective. While we continue to invest in our existing set of businesses
column141: we are also looking for new opportunities. One example is our digital consumer lending platform. While still in its early stages
column142: we expect to begin the initial phase of engaging consumers this fall. As we have discussed with you in the past
column143: we are taking a very deliberate and methodical approach to this effort. We are looking to build a durable business
column144: so it will take time. Similar to our other businesses
column145:
creating a valuable and differentiated service for our clients is core to our strategy.

"
column146:
"

In summary
column147:
our ability to both react to the current world and simultaneously invest in the future will position the firm to deliver superior value to our clients and our shareholders in the years ahead.

"
column148:
"

Thanks again for dialing in
column149:
and I\u2019m happy to answer your questions.

column870: fair enough. Then just in terms of the backlog decline both sequentially and year over year
column871: is there any specific geography - you know
column874:
North AmericA - that is meaningfully stronger or weaker within that trend?

"
column880:
that\u2019s it for me. Thank you.

"
column884:
"

Your next question is from the line of Eric Wasserstrom with Guggenheim Partners. Please go ahead.

"
column887: just to circle back to the expense commentary for a moment
column888: would it be your expectation that the actions you\u2019ve taken will allow you to generate positive operating leverage
column890:
what is your expectation about operating leverage for the back half of this year?

"
column893: you\u2019ve seen it - it seems like ages ago now
column894: but in the first quarter of 2015
column895: we had an improved market environment
column896: we were very quickly able to deliver lots of operating leverage
column897: and you saw a near 15% ROE in that quarter. Like I said
column898: it feels like a long time ago now. We continually review all the businesses to ensure that we\u2019re maintaining the right footprint
column899: so this is all about making sure that we find the right balance between our commitment to clients over the long term and expense management
column900: and obviously the first half of this year has not been the greatest environment
column901:
so you\u2019re just seeing us respond to it.

"
column903:
"

Can you just help me understand - when you say $700 million of run rate savings
column904:
from what level and under what revenue circumstances?

"
column906:
"

So the way to think about that is
column907: if we finish the end of the 2015 with a certain [indiscernible]
column908: all those adjustments and resources on a run rate basis would be $700 million
column909: so all other factors being equal. But that won\u2019t translate into this year because there are severance and other related costs
column910: and net of that will be something more like 350
column911: so you should really think of that as translating into 2017. Now
column912: this will be dynamic of course because we\u2019ll be hiring more people
column913: so you and I are really sterilizing the discussion for this number
column914:
but I think that\u2019s the best way to explain it to you.

"
column916:
"

It sounds like you think that the actions you\u2019ve taken are sufficient to address this current revenue circumstance
column917:
but what would cause you perhaps reconsider and make additional adjustments?

"
column919:
"

Well certainly if the environment continued to be challenged
column920: we would continue to refine the businesses. On the flipside
column921: if the environment globally improved dramatically and there was a real demand for our resources
column922: which has been no difficulty in attracting very
column923: very high quality talent to the firm
column924:
so we\u2019re also being very thoughtful about giving people an opportunity to want to be at Goldman Sachs that we want to be here.

"
column926:
"

Great. Then just one quick accounting question. I think last quarter you indicated that your expected tax rate for the full year would be around 31%. Has that changed at all
column931:
I would say something just shy of 30 feels like a better expectation where we stand right now.

"
column935:
"

Your next question is from the line of Devin Ryan with JMP Securities. Please go ahead.

"
column943:
"

I appreciate the update on the digital consumer finance business initiative
column944: understand the current view that this is going to be a slow build. It sounds like it could take some time to really move the needle under the current path
column945: but is there a case for buying something to enhance either the lending capabilities or liability gathering
column946: just so that you get to that critical mass more quickly
column947: or just thinking about the strategy
column948: is it just kind of by its nature it needs to be built up organically
column949:
just so that it\u2019s a differentiated platform?

"
column952: it\u2019s a good question. So obviously you\u2019ve seen us do a number of smaller bolt-on acquisitions in IMD
column954: because we\u2019re certainly not reluctant to do that
column955: is when we feel like we had a capability that we would\u2014if there\u2019s a service we\u2019d like to enhance for our clients or a capability that we\u2019re quite good at
column956: that we think we can add scale to
column957:
we\u2019ll just weigh the costs and benefits of acquiring versus building in-house.

"
column960: we really felt like best designed from scratch
column961: and the reason for that is I think we\u2019re kind of uniquely positioned. It allows us to leverage our technology skills and our risk skills
column962: but this is really about if you look at sort of the competitive landscape
column963:
there are benefits that online lending platforms provide to consumers and there are benefits that large commercial providers of credit provide to consumers. We\u2019re just really looking to bridge the gap between those strengths and offer consumers as best we can a really thoughtful and differentiated product.

"
column967: just love some thoughts about how you guys are thinking about the upcoming election just as an influence on business
column968: either from a client perspective or even how you\u2019re thinking about planning in your business. There\u2019s been a lot of rhetoric just around some pretty bold proposals recently
column971: some similar kind of bold themes in other sectors. I\u2019m just curious how much is this uncertainty into the election delaying decision-making
column973:
or keeping a lid on client activity.

"
column976: I think this cycle will have its unique aspects to it versus other presidential cycles
column977: but historically there\u2019s always been some element which may have ultimately deferred a decision that a client might make to a later period. But these are short term in nature
column978:
so we don\u2019t see any significant impact in terms of the near term.

"
column981: okay. Just last one quickly - the decline in VAR
column982: I know that can bounce around
column983:
but was that just de-risking into the U.K. referendum or just the reduced volatility? Just curious what drove that - it was at the lowest level in quite some time.

"
column985:
"

It was a combination. Obviously the VAR declined pretty meaningfully in average over the quarter. Really
column986: that was a combination of two factors. There was reduced client activity going into Brexit
column988:
we were being pretty prudent as we approached the date.

"
column995:
"

Your next question is from the line of Marty Mosby with Vining Sparks. Please go ahead.

"
column998: I wanted to go back into the CCAR and think about adjustments on operational risk. Like we had talked about
column999: there had been some double counting. You did get a benefit of 250 basis points
column1001: in your minimum ratios going higher. Is that\u2014you know
column1002: as we talked about double counting and SIFI possibly going into CCAR
column1003:
it looks like you got a break on operational risk that almost equals your SIFI charge almost exactly.

"
column1005:
"

We don\u2019t have any visibility into those calculations
column1007: there\u2019s no transparency in that process
column1008: so I really can\u2019t comment. I think this year\u2019s test and last year\u2019s test and the year prior to that
column1009: I think it just confirms what the Federal Reserve has been very clear about. Their test is going to be dynamic from year to year. They\u2019re going to incorporate lots of different variables - that\u2019s how they designed it
column1010:
so I actually think they\u2019re just fulfilling their design criteria.

"
column1012:
"

The other thing I was going to ask you was on this quarter and the headcount reductions
column1013: where the severance costs would probably hit
column1014: when you look at kind of dividing it
column1016: you\u2019re at full run rate in the second quarter
column1017: which I know you probably weren\u2019t
column1019: and then you look at the net for the year you\u2019re talking about for this year of being 350 net severance then being possible $350 million
column1020:
I was trying to think of the timing in relation to the gains in the sense of the expense savings and how that might have affected the second quarter.

"
column1023: so the way to think about it is on an annualized basis
column1025: so you should incorporate those numbers as $700 million on a run rate basis
column1026: that run rate basis\u2014and this is again a very sterilized way we\u2019re doing this conversation. That\u2019s all other factors being equal going into 2017
column1027: and this year that will translate roughly into $350 million of savings this year. How that flows through quarter to quarter
column1028:
that\u2019s very specific to a number of circumstances.

"
column1030:
"

Would it be safe to say that a majority of the severance was going to be at least in the second quarter?

"
column1037:
"

Your next question is from the line of Brian Kleinhanzl with KBW. Please go ahead.

"
column1044:
"

I just had a quick question on the Volcker investments. I know you said previously that there is a chance that it could get extended as you get into 2017
column1045:
but there\u2019s really been no discussion as far as I\u2019ve seen with regards to that. So how should we think about those Volcker investments over the course of next year? Is it really just some type of liquidity event in 2Q17 that will become or happen because if there is no extension or you\u2019re just going to take a wait-and-see approach on winding those down?

"
column1047:
"

So as I mentioned before
column1050: so I won\u2019t do it again. You would have seen a communication from the regulators that basically spoke to the confirmation of the extension to 2017
column1051: and then there\u2019s been public submissions in terms of industry-wide requests for incremental extensions
column1052:
which I believe under the Volcker interpretations can be as much as an incremental five years.

"
column1054: if you go back to the genesis of Volcker
column1055: it wasn\u2019t designed to force fire sales or anything like that
column1056: so the industry again has been working with the regulators through various bodies
column1057: and we\u2019ll see how the regulators finally respond to that. But I think the industry has done a good job
column1060: but we\u2019re sitting alongside our clients mostly in these funds
column1061:
so we don\u2019t have unilateral authority just to sell these assets.

"
column1069:
there are no further questions. Please continue with any closing remarks.

"
column1071:
"

That\u2019s great. Since there aren\u2019t any more questions
column1072: we just want to thank everybody for joining the call. Hopefully we\u2019ll all get to see you over the course of the coming months. If you have any other questions
column1073:
give a call into Dane and the team; but otherwise thanks again for participating and have a great summer.

"

this does conclude the Goldman Sachs second quarter 2016 earnings conference call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.

{"Goldman Sachs Group's (GS) Management on Q3 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (NYSE:GS)

Dane Holmes - IR
