"
column28:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column29: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded today
column34:
"

Dane Holmes

"
column35:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column36:
Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call.

"
column37:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that
column38: by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ possibly materially from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column39:
please see the description of Risk Factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 2015.

"
column40:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column41: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column42: capital ratios
column44:
global core liquid assets and supplementary leverage ratio and you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that's posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column45:
"

This audio cast is copyrighted material to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and may not be duplicated
column46: reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent. Our Chief Financial Officer
column47: Harvey Schwartz
column48:
will now review the firm's results. Harvey?

"
column50:
"

Thanks Dane and thanks to everyone for dialing in. I'll walk you through the third quarter and year-to-date results and am happy to answer any questions.

"
column51:
"

Net revenues were $8.2 billion
column52: net earnings $2.1 billion. Earnings per diluted share $4.88 and our annualized return on common equity was 11.2%. For the year-to-date
column53: net revenues were $22.4 billion
column55:
earnings per diluted share $11.24 and our annualized return on common equity was 8.7%.

"
column56:
"

Relative to the first quarter of this year
column57: the second and now the third quarter
column58: have shown steady improvement. This improvement is reflected in third-quarter revenues
column59:
which increased 19% year-over-year. We also had a modest sequential increase which is particularly noteworthy given the third quarter is often seasonally slower.

"
column60:
"

A few factors contributed to the enhanced operating environment. The markets generally improved with equity prices steadily moving higher. The S&P 500 was up 3.3% in the third quarter. The MSCI World increased by 4.8% and the VIX declined by 15%.

"
column61:
"

Credit spreads also tightened during the quarter with U.S. investment grade and high yield cash spreads tighter by 12 basis points and 87 basis points respectively. In addition
column62:
there weren't any major changes to the global economic outlook over the course of the quarter. For example consensus estimates for global GDP growth remained roughly consistent.

"
column63:
"

Ultimately a more favorable backdrop and improved client sentiment translated into year-over-year revenue growth in three of our four business segments. Now let's discuss them.

"
column64:
"

Investment banking produced third quarter revenues of $1.5 billion
column65: 14% lower than a strong second quarter. Although revenues declined sequentially
column66: our investment banking backlog remained robust and was up versus last quarter. Breaking down the components of investment banking in the quarter
column67:
advisory revenues were $658 million down 17% compared to the second quarter as industry-wide completed activity declined.

"
column68:
"

Year-to-date Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the third quarter
column69:
including ARM holdings \u00a324.4 billion sale to Softbank Group. AGL Resources $12 billion merger with Southern Company and Lockheed Martin's $5 billion spinoff and merger of its IS&GS business into Leidos.

"
column70:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the third quarter
column71:
including WhiteWave Foods $12.5 billion sale to Group Danone. Hewlett-Packard Enterprises' $8.8 billion spin off and merger of non-core software assets with Micro Focus International and Abbott Medical Optics' $4.3 billion sale to Johnson & Johnson.

"
column72:
"

Moving down to revenue
column73: revenues were $879 million in the third quarter
column74: down 11% sequentially
column75:
due to a decline in both debt and equity underwriting. Equity underwriting revenues were $227 million down 16% compared to the second quarter due to a continued weak backdrop for equity issuance.

"
column76:
"

However the end of the quarter was significantly more active in the beginning with more than half of the quarter's IPO volume occurring in September. Debt underwriting revenues of $652 million were down 10% quarter-over-quarter
column77:
following a robust second quarter.

"
column78:
"

For the first nine months of the year debt amortizing produced record year-to-date results. During the third quarter
column79: we actively supported our client's financing needs
column80: participating in Postal Savings Bank of China's $7.4 billion IPO
column81:
Great Plains Energy's $2.5 billion follow-on and convertible offering to support its purchase of Westar and Fortis' $2 billion investment grade offering for the purchase of ITC.

"
column82:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column83: which comprises both our FICC and equities businesses
column84:
net revenues were $3.7 billion in the third quarter up 2%compared to the second quarter. FICC client execution net revenues were $2 billion in the third quarter up 2% sequentially.

"
column85:
"

Credit increased and benefited from strong primary issuance and tighter spreads. Mortgage also increased and included better market-making conditions even tighter spreads. Rates was down slightly as client activity was driven by the continued discussion around potential Central Bank actions.

"
column86:
"

Currencies was essentially unchanged compared to the second quarter with lower client activity
column87: particularly post the Brexit vote and commodities declined during the quarter as activity remained light. In equities
column88: which includes equities client execution
column89: commissions and fees and security services
column90:
net revenues for the third quarter were $1.8 billion up 2% quarter-over-quarter.

"
column91:
"

Equities client execution net revenues of $678 million were up 16% sequentially
column92: reflecting better market-making conditions. Commissions and fees were $719 million
column93:
down 3% quarter-over-quarter. Security services generated net revenues of $387 million down 8% relative to the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column94:
"

Turning to risk
column95: average daily volume in the third quarter declined to $57 million
column96: down $5 million sequentially. Moving on to our investing and lending activities
column97: collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $1.4 billion in the third quarter. Equity securities generated net revenues of $920 million
column98: reflecting company-specific events
column99:
sale and gains in public equity investments.

"
column100:
"

Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $478 million and included approximately $275 million of net interest income. Investment management we reported third-quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion up 10% from the second quarter as incentive fees
column101:
management fees and transaction revenues all increased.

"
column102:
"

Assets under supervision increased $37 billion sequentially to a record $1.35 trillion. The increase was due to net market appreciation and net inflows. Long-term fee-based net inflows of $14 billion were primarily driven by fixed-income products.

"
column103:
"

Now let me turn to expenses
column104: year-to-date compensation and benefits expense
column105: which includes salaries
column106: bonuses
column107:
amortization of prior your equity awards and other items such as benefits declined by 13%. This was roughly in line with net revenues.

"
column108:
"

The 13% year-to-date decline results in a compensation to net revenues ratio of 41%. This is a hundred basis points lower in the funds accrual in the first half of this year. Third-quarter noncompetition expenses were $2.1 billion down slightly compared to the second quarter.

"
column109:
"

Now I would like to take you through a few key statistics. Total staff was approximately 34
column110:
900 roughly flat with the second quarter. Our effective tax rate for the year-to-date was 26.9%. Our global core liquid asset ended the third quarter at $214 billion and our balance sheet was $880 billion.

"
column111:
"

Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 14% using the standardized approach. It was 12.4% under the Basel 3 advanced approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 6.3%. In the quarter we repurchased 7.8 million shares for $1.3 billion.

"
column112:
"

In terms of capital
column113: our ratios have significantly strengthened over the last several years. This reflects the transformation of our balance sheet and our cumulative effort to de-risk the firm. All of these actions
column114: combined with more than $30 billion of earnings since 2011
column115:
position the firm to grow our capital ratios and simultaneously bring our basic share count to its lowest point ever.

"
column116:
"

Before I wrap up
column117: I want to cover three topics
column118: our client franchise
column119: expense initiatives and new opportunities. With respect to global client franchise
column120: it's in great shape. We have a strong position in each of our four segments
column121: investment banking
column122: institutional client services
column123:
investing in lending and investment management.

"
column124:
"

While many of our clients are currently challenged by the low growth environment
column125: we are committed to partnering with them and they look to navigate these headwinds. On expenses
column126:
last quarter we discussed the $700 million savings initiative that we undertook in the first half of the year and we continue to look at additional means of improving our efficiency without impacting our global client franchise.

"
column127:
"

Focusing on operating efficiency
column128: not only positions us for margin expansion in better environments
column129: but it also provides additional benefits. It allows the firm to maintain its global footprint and to continue to invest in the future
column130:
which is an essential component of sustainable value creation.

"
column131:
"

While there are currently economic headwinds in several countries globally
column132: our focus on efficiency across all of our businesses and regions allows the firm not only to maintain
column133: but also to invest in our client franchise through the cycle. Additionally
column134:
our expense discipline allows us to invest in new opportunities. Last week we launched a new online personal loan platform Marcus by Goldman Sachs.

"
column135:
"

Marcus' goal is to enter the consumer credit market and provide a product that is simple
column136: transparent
column137: flexible and provides consumers with real value. Like any new effort
column138:
we are taking a slow and methodical approach with Marcus. We are leveraging all the firm's pre-existing strengths across risk management and technology and we have brought an experienced team of consumer lending professionals to drive Marcus forward led by Harit Talwar.

"
column139:
"

Before taking your questions
column140: I would like to leave you with one thought. The firm is as focused on navigating today's environment
column141:
as we are on preparing for the future. You have to do the first really well to be in a position to do the latter. Thanks again for dialing in and I am happy to answer your questions.

"
column142:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"

Glenn Schorr

Your next question is from the line of Christian Bolu with Credit Suisse. Please go ahead.

"

Christian Bolu

Good morning Harvey.

So a question on your consumer lending efforts
column201: given the firm will be facing a very different demographic than you have historically faced
column202:
may we just talk about how you think about reputational risks and how you mitigate it?

"
column203:
"

Harvey Schwartz

column204:

Yes
column205:
so it's a great question. So I think the short answer is providing value to the consumer. So one of the reasons we have said so many times and this is going to be a very deliberate and methodical approach and a bit of crawl before we walk in this business is because we're well aware that this is a new effort for us.

"

column214:
"

But also

{"Goldman Sachs Group's (GS) Q4 2016 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (NYSE:GS)

column27:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column28: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This call is being recorded today
column34:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column35:
Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. And welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call.

column40: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column41: capital ratios
column42: risk-weighted assets
column43:

column45:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

I'll now pass the call over to our Chief Financial Officer
column47: Harvey Schwartz
column48: who is also joined by our Deputy CFO
column50:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column51:
"

Thanks Dane and thanks to everyone for dialing in. As many of you are aware
column52: Marty will be assuming my position in April. As you would expect
column53:
we\u2019re already working side by side to ensure a smooth transition in the coming months.

"
column55: Mary held positions of increasing responsibility in investment banking
column56: institutional client services and then most recently as our Chief Information Officer. During that time
column57: Marty established a track record of creating tremendous value for both our clients and our firm. Having worked closely with him for over a decade
column58:
I have full confidence that Marty will continue that track record as our Chief Financial Officer.

"
column59:
"

With that Marty would like to make a few comments.

"
column60:
"

Martin Chavez

"
column61:
"

Thanks Harvey. Just a few brief words from me. I have really enjoyed the opportunity to meet many of you in my prior role as CIO. I look forward to building upon existing relationships and building new ones in the months and years ahead. I have always found our conversations to be extremely insightful and valuable to effectively managing our firm. Goldman Sachs has a long tradition vigilantly focusing on risk management
column62: operational excellence and maintaining a conservative financial profile. In my new role
column63:
I have every intention of continuing that focus and tradition.

"
column64:
"

With that I will turn it back to Harvey.

"
column65:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column66:
"

Thanks Marty. Okay
column67:
now let\u2019s walk through the fourth quarter and full year results then Marty and I are happy to answer any questions.

"
column68:
"

Briefly on the fourth quarter; net revenues were $8.2 billion
column69: net earnings were $2.3 billion
column70:
earnings per diluted share were $5.08 and annualized return on common equity was 11.4%.

"
column71:
"

With respect to our annual results
column72: we had firm-wide net revenues of $30.6 billion
column73: net earnings of $7.4 billion
column74:
earnings per diluted share of $16.29 and a return on common equity of 9.4%. We grew book value per share by 6.7% year-over-year.

"
column75:
"

When reviewing 2016
column76:
it\u2019s helpful to contrast the performance between the first half of the year and the second half. The year began with a number of challenges but ultimately ended with a lot of positive momentum.

"
column77:
"

For example
column78: the start of the year which has historically been a period of high activity
column79: which instead impacted by significant concerns regarding the economic outlook
column80:
equity markets posted substantial declines and credit spreads wide and materially at the start of the year. This combination of factors translated into a difficult operating environment for our clients and by extension for our firm.

"
column81:
"

In the second quarter concerns regarding global economic growth moderated but other concerns including the potential implications of the Brexit vote surface. Ultimately
column82:
net revenues in the first half of the year declined by 28% year-over-year with a vast majority of that declining occurring in the first quarter.

"
column83:
"

Switching to the back half of the year
column84:
the global economic outlook improved reflecting solid economic reports particularly in the U.S. The prospect of diverging monitory policy and more pro-growth policies in the United States drove both activity levels and asset prices higher.

"
column85:
"

For example various fixed income market volumes in the second half of 2016 rose double digits year-over-year.

"
column86:
"

U.S. investment grade credit spreads tightened by nearly 40 basis points. U.S. high yield spreads tightened by over 150 basis points. And the MSCI World index climbs 6% during the period.

"
column87:
"

Ultimately this drove improved client sentiment and better environments. As a result
column88:
net revenues in the back half of the 2016 increased by nearly 16% year-over-year and included two consecutive quarter of 11 plus percent returns on equity.

"
column89:
"

In short
column90: we ended the year with positive momentum and a significantly improved operating environment. With that as a back ground
column91:
let\u2019s discuss the individual business using greater detail.

"
column92:
"

As it relates to the quarter
column93: investment banking produced net revenues $1.5 billion
column94: 3% lower than the third quarter. A pick up in M&A was more than offset by a decline in underwriting. For the full year investment banking net revenues were $6.3 billion
column95: down a 11% from 2015 and a decrease in equity underwriting and financial advisory revenues
column96:
which was partially by record debt underwriting revenues of $2.5 billion.

"
column97:
"

Our franchise remains very well positioned. We ended the year as a leader in global announced and completed M&A and as a leading equity and debt underwriter globally.

"
column98:
"

Breaking down the components of investment banking in the fourth quarter
column99: advisory revenues were $709 million. The 8% improvement relative to the third quarter reflects an increase in a number of completed M&A transactions. We advise on a number of significant transactions that closed during the fourth quarter including Procter & Gamble
column100:
$12.5 billion merger with beauty business into Coty. Fortis Inc\u2019s $11.8 billion acquisition of ITC Holdings Corp. And Rackspace Hosting\u2019s $4.3 billion sales were of Apollo.

"
column101:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the fourth quarter including Qualcomm\u2019s $47 billion acquisition of NXP Semiconductors
column102:
B/E Aerospace\u2019s $8.3 billion sales for Rockwell Collins and Capsugel\u2019s $5.5 billion sales for Lonza Group.

"
column103:
"

Moving to underwriting
column104:
net revenues were $777 million in the fourth quarter down 12% sequentially as debt and equity issuance slowed. Equity underwriting net revenues up $212 million were down 7% compared to the third quarter as follow-on offerings decreased.

"
column105:
"

Debt underwriting net revenues decreased 13% to $565 million from robust issuance levels in the third quarter. During the fourth quarter
column106: we actively supported our clients' financing needs
column107: participating in energies \u20ac4.6 billion IPO to Soros $1.6 billion high yield bond offering and it seems [indiscernible] $1.2 billion IPO. Our investment banking backlog improved from the third quarter
column108:
it was lower compared with very strong level at the end of 2015.

"
column109:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column110: which comprises both our FICC and equities businesses
column111:
net revenues were $3.6 billion in the fourth quarter down slightly compared to the third quarter. For the full year $14.5 billion of net revenues were down modestly compared to 2015.

"
column112:
"

FICC client execution net revenues were $2 billion in the fourth quarter
column113:
up slightly quarter-over-quarter as many businesses benefited from increased client activity. This more than offset typical year end seasonality.

"
column114:
"

Commodities increased significantly during the quarter as higher energy prices drove better market making conditions and more client activity. Currencies were higher compared to the third quarter increasing client activity. Rates were down slightly relative to the third quarter
column115:
client activity was solid driven by diverging monetary policies. Credit and mortgages decreased in an environment that included lesser issuance and generally tighter spreads.

"
column116:
"

For the full year
column117: FICC client execution net revenues were $7.6 billion. This translated into a 6% increase year-over-year excluding DVA gains from 2015 results
column118: given the difficult market conditions in the first quarter of 2016
column119: 6% growth particularly notable. In equities
column120: which include equities client execution
column121: commissions and fees and security services
column122: net revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.6 billion down 11% sequentially. Equities client execution net revenues were $459 million
column123:
down significantly across both derivatives and cash products.

"
column124:
"

Commissions and fees were $736 million
column125: up slightly relative to the third quarter as global client volumes increased modestly. Security services generated net revenues of $398 million
column126:
up modestly on a sequential basis

"
column127:
"

For the full year
column128: equities produce net revenues of $6.9 billion down 12% year-over-year. In 2016
column129:
we were impacted by less favorable market conditions and lower client activity and equities client execution. This compared to a relatively robust performance in the first half of 2015.

"
column130:
"

Turning to risk
column131:
average daily VaR in the fourth quarter was $61 million up from $57 million in the third quarter.

"
column132:
"

Moving on to our investing and lending activities
column133: collectively these businesses produced net revenues of $1.5 billion in the fourth quarter. Equity security generated net revenues of $1 billion
column134:
reflecting corporate performance as well as sales and gains in public equity investments.

"
column135:
"

Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $457 million which was largely driven by net interest income of roughly $300 million. For the full year
column136:
investing and lending generated net revenues of $4.1 billion driven by $2.6 billion in gains from equity securities and $1.5 billion of net revenues from debt securities and loans. Our net interest income within debt securities was more than $1 billion for the year.

"
column137:
"

In investment management
column138: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion. This is up 8% from the third quarter primarily as a result of $224 million in incentive fees largely from alternative investment products. For 2016
column139: investment management net revenues were $5.8 billion
column140:
down 7% year-over-year largely due to lower incentive fees. For the fourth quarter assets under supervision finished at a record $1.38 trillion.

"
column141:
"

The $32 billion increase versus the third quarter was driven by $17 billion of long term net inflows
column142: $31 billion of net inflows into liquidity products
column143: partially offset by $16 billion of market depreciation. On a full year basis
column144:
we had $42 billion of long term net inflows primarily driven by fixed income and $52 billion of liquidity product inflows.

"
column145:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense which includes salaries
column146: bonuses
column147:
amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits was down 8% for 2016 reflecting the decline in net revenues. This translated into compensation in net revenues ratio of 38.1%.

"
column148:
"

Fourth quarter non-competition expenses were $2.3 billion. The quarter included a $114 million donation to Goldman Sachs gives our donor advised charitable fund. For the full year non-compensation expenses were down significantly due to a decrease in provisions for litigation and regulatory matters. Excluding litigation provisions
column149:
non-competition expenses would have been down slightly year-over-year.

"
column150:
"

Now I'd like to take you through a few key statistics for the end of the year. Total staff was approximately 34
column152:
down slightly from the third quarter. Our effective tax rate for the year was 28.2%. Our global core liquid asset ended the fourth quarter at $226 billion and our balance sheet was $862 billion.

"
column153:
"

Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 14.5% using the standardized approach. It was 13.1% under the Basel III Advanced approach. Our supplementary leverage ratio finished at 6.4%. Our prudent approach to capital management is demonstrated by the strength of our capital ratios and had supported our return of excess capital to shareholders. In the fourth quarter
column154: we repurchased 7.6 million shares of common stock for $1.5 billion. For the full year
column155:
we repurchased $6.1 billion at an average purchase price of roughly $166 per share.

"
column156:
"

As a result
column157: we reduced our basic share count by approximately 27 million shares for the year reaching a new record low. In addition
column158: we paid out approximately $1.1 billion dollars of common dividends over the course of the year. In total
column159:
we returned $7.2 billion of capital to shareholders in 2016.

"
column160:
"

Before taking questions
column161: a few closing thoughts. As we've said many times before
column162:
we have a healthy respect for the dynamic nature of our industry and we have an established track record of being responsive to changes in operating environment.

"
column163:
"

As we discussed
column164: the first half of 2016 was challenging. In response
column165: we undertook and completed a $700 million expense initiative in the first half of the year. We continued those efforts in the second half of the year and ultimately generated nearly $900 million of run rate savings. When undertaking any expense initiative all about finding the right balance
column166:
you want to protect near term results without impacting long term prospects.

"
column167:
"

We believe we found the right balance in 2016. This can be seen in our ability to effectively serve our clients as activity picked up in the second half of the year. It also reflected in our continued investment in technology and infrastructure including our launch of Marcus.

"
column168:
"

Most importantly our expense discipline and the strength of our client relationships leaves as well positioned to deliver significant operating leverage to our shareholders in a better operating environment.

"
column169:
"

In summary
column170: we entered 2017 from a position of strength. We have a robust financial profile ending the year with $226 billion in liquidity more than a quarter of our balance sheet. All of our risk based capital ratios are well in excess of regulatory requirements well our share count sits at a record low. Importantly
column171:
this means we have the flexibility to navigate shifts in the operating environment including the positive scenario where we experienced a significant increase in client activity.

"
column172:
"

Finally
column173: our global franchise remains as strong as ever reflecting our commitment and investment to serve our clients. Meeting their core objectives
column174:
we\u2019ll continue to be the basis for our long term success.

"

Thank you again for dialing in. Marty and I are happy to answer your questions.

I think the bigger issue is how we want to run the company. And we\u2019re not thinking about changing how we run the company because where the share price is. We try to run the company in the best way for our clients and our shareholders and ultimately that translates to a higher share price.

column28:

Good morning. My name is Rachel
column29: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. After the speakers' remarks
column30: there will be a question-and-answer period. Also
column31: this call is being recorded today
column34:
2010. Thank you.

"
column36:

Thank you
column38: everyone. This is Dane Holmes
column39:
Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call.

"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The Firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column41: possibly materially
column42: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the Firm's future results
column43:
please see the description of risk factors in our current Annual Report on Form 10-K for fiscal year ended December 2009.

"
column44:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column45: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column46: capital ratios
column47: risk weighted assets and global core excess
column48: and you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures and the impact of Basel III that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website
column50:
"

column51: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column52:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column53:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column54:
David Viniar will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column55:
"

David Viniar

"
column56:
"

Thanks Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give a brief overview of our third quarter results and then take your questions. Third quarter net revenues were $8.9 billion. Net earnings were $1.9 billion and earnings per diluted share were $2.98. Our annualized return on common equity was 10.3%.

"
column57:
"

Our performance in the third quarter resulted in a year-to-date annualized return on common equity of 13.2%
column58:
excluding the impact of the U.K. bank payroll tax and SEC settlement. Our book value per share has grown 8% to $127.08 year-to-date.

"
column59:
"

Many of the market concerns that were most prevalent in the second quarter of 2010 continued into the third quarter
column60: with our client base remaining focused on the macroeconomic outlook
column61: particularly in the United States and Western Europe. Markets were also focused on the implications of global financial regulation
column62:
specifically implementation of Dodd-Frank Act and Basel III.

"
column63:
"

Consequently
column64: investment conviction among institutional asset managers remains low
column65: and while CEO confidence seems to be improving
column66: it remains fragile. These factors
column67: combined with the seasonal dynamics of the third quarter
column68:
negatively impacted activity levels within many of our businesses.

"
column69:
"

While we experienced modest improvement in activity levels in September
column70: third quarter activity levels for many of our businesses were at or below second quarter levels. For example
column71: NYSE
column72: NASDAQ and LSE average daily share volumes declined significantly compared with the second quarter
column73: down 27%
column75:
respectively.

"
column76:
"

On September 12
column77: the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision announced its capital framework generally referred to as Basel III. This announcement represented an important step in providing greater clarity on global regulatory capital requirements. Ultimately
column78: the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System will determine how the capital framework will be implemented for financial institutions in the United States. Understandably
column79:
our shareholders have been interested in how this development could impact our business.

"
column80:
"

While there are many aspects of Basel III that still require rule-writing and many rules that require significant guidance and interpretation
column81:
we wanted to provide our best estimate of our position on the Basel III with the caveat that these numbers and assumptions could and almost certainly will change.

"
column82:
"

At the end of the third quarter
column83: we had a Basel I
column84: Tier 1capital ratio of 15.7%
column85:
and a Tier 1 common ratio of 13%. We estimate that our current robust capitalization positions the firm to exceed requirements under the Basel III framework.

"
column86:
"

If we calculate Basel III requirements with actual second quarter numbers as of June 30
column88:
our estimated Tier 1 common ratio would be nearly 8.8% before considering any mitigating actions. This assumes risk-weighted assets of approximately $750 billion and Tier 1 common of approximately $59 billion. The principal drivers of the increase in total risk-weighted assets are higher credit risk-weighted assets for private equity investments in DVA and higher market risk-weighted rated assets for securitization and correlation risk exposures.

"
column89:
"

If we assume contractual roll off of our correlation portfolio
column90: expected duration of our mortgage securitization book
column91: coupled with 2.5 years of forward earnings at the 2010 consensus estimates
column92:
our Tier 1 common ratio would increase to 11% by the end of 2012. Of course there are many additional steps that we can and will take to further increase our capital ratios.

"
column93:
"

We also continue to maintain significant excess liquidity
column94: which average $173 billion during the third quarter. While we are awaiting more clarity on rules for the liquidity coverage ratio under Basel III
column95:
the concept is very similar to how we manage liquidity with our Global Core Excess and internal liquidity model. We estimate that our current Global Core Excess will comfortably exceed requirements under the new rule set.

"
column96:
"

Another area of investor focus has been the procedural concerns associated with foreclosure affidavits. In December 2007
column97: we acquired Litton Loan Servicing
column98: a subprime loan servicer. Litton is well known for providing borrowers with alternatives to foreclosure
column99:
particularly modifications.

"
column100:
"

Since 2008
column101: Litton has completed over 80
column102: 000 permanent loan modifications.  Additionally
column103: approximately one out of every four loans currently serviced has been modified.  In the states where the foreclosure process has been suspended Litton currently has approximately 23
column104: 000 loans in the foreclosure process.  Litton's initiated an extensive review of it's foreclosure procedures
column105:
while certain process issues are identified as part of the review to date Litton believes the underlying foreclosure decisions were warranted. I'll now review each of our businesses.

"
column106:
"

Investment banking produced revenues of $1.1 billion
column107: up 22% from the second quarter.  Third quarter advisor revenues were $496 million
column108: up 5% from the second quarter.  Goldman Sachs ranked first in the announced and completed M&A globally to date and advise \u2013 year to date and advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the third quarter.  These include GDF SUEZ's $21.5 billion transactions in international power
column109:
Intel $7.7 billion acquisition of McAfee and Dynegy's $4.7 billion sales for Blackstone.

"
column110:
"

We were also advisors in a number of significant completed transactions including Novartis's $28.4 billion acquisition of the stake in Alcon
column111:
Schlumberger's $11 billion acquisition of Smith International and Millipore's $7 billion sale for Merck. Third quarter underwriting net revenues were $623 million. Equity underwriting revenues are up 30% from the second quarter to $288 million driven by stronger client activity particularly in Asia.

"
column112:
"

Goldman Sachs ranked first year to date in common stock offerings globally. Debt underwriting was 50% to $355 million. This primary issuance is robust across both leverage finance and investment grade markets.

"
column113:
"

During the third quarter
column114: we participated in many note worthy underwriting transactions.  Including
column115: Agricultural Bank of China's $22.1 billion initial public offering
column116:
Impax Corporation $6.2 billion following offering and Valeant Pharmaceuticals combined $1.2 billion high-yield notes offering and $1.6 billion term loan.

"
column117:
"

Our investment banking backload was flat with the second quarter.

"
column118:
"

Let me now turn to trading in principle investments
column119: which is comprised of fixed equities and principles investments.  Net revenues were $6.4 billion in the third quarter and includes CVA losses of approximately $200 million associated with the tightening of credit spreads on our own debt mostly in debt.  [Sick net] revenues were $3.8 billion in the quarter
column120: down 14% from the second quarter.  During the third quarter continued macro-economic certainties acerbated seasonally slow customer activity levels and drove weaker sequential revenues across interest rates
column121:
mortgages and commodities.

"
column122:
"

Currency revenues were up modestly from the second quarter levels. Our credit business improved sequentially as a strong issuance calendar and technical support from solid flows into fixed income funds provided a favorable backdrop. Turning to equities
column123: net revenues from the third quarter were $1.9 billion
column124:
up 53% sequentially. Equities trading net revenues of $1.1 billion represented a significant improvement compared to the second quarter and reflected a more normalized contribution from our derivatives franchise.

"
column125:
"

Equities commissions were down 18% to $806 million reflecting lower client activity levels during the quarter. During to risk
column126: average daily value at risk in the third quarter was $121 million
column127: down 11% from the second quarter on lower volatility and continued low activity levels.  Let me now review principal investments which produced net revenues of $754 million in the third quarter.  Our principal investing portfolio generated net gains of $613 million
column128:
largely on corporate public equity investments. We also benefited from overrides of $132 million that were principally driven to $2.25 billion partial sale of the investment of ICBC during the quarter.

"
column129:
"

In asset management and security services we reported third quarter net revenues of $1.4 billion
column130: up 2% from the second quarter.  Asset management produced net revenues of $1 billion
column131: up 5% from the second quarter.  Asset management increased $21 billion sequentially to $823 billion
column132: driven largely by market appreciation
column133: partially offset by money market and equity outflows.  Security services produced net revenues of $383 million
column134:
down 4% from the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column135:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation benefits expense which is a reminder
column136: include
column137: salaries
column138: bonuses
column139: amortization of prior equity awards and other items was accrued at a compensation net revenues ration of 43%.  [Indiscernible] the first two quarters of 2010 and our lowest nine month ratio as a public company.  Third quarter non-compensation expenses decreased 24% sequentially
column140: $2.3 billion
column141:
primarily driven by the SEC settlement that was included in the second quarter results.

Total staff at the end of the third quarter was approximately $35
column143: up 45 from the second quarter
column144:
reflecting the normal seasonal pattern of new college and business school starting in the summer. In keeping with the firm's long-standing policy of repurchasing shares. The offset increased in share account over time resulting from employee share-based compensation. We repurchased 5.4 million shares of common stock during the third quarter for a total cost of approximately $800 million.

"
column145:
"

Even after the share repurchase common shareholders equity increased almost $2 billion during the quarter to $68.7 billion. The operating environment during the third quarter was denominated by heightened uncertainties surrounding the global economic outlook
column146: which contributed to lower activity levels across our global client base.  As you know our ability to generate revenues and return to our shareholders is dependent on our clients transacting in the market place
column147:
whether it\u2019s a CEO who wants to expand to an acquisition or a portfolio manager deciding to allocate capital to different investment strategies the opportunity for our firm begins with the client's decision to act.

"
column148:
"

While we've seen some modestly positive signs in recent weeks
column149: it's difficult to predict the catalyst for improved client activity especially since human psychology can be an important driver.  However
column150:
we believe that it's critical to remain focused on serving our clients and executing our strategy. We believe that these efforts will ultimately drive the strength of our franchise and the value that it can generate for investors over the longer term. With that I'd like to thank you again for listening today and I'm now happy to take your questions.

column824:

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column26: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Holmes
column29:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column30: Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call. Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial conditions may differ
column32:
from what is indicated in these forward-looking statements.

"
column33:
"

For a discussion of some of the risk factors that could affect the firm's future results
column34: please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our fiscal year ended December 2009. I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column35: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking
column36: transaction backlog
column38: risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com. This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column39: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column40:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column41:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column42: David Viniar
column43:
will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column45:
"

Thanks
column46: Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our fourth quarter and full year results and then take your questions. My remarks today will be focused on our new segment disclosure that was discussed in our Business Standards Committee report. The Business Standards Committee evaluated the firm's public financial disclosures with the objective of improving our standards of transparency and disclosure by more clearly explaining business activities and performance and how they relate to serving our clients. The committee recommended changing the firm's three previous business segments into the following four business segments: Investment Banking
column47: Institutional Client Services
column48: Investing and Lending and Investment Management. The composition of the new four segments is described in greater detail in our 8-K dated January 11
column50:
"

Full year and net revenues for 2010 were $39.2 billion. Net earnings were $8.4 billion
column51: and earnings per diluted share were $13.18. These results generated an adjusted return of common equity of 13.1%
column52: which is our reported return of common equity excluding the U.K. bank payroll tax
column53: the SEC settlement and the impairment of our New York Stock Exchange Designated Market Maker rights. If these items are included
column54: our return on common equity for 2010 was 11.5%. Over the past year
column55:
book value per share was up 10% to $128.72.

"
column56:
"

Fourth quarter net revenues were $8.6 billion. Net earnings were $2.4 billion and earnings per diluted share were $3.79. During 2010
column57:
market participants were faced with a series of broad macroeconomic concerns. European sovereign risk came under heightened scrutiny periodically during the year. Investors have also been intensely focused on the U.S. mortgage market regarding procedural concerns associated with home foreclosures and the potential for mortgage put back risk.

"
column58:
"

Throughout the year
column59: global financial regulation continued to be a concern
column60: specifically
column61: the implications of the Dodd-Frank Act and Basel III. Finally
column62: the trajectory of the global economy was heavily debated
column63: and there were growing fears about the potential for inflation in growth markets. The ultimate consequence of these concerns lead to greater risk aversions
column64: a deterioration and conviction among institutional investors and thus
column65:
a steady decline in client activity.

"
column66:
"

This reduction of client activity occurred across a broad set of businesses within Investment Banking and FICC and equities client execution. Despite the difficult economic backdrop and lower levels of client business
column67: the firm produced a solid 13% adjusted return on common equity
column68:
which is a testament to the strength and breadth of our client franchise and the commitment of our people.

"
column69:
"

I'll now review each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced fourth quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion
column70: up 30% from the third quarter due to significant increases in Financial Advisory and Equity Underwriting revenues. For the full year
column71: Investment Banking net revenues were $4.8 billion
column72: down 3% from 2009
column73: with a 9% improvement in Financial Advisory
column74:
partially mitigating an 11% decline in Underwriting.

"
column75:
"

Within Investment Banking
column76: fourth quarter Advisory revenues were $628 million
column77: up 26% from the third quarter. Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A globally for calendar 2010. We advised on a number of important transactions that closed in the fourth quarter
column78: including for Brookfield Asset Management
column79:
which led to $24 billion restructuring of general growth properties; E.On's $7.6 billion sale to PPL Corporation; and United Airlines' $6.5 billion merger with Continental Airlines. We're also adviser on a number of significant announced transactions including NSTAR's $17.5 billion merger of equals with Northeast Utilities; Earl Cully's $9.6 billion acquisition of Silvenate [ph] and Toronto-Dominion Bank's $6.3 billion acquisition of Chrysler Financial.

"
column80:
"

Fourth quarter Underwriting net revenues were $879 million
column81: up 33% sequentially. Equity Underwriting revenues of $555 million were up 79% from the third quarter
column82: reflecting a significant increase in IPO activity. Debt Underwriting decreased 7% to $324 million
column83:
reflecting lower activity in investment grade markets.

"
column84:
"

During the fourth quarter
column85: we participated in many noteworthy Underwriting transactions including AIA Group's $20.5 billion IPO
column86: Renault's $4.2 billion sale of a portion its equity stake in Volvo
column87:
and Hutchison Whampoa's $2 billion investment-grade issuance. Our Investment Banking backlog decreased compared with the end of the third quarter.

"
column88:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services
column89: which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column90: commissions and fees and Security Services. Net revenues were $3.6 billion in the fourth quarter. Net revenue generation within FICC and equities client execution declined significantly
column91:
as client activity leading into and through the holiday season was low and exacerbated by several macro concerns. Full year net revenues of $21.8 billion dollars for institutional client services were down 33% relative to 2009 on lower levels of client activity and tighter bid-offer spreads.

"
column92:
"

FICC client execution net revenues were $1.6 billion in the fourth quarter
column93: down 39% sequentially as client activity slowed meaningfully in the quarter. Credit and rates net revenues
column94: our most significant FICC client execution businesses
column95:
were down as macro uncertainties led to lower customer activity levels and weaker revenues. Currencies and mortgages net revenues were also lower sequentially.

"
column96:
"

Commodity net revenues were up amid more favorable market conditions. For the full year
column97:
FICC client execution net revenues of $13.7 billion were down 37% from 2009 as macro uncertainty throughout the year drove lower client activity and led to tighter bid-offer spreads.

"
column98:
"

Turning to Equities
column99: which includes Equities client execution
column100: commissions and fees and Security Services. Net revenues for the fourth quarter were $2 billion
column101: up 1% sequentially. Equities client execution revenues were down 10% to $772 million
column102: reflecting lower net revenues within our derivatives business. A slight improvement in market volumes and higher market values drove an 11% increase in commissions and fees. Security Services net revenues also increased sequentially by 7% to $368 million
column103: reflecting higher average customer balances. For the full year
column104: equities produced net revenues of $8.1 billion
column105:
down 25% from 2009 on lower market volumes in the U.S. and client activity levels across the franchise.

"
column106:
"

Turning to Risk. Average daily value at Risk in the fourth quarter was $120 million
column107:
roughly flat with the third quarter.

"
column108:
"

Let me now review Investing and Lending
column109: which produced net revenues of $2 billion in the fourth quarter. The firm is investing in lending activities across various asset classes
column110: primarily including debt securities and loans and equity securities
column111: including private equity and real estate
column112: are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through fund as well as lending activities. Our investment in ICBC produced a $55 million gain in the quarter. Other equity investments generated net revenues of $1.1 billion across both public and private equity investments
column113:
and benefited from the significant increase in the equity markets.

"
column114:
"

Net revenues from our debt
column115: investing and lending businesses were $537 million from interest income and tightening credit spreads throughout the quarter. Other revenues of $330 million were primarily produced by the firm's investment in consolidated investment entities. For the full year
column116: Investing and Lending generated net revenues of $7.5 billion dollars
column117: driven by $747 million in gains from our ICBC investment
column118: $2.7 billion in gains from our other equity investments
column119: $2.6 billion in revenue from our debt Investing and Lending businesses
column120:
and $1.5 billion from other investments. A significant increase in global equity markets and tighter credit spreads provided a favorable backdrop for our Investing and Lending businesses in 2010.

"
column121:
"

In Investment Management
column122: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion
column123: up 18% from the third quarter due to higher Assets Under Management and $310 million in incentive fees generated across the firm's alternative asset products. For the full year
column124: Investment Management net revenues were $5 billion
column125:
up 9% from 2009 due to a favorable change in the composition of assets managed and a significant increase in incentive fees.

"
column126:
"

During the fourth quarter
column127: assets under management grew $17 billion to $840 billion. The increase was driven by $5 billion of net inflows
column128: reflecting money market inflows
column129: as well as $12 billion in market appreciation. On a full-year basis
column130: asset under management declined by 4%
column131:
mainly reflecting industry-wide outflows in money market assets.

"
column132:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation benefits expense
column133: which includes salaries
column134: bonuses
column135: amortization of prior equity awards and other items such as benefits
column136: was down 5% to $15.4 billion. This translated into a compensation to net revenue ratio of 39.3%
column137: which is in excess of 600 basis points lower than our average compensation ratio between 2000 and 2009. When adjusted for the increase in headcount
column138:
compensation and benefits declined in line with the firm's overall revenue decline.

"
column139:
"

Fourth quarter non-compensation expenses were up 35% sequentially
column140: largely in depreciation
column141: amortization and other expenses. Depreciation and amortization increased significantly to $725 million
column142:
as the firm wrote down the value of our New York Stock Exchange Designated Market Maker rights by $305 million in the quarter.

"
column143:
"

The increase in other expenses is primarily related to a $320 million donation to Goldman Sachs Gives
column144: our donor-advised charitable fund. Compensation was reduced to fund this charitable contribution. As we discussed last year
column145: GS Gives provides senior employees with a firm-sponsored mechanism for recommending charitable contributions. This effort will continue to be focused on those areas that have been proven to be fundamental to creating jobs and economic growth
column146: building and stabilizing communities
column147:
honoring service and veterans and increasing educational opportunities.

"
column148:
"

For the full year
column149: non-compensation expenses were up 14%. In 2010
column150: non-compensation expenses included the $550 million SEC settlement and the $305 million impairment of our New York Stock Exchange Designated Market Maker rights. Total staffs at the end fourth quarter was approximately 35
column152: up 1% from the third quarter and up 10% versus year-end 2009. Our effective tax rate was 35.2% for the full year
column153: resulting in $4.5 billion in tax expense. As you know
column154: economic growth remains the key driver of our operating performance. As we have said in the past
column155: a strong and growing global economic environment usually translates into greater activity among our client base and ultimately drives our business. The operating environment in 2010 was dominated by heightened uncertainty surrounding the global economic outlook
column156:
which contributed to a steady decline in activity levels over the course of the year.

"
column157:
"

While economic activity has improved in recent weeks
column158: the seasonal nature of the fourth quarter
column159: combined with the continued uncertainty surrounding the outlook
column160: makes future activity levels difficult to predict. Longer-term
column161:
we remain optimistic about the opportunities that lie ahead for the firm. Our optimism is rooted in our belief that the firm will continue to expand with the growth of the global economy and the further development of the capital markets.

"
column162:
"

In addition
column163: clients' demand for our advise and execution capabilities remains unchanged. As always
column164:
our global client franchise is essential to our success. We believe our fundamental recommitment to our clients and the primacy of their interest coming out of the Business Standards Committee report will further strengthen our existing client relationships and serve as the foundation to build new ones. We also remain committed to expanding our global franchise and footprint.

"
column165:
"

Even in a difficult macroeconomic environment
column166: we've continued investing in our client franchise and in new market expansion. This commitment will enable the firm to continue its legacy of providing best in class service to our clients
column167: best in class return to our shareholders
column168: and attracting and retaining the best talent in a competitive global marketplace. With that
column169: I'd like to thank you again for listening today
column170:
and I'm now happy to take your questions.

that's -- is there an increase in competition from non-Chinese competitors in that business? And does that imply that there could be some margin reduction in that business over time?

column633:

No doubt that there's an increase in competition. And there's going to continue to be an increase in competition. I actually generally assume there will be an increase in competition in all of our businesses everywhere in the world
column634: all the time. We had a multi-year start on our presence in China

column682:

The larger question is
column683: I think what everybody's try to get at is
column684: has there been a lack of customer conviction in the last six months in the marketplace
column685: or has there been a structural change in the marketplace which has got nothing to do with invested conviction? And I would point to the commercial paper market for asset-backed securities
column686: which at the peak was $1.2 trillion in size and now is 1/3 that in size. It is unlikely to get back to $1.2 trillion
column687: because there isn't any major housing market out there. There isn't any major ferment in [ph] CDOs squared or CDOs cubed
column688: et cetera. So where in the structure of the financial sector
column689: as we see it
column690:
are there product lines that could in fact come back to replace what I would consider to be a structural decline in a market like that? And I'm applying that to all financial markets.

"
column691:
"

David Viniar

"
column693: there have been some structural changes in certain parts of the market. The real question is are they permanent? Are they temporary? I don't happen to believe most things are permanent. When you look over time at financial markets
column694: things get created. Sometimes they stay
column695: sometimes they get out of fashion and other things get created to replace them. There's going to be a housing market in the United States. In order to have a housing market in the United States
column696: you need mortgages and you need financing for those mortgages. That's not going to go away. Is it going to be the same type of securitizations that we saw in 2006 and 2007? Probably not for some period of time. I wouldn't say not forever but certainly
column697: not for some period of time. But is there going to be something to replace them to allow that market to go on? Yes
column698: there's going to be something. I don't know what's going to be yet. So it's a really tough question to answer. Some products that were in favor are now out of favor
column699: and are likely to stay out of favor for at least some period of time
column700:
but other products will be developed to replace them

David Trone - JMP Securities LLC

It goes back to this question that everybody's wondering about

column754: I think you indicated you'd be up this year
column755: assuming you budgeted for that. Yet historically
column756: when you've gone into these periods of weak activity
column757: you've seen the brokers cut back sometimes on headcount. So does this reflect your confidence

"
column763:

David Viniar

Two things I'd say

column769: we wouldn't be growing our headcount. We don't think that's going to happen. We think it was largely a seasonal fourth quarter event

column41: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call.  [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Holmes
column42:
you may begin your conference.

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes

Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our First Quarter Earnings Conference Call.

"
column52:

column53: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column55:
risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is pointed on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column57: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column58: reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent. Our Chief Financial Officer
column59: David Viniar
column60:
will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column61:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column62:
"

Thanks
column63: Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our first quarter results and then take your questions. I'm pleased to report solid first quarter results for the firm. Net revenues were $11.9 billion and net earnings were $2.7 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $1.56
column64: and our annualized return on common equity was 12.2%. Excluding the impact of a $1.6 billion preferred dividend associated with our repayment of the Berkshire Hathaway preferred stock
column65: earnings per diluted share were $4.38
column66:
and our annualized return to common equity was 14.5%.

"
column67:
"

In 2010
column68: many of our clients' strategic and investment decisions were burdened by fears about the global economic outlook. These concerns were focused on many considerations ranging from European sovereign risk to regulatory uncertainty to the potential for inflation in growth markets. Many of the issues facing the broader operating environment in 2010 continued into 2011
column69:
with political unrest in the Middle East and the tragedy in Japan adding to their list of concerns.

"
column70:
"

Despite these broad macro concerns
column71: we experienced increased client activity across many of our businesses within Institutional Client Services during the first quarter
column72: although volumes were still generally subdued. In part reflecting a typical seasonal upswing
column73:
we saw improved client activity in each of the major businesses within FICC client execution in addition to higher volumes across equities as reflected in equities client execution and commissions and fees.

"
column74:
"

Throughout the challenging operating environment in the past few years
column75:
our people have remained focused on helping our clients navigate complex problems and making difficult decisions. The increased activity that we experienced during the first quarter of 2011 reflects our continual investment in the firm's global client franchise.

"
column76:
"

Another driver of our performance in the first quarter was the increase in asset prices despite the uncertain macroeconomic backdrop
column77:
which contributed to greater quarterly revenues in our Investing and Lending segment.

"
column78:
"

On March 18
column79: we announced that we would redeem the 10% Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock held by Berkshire Hathaway. Following a 30-day notice period
column80:
we completed the full redemption yesterday.

"
column81:
"

The depth and breadth of our client franchise positioned the firm to generate solid first quarter results despite our conservative leverage profile and near record levels of liquidity
column82:
amidst continued global economic uncertainty. I'll now review each of our businesses.

"
column83:
"

Investment Banking produced first quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion
column84: down 16% from solid fourth quarter results. First quarter advisory revenues were $357 million
column85: down 43% from the fourth quarter. We advised on a number of important transactions to close in the first quarter
column86: including GDF Suez's $25.4 billion merger with International Power
column87: Allegheny Energy's $8.9 billion sale to FirstEnergy Corp. and Intel's $7.7 billion acquisition of McAfee. We're also adviser on a number of significant announced transactions
column88: including Reliance Industries' $9 billion sale of certain assets to BP
column89:
Beckman-Coulter's $6.8 billion sale to Danaher and Liberty Global's $5.5 billion acquisition of KBW.

"
column90:
"

First quarter Underwriting net revenues were $912 million
column91: up 4% sequentially. Equity underwriting revenues of $426 million were down 23% from the fourth quarter
column92: reflecting a decline in IPR activity from robust fourth quarter levels. Debt underwriting increased 50% to $486 million
column93:
reflecting higher activity across leveraged finance and investment grade markets and a reopening of the CMBS market.

"
column94:
"

During the first quarter
column95: we participated in many noteworthy underwriting transactions
column96: including Hutchinson Port Holdings' $5.5 billion IPO
column97:
Schaeffler's $2.5 billion sale of a portion of its equity stake in Continental and J.Crew's $1.9 billion combination bank debt and high yield notes offering. Goldman Sachs ranked first globally in equity and equity-related offerings year-to-date. Our Investment Banking backlog increased from year-end levels.

"
column98:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services
column99: which is comprised of FICC and Equities Client Execution
column100: Commissions and Fees and Securities Services. Net revenues were $6.6 billion in the first quarter. Our FICC and Equities client execution business improved significantly from fourth quarter levels
column101:
driven by a broad-based increase in client activity.

"
column102:
"

FICC client execution net revenues were $4.3 billion in the first quarter
column103: more than doubling sequentially as every major business generated higher revenues. This quarter results were quite balanced with a broad contribution across products and regions. Our Credit business benefited from higher origination activity
column104: particularly in high-yield markets. Mortgages produced solid results on improved volumes
column105: largely in our Non-Agency business. Our macro complex
column106: including rates
column107:
FX and commodities produced solid results as clients reacted to continued uncertainty in the macroeconomic outlook.

"
column108:
"

Turning to Equities
column109: which includes Equities Client Execution
column110: Commissions and Fees and Securities Services. Net revenues for the first quarter were $2.3 billion
column111: up 16% sequentially. Equities Client Execution revenues were up 27% to $979 million
column112: reflecting higher net revenues within our derivatives business. Commissions and Fees were $971 million
column113:
up 13% from the fourth quarter on higher market volumes. Securities Services net revenues of $372 million were roughly flat.

"
column114:
"

Turning to risk
column115: average daily value at risk for the first quarter was $113 million
column116:
down 6% relative to the fourth quarter. Lower equity and currency risk was partially offset by higher commodity risk.

"
column117:
"

Let me now review Investing and Lending
column118: which produced net revenues of $2.7 billion in the first quarter. The firm's investing and lending activities across various asset classes
column119: primarily including debt securities and loans and equities securities are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through funds
column120:
as well as lending activities.

"
column121:
"

Our investment in ICBC produced a $316 million gain in the quarter. Other equity investments generated net revenues of $1.1 billion across both public and private equity investment. Net revenues and debt securities and loans were $1 billion
column122:
generated from interest income and a favorable credit market. Other revenues of $311 million were primarily driven by the firm's investment in consolidated investment entities.

"
column123:
"

In Investment Management
column124: we reported first quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion
column125:
down 16% from the fourth quarter due to seasonally lower incentive fees. Management and other fees were consistent with the fourth quarter at $1 billion.

"
column126:
"

During the first quarter
column127:
assets under management remained unchanged. Outflows in money market and fixed income assets were offset by $12 billion of market appreciation.

"
column128:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column129: which includes salaries
column130: bonuses
column131: amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as payroll taxes and benefits was accrued at a compensation of net revenue ratio of 44%. First quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.6 billion. Depreciation and amortization expenses included impairment charges of approximately $220 million related to assets classified as held for sale during the first quarter
column132: primarily related for Litton Loan Servicing. Total staff at the end of the first quarter was approximately 35
column134:
down 1% from the end of 2010. Our effective tax rate was 32.3% for the first quarter.

"
column135:
"

In keeping with the firm's long-standing policy of repurchasing shares to offset increases in share count over time resulting from employee share-based compensation
column136:
we repurchased 9 million shares of common stock during the first quarter for a total cost of approximately $1.5 billion.

"
column137:
"

Many headwinds continued to exist for our global businesses
column138: particularly on the macroeconomic front. This leads to a natural ebb and flow of client activity. As a result
column139: the firm continues to operate in an uncertain environment over the near term. However
column140: we believe our ability to generate industry-leading returns for our shareholders remains intact. We remain committed to building and maintaining valued long-term relationships with our clients. We remain committed to managing our risk prudently and appropriately
column141: balancing risk/return decisions. We remain committed to creating long-term value through continued investments in our global footprint
column142: technology and operational infrastructure. And finally
column143:
we remain committed to recruiting and retaining individuals who embrace our culture of teamwork and client focus.

"
column144:
"

We understand the importance of these commitments not only to our shareholders but also to our clients
column145: our regulators
column146:
our employees and the public at large.

"
column147:
"

With that
column148: I'd to thank you again for listening today
column149:
and I'm now happy to take your questions.

column496: and they have the right to regulate their local jurisdictions and I think we and other financial institutions around the world are -- we've always lived with that
column497: and I think we're going to have to live with that. I think they're all trying hard to standardize the regulations as much as possible
column498: but I think it's unrealistic to think that there is just going to be one set for everybody around the world. And as I said
column500: and we're going to have to live with that going forward. But they're doing the best job they can. As far as when we're going to get complete clarity in the U.S.
column501:
I'm not sure. I know the regulators are working very hard at this and are trying again to do the best job they can. It's a very hard job. And so we're trying to be as helpful as we can. We're hopeful to get more clarity by the end of this year.

column70:
