Net revenues in the second quarter were $7.3 billion
column71: and net earnings were $1.1 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $1.85
column72:
and our annualized return on common equity was 6.1%.

"
column73:
"

Year-to-date
column74: excluding the impact of a $1.6 billion preferred dividend associated with our repayment of the Berkshire Hathaway preferred stock in the first quarter
column75: our annualized return on common equity was 10.2%. Including the impact
column76:
our annualized return on common equity was 8%.

"
column77:
"

The second quarter was dominated by concerns surrounding the state of the global economy. These concerns emanated from a variety of regions around the world including Europe
column78: the United States and China. While many of these concerns have been around for quite some time
column79:
the further deterioration in economic data coupled with the passage of time without resolution of the significant number of political issues has led to heightened concerns among market participants.

"
column80:
"

Sovereign risk in a number of smaller European member states increased with a particular focus on development increase. Concerns remain for other countries within Europe and the potential negative economic impact on financial institutions with credit exposure to these sovereigns.

"
column81:
"

Within the U.S.
column82: concerns have centered on the political debate on the raising the debt ceiling
column83: a growing budget deficit
column84: stubbornly high unemployment and potential further pressure on U.S. housing prices. Finally
column85:
there has also been greater focus on China given the important role it plays in the broader global economy.

"
column86:
"

The complexities surrounding the interplay of these various economic considerations has created tremendous uncertainty about the state of the world's economy and
column87: among other things
column88:
has resulted in limited conviction among market participants.

"
column89:
"

As a result of this uncertainty
column90: many of our investing clients have significantly reduced their risk appetite
column91: and thus
column92: activity levels generally declined. Despite these market uncertainties
column93:
we remain focused on serving the needs of our leading global client base.

"
column94:
"

Within Investment Banking
column95: we continue to focus on providing our clients with world-class strategic advice and superior financing execution
column96:
which is reflected in our Investment Banking league table standards.

"
column97:
"

Year-to-date
column98:
we ranked first in announced M&A globally. We're also ranked first in equity and equity-related common stock offerings and IPOs global year-to-date.

"
column99:
"

We understand that our clients value consistent high-quality service and excellent execution
column100: effectively meeting their needs for advice
column101: financing
column102: risk capital and liquidity
column103:
as well as asset management solutions essential to our long-term performance.

"
column104:
"

In the context of more difficult economic and financial conditions
column105: the firm launched an internal initiative to identify areas where we can operate more efficiently. Thus far
column106:
we've targeted approximately $1.2 billion in run rate compensation and non-compensation reductions. We're in the process of implementing the cost reduction efforts and expect to complete them before year end.

"
column107:
"

I'll now review each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced second quarter net revenues of $1.4 billion
column108: up 14% from first quarter results. Second quarter advisory revenues were $637 million
column109: up 78% from the first quarter
column110:
reflecting a number of significant deal closings.

"
column111:
"

We advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the quarter
column112: including Johnson & Johnson's $21.3 billion acquisition of Synthes
column113:
Skype's $8.5 billion sale to Microsoft and Diversity's $4.3 billion sale to Sealed Air Corporation.

"
column114:
"

We're also the adviser on a number of significant closed transactions
column115: including Pride International's $8.7 billion merger with ESCO
column116:
Beckman-Coulter's $6.8 billion sales to Danaher and Equinox Minerals' $7.7 billion sales to Barrick Gold.

"
column117:
"

Second quarter underwriting net revenues were $811 million
column118: down 11% sequentially. Equity underwriting revenues of $378 million were down 11% from the first quarter
column119: reflecting more challenging equity markets. Debt underwriting revenues decreased 11% to $433 million
column120: reflecting lower investing grade and CMBS issuance volume
column121:
partially offset by strong leveraged finance activity.

"
column122:
"

During the second quarter
column123: we participated in many noteworthy underwriting transactions
column124: including PRADA's $2.5 billion IPO
column125: Shanghai Pharmaceuticals' $2.1 billion IPO
column126:
and Wal-Mart's $5 billion long-term debt offering.

"
column127:
"

Our Investment Banking backlog was unchanged compared with the end of the first quarter.

"
column128:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column129: which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column130: commissions and fees and security services
column131: net revenues of $3.5 billion
column132:
were down 47% from the first quarter as continued macro concerns created more challenging market and operating conditions.

"
column133:
"

The effect of these macro concerns was more pronounced within our Asian and European FICC franchises
column134: which have historically been significant contributors to the global franchise. Further
column135: during the quarter
column136:
we were not as effective at navigating inter-quarter swing to the market prices and liquidity that we have been historically.

"
column137:
"

Consequently
column138: we generated lower revenues from managing client-originated market-making inventory
column139:
particularly in our largely U.S.-based mortgages business and our global commodities and credit businesses.

"
column140:
"

In this environment
column141:
we were particularly prudent in the management of our market risk. This is highlighted by the fact that VaR in the second quarter was in its lowest quarterly level since the third quarter of 2006.

"
column142:
"

FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.6 billion in the second quarter
column143: down significantly from the first quarter
column144:
as every major business generated lower but positive revenues.

"
column145:
"

Our commodities business was negatively impacted by asset price fluctuations. Credit experienced the more challenging environment for hedging and inventory management. Our mortgages results reflected the negative impact of asset price decline
column146: reduced market liquidity
column147: and greater divergence between our cash positions and corresponding hedges
column148:
particularly in non-agency products. Interest rates and FX were also down but to a lesser extent.

"
column149:
"

In equities
column150: which includes the equities client execution
column151: commissions and fees and securities services
column152: net revenues for the second quarter were $1.9 billion
column153:
down 17% sequentially.

"
column154:
"

Equities client execution revenues were down 36% to $623 million
column155:
reflecting lower net revenues within our cash and derivatives businesses as declining volumes and lower volatility impacted results.

"
column156:
"

Commissions and Fees were $861 million
column157:
down 11% from the first quarter on lower market volumes. Securities services net revenues of $432 million were 16% higher sequentially due to the seasonally stronger client activity.

"
column158:
"

Turning to risk. Average daily value of risk in the second quarter was $101 million
column159:
down 11% relative to the first quarter. Our value of risk remains at levels we have not experienced in a number of years.

"
column160:
"

Now I'll review Investing & Lending
column161: which produced net revenue of $1 billion in the second quarter. The firm's Investing & Lending activities across various asset classes
column162: primarily including debt securities and loan and equity securities
column163: are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through funds
column164:
as well as lending activities.

"
column165:
"

Our investment in ICBC produced a $176 million loss in the quarter. Other equity investments generated net revenues of $686 million across our portfolio of funded and direct investments.

"
column166:
"

Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $200 million
column167:
principally from interest income. Other revenues of $334 million were primarily driven by operating revenues from our consolidated investment entities.

"
column168:
"

In Investment Management
column169: we reported second quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion
column170:
consistent with first quarter results. Management and other fees were 3% higher sequentially at $1.1 billion.

"
column171:
"

During the second quarter
column172:
assets under management increased $4 billion to $844 billion due to market appreciation in fixed income assets.

"
column173:
"

Turning to expenses
column174: compensation and benefits expense
column175: which includes salaries
column176: bonuses
column177: amortization of prior year equity awards
column178: and other items such as payroll taxes and benefits
column179: has accrued at a compensation-to-net-revenue ratio of 44% for the second quarter of 2011
column180:
a ratio consistent with the compensation accrual in the first quarter.

"
column181:
"

Second quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.5 billion
column182: 6% lower than the first quarter
column183: which included impairment charges of approximately $220 million related to assets classified as held for sale
column184:
primarily related to Litton Loan Servicing.

"
column185:
"

Adjusting for the $220 million impairment charge and provisions for litigation
column186:
non-compensation expenses in the second quarter of 2011 were essentially unchanged.

"
column187:
"

Total staff at the end of the second quarter is approximately 35
column189:
relatively unchanged from the end of the first quarter. Our effective tax rate was 32.6% for the second quarter.

"
column190:
"

As a management team
column191: while we were disappointed in the performance of certain businesses this quarter
column192:
we're committed to creating long-term shareholder value. We believe that the core drivers of long-term value continue to be the strength of our global client franchise and our employees' tireless commitment to serving that franchise.

"
column193:
"

While the current environment presents a number of challenges
column194:
we continue to invest in expanding our global platform. Our effort to drive greater efficiencies within our operations are an important component supporting this growth plan.

"
column195:
"

We remain focused on generating superior returns for our shareholders. During the quarter
column196: we repurchased 10.8 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.5 billion. Furthermore
column197: our Board of Directors has authorized a 75 million share increase in our share repurchase program
column198:
bringing our total authorization to approximately 91 million shares.

"
column199:
"

In this ongoing challenging environment
column200:
we'll continue to balance near-term uncertainties with longer-term strategic goals. We will balance holding more capital and liquidity to protect against the current macro uncertainties with our commitment to providing strong relative return to our shareholders.

"
column201:
"

We'll invest for growth in attractive regions and businesses and reduce our commitment to businesses experiencing lower client demand. This adaptability is at the heart of our culture.

"
column202:
"

While the outlook remains uncertain
column203:
we'll continue to respond accordingly with the goal of positioning the firm to best serve our clients and shareholders.

"

"

With that

and I'm now happy to take your questions.

{"The Goldman Sachs Group Management Discusses Q3 2011 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

The Goldman Sachs Group (NYSE:GS)

Research Division

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column35: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to The Goldman Sachs Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also
column36: this call is being recorded today
column38: October 18
column39: 2011. Thank you. Mr. Holmes
column40:
you may begin your conference.

"
column41:
"

Dane Holmes

"
column42:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column43: Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column45:
from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements.

"
column46:
"

For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column47:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 2010.

"
column48:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column49: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column50: capital ratios
column51:
risk-weighted assets and global core excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column52:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column53: Inc.
column55:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column56:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column57: David Viniar
column58:
will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column59:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column60:
"

Thanks
column61:
Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our third quarter results and then take your questions.

"
column62:
"

Net revenues in the third quarter were $3.6 billion. Net earnings were negative $393 million
column63: and earnings per diluted share were negative $0.84. The third quarter continued to be dominated by concerns surrounding the weakened state of the global economy. The market was particularly focused on sovereign risk within the Eurozone
column64:
specifically the risk of contagion from smaller GDP countries like Greece to larger GDP countries.

"
column65:
"

Market participants are also focused on how heightened sovereign risk will impact the banking system within the Eurozone and beyond. The uncertainty surrounding the potential policy responses to these complex issues have amplified the level of concern among market participants. The price performance within European markets was a strong indicator of market fears
column66:
with the EURO STOXX 50 down 23% during the third quarter.

"
column67:
"

As would be expected
column68: the Eurozone concerned heightened worries regarding the implications of these challenges on economic prospects in the U.S. Similar to Europe
column69: equity and debt markets reflected increased fears about the U.S. economic outlook. The S&P 500 declined 14% and the VIX increased to its highest level in more than 2 years. Ultimately
column70: economic concerns within Europe and the U.S. permeated investor sentiment within growth markets as demonstrated by Hang Seng
column71: Bovespa and Shanghai composites
column72: posting quarterly declines of 21%
column74:
respectively.

"
column75:
"

Faced with a challenging global economic outlook
column76: CEO confidence and investor sentiment remained under pressure. Whether it was a volatile and unpredictable market that made new equity issuances very difficult to execute
column77: our asset management clients having much less conviction on investment decisions
column78:
the broader environment served as a significant headwind to clients moving forward with their business objectives.

"
column79:
"

As we've said in the past
column80: the firm's opportunity set begins with the client's decision to transact
column81: a decision which has historically been correlated to a growing economic environment. A growing economy is also correlated to increasing asset values and positive revenues from our Investing & Lending activities. Not surprisingly
column82: the macro challenges in the quarter drove lower levels of client activity in Investment Banking and certain FICC businesses and a significant decline in asset values within our Investing & Lending portfolio
column83:
resulting in a third quarter loss.

"
column84:
"

Despite the negative revenues in our Investing & Lending business this quarter
column85: we have a strong track record as an investor and our position to the product of long-term investment decisions. We entered into these positions with a focus on meeting our client's needs for financing
column86:
supporting key strategic relationships and generating long-term returns for our clients and shareholders.

"
column87:
"

The firm also has a full understanding of the fair value implications of these investment decisions
column88: and our third quarter results reflect falling asset prices and are unrealized. Given the significance in complexity of the economic issues facing governments and regulators
column89: we are
column90: of course
column91:
cautious about the near-term outlook for our business.

"
column92:
"

And while we are clearly disappointed about our third quarter results
column93: we remain optimistic about the medium- and long-term outlook for Goldman Sachs. Our global clients continue to place significant value on our services
column94: whether acting as a merger advisor or as a financial intermediary. We will continue to focus on serving our clients' needs and managing shareholders' capital prudently
column95:
a commitment which we believe is central to our long-term value proposition.

"
column96:
"

I'll now review each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced third quarter net revenues of $781 million
column97: down 46% from second quarter results. Third quarter Advisory revenues were $523 million
column98: down 18% from the second quarter
column99: reflecting an industry-wide slowdown in completed M&A transactions. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the third quarter
column100: including Petrohawk Energy Corp.'s $15.1 billion sale to BHP Billiton
column101:
Phadia AB's $3.5 billion sale to Thermo Fisher Scientific and GE Energy's $3.2 billion acquisition of Converteam Group.

"
column102:
"

We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the third quarter
column103: including Nalco Holdings' $8.1 billion merger with Ecolab
column104:
ING's EUR 2.7 billion sale of its Latin American insurance and pension operations to GRUPOSURA and Drogasil's $1.2 billion merger with Raia.

"
column105:
"

Third quarter Underwriting net revenues were $258 million
column106: down 68% sequentially as the more challenging market backdrop significantly reduced new issuance activity. Equity underwriting revenues of $90 million were down 76% from the second quarter
column107: reflecting lower volumes in a volatile and declining equity market. Debt underwriting revenues decreased 61% to $168 million
column108:
reflecting sharply lower leverage finance activity and more muted investment-grade issuance.

"
column109:
"

During the third quarter
column110: we participated in noteworthy underwriting transactions
column111: including ANZ Banking Group's $1.4 billion convertible preferred offering
column112:
Carlyle Group's $1 billion sale of a portion of its equity stake in China Pacific Insurance Company and Intel's $5 billion debt offering.

"
column113:
"

Our franchise remains strong
column114: as demonstrated by year-to-date global LEED table standings
column115: where we ranked first in announced M&A
column116:
equity and equity-related common stock offerings and IPOs. Our Investment Banking backlog increased compared with the end of the second quarter of 2011.

"
column117:
"

Turning to Institutional Client Services
column118: which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column119: commissions and fees and security services
column120:
net revenues of $4.1 billion were up 16% from the second quarter as activity levels improved in certain businesses despite the continued difficult operating environment.

"
column121:
"

FICC client execution net revenues were $1.7 billion in the third quarter
column122: up 8% from the second quarter. Our rates business increased sequentially as client flows improved in the midst of higher central bank activity and a more volatile interest rate environment. Commodities improved relative to a difficult second quarter as elevated volatility and macro uncertainty drove higher levels of business across all of our client segments. Foreign exchange revenues were down sequentially as volatility in certain markets proved difficult to navigate. Credit continued to be challenging as a lack of new issuance
column123:
wider spreads and a customer risk aversion created a difficult backdrop for hedging and inventory management.

"
column124:
"

Our mortgages results reflected significantly lower levels of client activity and the negative impact of asset price declines particularly in CMBS. In equities
column125: which includes equities client execution
column126: commissions and fees and security services
column127: net revenues for the third quarter were $2.3 billion
column128:
up 22% sequentially. Equities client execution revenues were up 45% to $903 million due to increased client activity in certain equity businesses and effective risk management of customer-driven positions in a more volatile environment.

"
column129:
"

Commissions and Fees were $1 billion
column130:
up 18% from the second quarter on higher market volumes. Security services net revenues of $409 million were down 5% from the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column131:
"

Turning to risk
column132: average daily value at risk in the third quarter was $102 million
column133: largely flat relative to the second quarter. Our quarter-end VaR was higher than the average
column134:
largely due to significantly greater volatility in interest rate products.

"
column135:
"

Now I'll review Investing & Lending
column136: which produced negative revenues $2.5 billion in the third quarter. The firm's Investing & Lending activities across various asset classes
column137: primarily including debt securities and loans and equity securities
column138:
are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through funds as well as lending activities.

"
column139:
"

The equity market indices such as the MSCI
column140: down 17%; ICBC
column141: down 35% and the high-yield CDX Index
column142: wider by more than 350 basis points
column143:
our longer-term investments posted significant mark-to-market losses for the third quarter. Our investment in ICBC produced a greater than $1 billion loss. Other equity investments generated a $1 billion loss across our portfolio fund and direct investments.

"
column144:
"

Losses from debt securities and loans were $907 million
column145:
primarily driven by wider spreads across our portfolio. Other revenues of $477 million consists primarily of operating revenues from our consolidated investment entities.

"
column146:
"

In Investment Management
column147: we reported third quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column148: down modestly from second quarter results. Management and other fees were 3% lower sequentially at $1 billion. During the third quarter
column149: assets under management decreased $23 billion to $821 billion
column150:
largely due to market depreciation in equities.

"
column151:
"

Turning to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column152: which include salaries
column153: bonuses
column154: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as payroll tax and benefits was accrued in a compensation to net revenue ratio of 44% for the third quarter of 2011
column155:
a ratio consistent with the compensation accruals of the first half of 2011.

"
column156:
"

Third quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.7 billion
column157: 11% higher than the second quarter
column158:
primarily due to higher brokerage clearing and exchange fees as a result of greater equity client volumes and approximately $100 million for the U.K. bank levy.

"
column159:
"

Total staff at the end of the third quarter was approximately 34
column161:
down 4% from the end of the second quarter. Our effective tax rate was 30.3% year-to-date.

"
column162:
"

Given the significant uncertainty regarding the prospects for the macroeconomic environment
column163: there is an understandable focus on the strength and stability of financial institutions. We
column164: like many other U.S. financial institutions
column165: took the lessons from 2008 to meaningfully improve our risk profile. We significantly reduced risk exposures while materially increasing our capital base
column166:
resulting in lower leverage and improved risk-adjusted capitalization.

"
column167:
"

Our strong capital levels have also positioned the firm to prudently manage our capitalization in the current environment
column168:
with the firm repurchasing 18.1 million shares for approximately $2.2 billion during the third quarter.

"
column169:
"

Liquidity is the lifeblood of any financial institution
column170: and given the challenged economic activity
column171:
our liquidity levels remain near historic highs.

"
column172:
"

We have also continued to take a prudent approach to our European region exposures. At the end of the third quarter
column173: our gross funded credit exposure to all sovereigns
column174: financial institutions and corporates in Portugal
column175: Ireland
column176: Italy
column177: Greece and Spain was $4.2 billion
column178:
which only includes the benefit of cash and U.S. Treasury collateral. Our exposure net of hedges was $2.5 billion.

"
column179:
"

Over the past 2 quarters
column180: the operating environment has been dominated by macroeconomic concerns which have translated into generally muted client activity and significant asset value declines in the third quarter. In the near term
column181:
several concerns need to be addressed to improve market sentiment and drive higher client activity levels across our franchise.

"
column182:
"

While we're as confident that the environment will eventually improve
column183: timing is uncertain. We're prepared to stand by our clients
column184: and we'll continue to address their challenges while providing best-in-class service. Ultimately
column185:
our ability to adjust and effectively respond to our clients' needs will drive long-term returns for our shareholders.

"
column186:
"

With that
column187: I'd like to thank you again for listening today
column188:
and I'm now happy to take your questions.

"
column189:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

Operator

David A. Viniar

David A. Viniar

Guy

column235:

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch

Research Division

And in terms of your interpretation of what you did see in the context of your Investing & Lending business

David A. Viniar

As far as we can see
column242: as you know
column243: we've already shut down our Waldorf proprietary business. So that's gone. We think that any investment in funds will be limited to 3%
column244: and other than that
column246:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column247:
Research Division

Fair enough. I have a final question on Basel III and your Basel III basis Tier 1 common target that you alluded to in the past of getting to around 11%. Obviously
column249: you have deployed a fair amount of capital through share buybacks

column254:

Guy
column257: let me just clarify. I don't think we ever said we were targeting 11% Basel III capital ratio. I think what we said was best calculation we could do right now looking out
column258: using consensus earnings estimates
column259: passive -- no active mitigation
column260: just letting things roll off

column263: I think that's higher than what our target would probably be. I think if we did that same calculation today
column264: which of course
column265: is not necessarily a meaningful calculation because most of these requirements are in effect in 2012
column266: the number would be closer to 10%
column267: given largely
column268: as you said
column269:
GDP down and earnings estimates down. But we still have round numbers best we can tell with all the caveats. It would be roughly 10% at the end of 2012.

"
column270:

column303:
"

Glenn Schorr - Nomura Securities Co. Ltd.

Research Division

Okay

David A. Viniar

column421:

column422: and the collateral that we're getting tends to be under agreements that were put in place when transactions were first entered into. Very difficult. When the environment gets stressed
column423: you go to a client and say
column424: \"We've changed our mind. Now we want collateral from you.\" So this is really part of our ongoing risk management. We make judgments about how much exposure we should take to individual counterparties but also to industries
column425: to regions
column426: to countries
column427:
et cetera. We set limits on those basis and we require collateral on those basis.

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column38: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs' Fourth Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also
column39: this call is being recorded today
column40: Wednesday
column41: January 18
column42: 2012. Thank you. Mr. Holmes
column45:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column46:
Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call.

"
column47:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that
column48: by their nature
column49: are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column50: possibly
column51: materially from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column52: please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for fiscal year ended December 2010. I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column53: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column55:
risk-weighted assets and global core excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column56:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column57: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column58:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column59:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column60: David Viniar
column61:
will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column62:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column63:
"

Thanks
column64:
Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our fourth quarter and full year results and then take your questions.

"
column65:
"

Full year net revenues for 2011 were $28.8 billion. Net earnings were $4.4 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $4.51
column66: and our return on common equity was 3.7%. Excluding the impact of a $1.6 billion preferred dividend associated with our repayment of the Berkshire Hathaway preferred stock
column67: earnings per diluted share were $7.46 and our return on common equity is 5.9%. Fourth quarter net revenues were $6 billion. Net earnings were $1 billion
column68:
and earnings per diluted share were $1.84.

"
column69:
"

Over the course of 2011
column70: the macroeconomic picture was clouded by several growing concerns. While the broader marketplace first began to evaluate the economic challenges facing the Euro zone in 2010
column71: the market's focus and concern accelerated meaningfully during 2011 and persists into 2012. The discussion evolved from largely a regional consideration into a significant global issue
column72: as market participants became increasingly worried about the secondary implications of a potential sovereign default. These underlying macroeconomic concerns have been exacerbated by growing skepticism regarding the willingness of the global political infrastructure to address the economic risk confronting the system
column73:
which was highlighted by the political debate within the United States on raising the debt ceiling.

"
column74:
"

In response to these dynamics
column75: market volatility increased significantly over the course of the year. While the S&P 500 ended 2011 essentially flat
column76: prices were volatile
column77: with the index's valuation ranging from up 8% in the spring to down nearly 13% in the fall. Not surprisingly
column78: the broader environment led our clients across a variety of businesses to be materially more risk averse. The firm's perspective on managing its risk exposures mirrored the sentiment of the broader market
column79: and consequently
column80: our risk exposures remained low in 2011. Ultimately
column81: macroeconomic concerns
column82: heightened market volatility
column83: lower corporate activity and decreased risk appetite among our institutional clients translated into fundamentally lower level of revenue opportunities over the course of the year
column84: hampering our returns. While we're disappointed in our results this year
column85: we remain firmly committed to supporting our client franchise
column86:
helping clients navigate the challenges ahead and managing our firm with a long-term orientation.

"
column87:
"

I'll now review each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced fourth quarter net revenues of $857 million
column88: up 10% from the third quarter
column89: primarily due to an increase in underwriting revenues following a weak third quarter. For the full year
column90: Investment Banking net revenues were $4.4 billion
column91: down 9% from 2010
column92: due to the more challenging macro backdrop. Within Investment Banking
column93: fourth quarter Advisory revenues were $470 million
column94:
down 10% from the third quarter.

"
column95:
"

Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced M&A globally for 2011. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the fourth quarter
column96: including Foster's $12.3 billion sale to SABMiller
column97: Global Crossing's $3.2 billion sale to Level 3 Communications and AGL Resources' $3.2 billion merger with Nicor. We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the fourth quarter
column98: including Entergy's $5.6 billion spinoff and subsequent merger of its electric transmission business with ITC Holdings
column99:
Statoil's $4.7 billion acquisition of Brigham Exploration Co. and Health Spring's $3.8 billion sale to Cigna.

"
column100:
"

Fourth quarter underwriting net revenues were $387 million
column101: up 50% sequentially
column102: as new issuance activity improved relative to a more challenging third quarter environment. Equity underwriting revenues of $191 million more than doubled from the third quarter
column103: reflecting higher volumes and improved market share. Goldman Sachs was ranked first in global equity and equity-related common stock offerings and IPOs for 2011. Net underwriting revenues increased 17% to $196 million
column104:
reflecting an improvement in high-yield issuance compared to a particularly difficult third quarter.

"
column105:
"

During the fourth quarter
column106: we participated in noteworthy underwriting transactions
column107: including Chow Tai Fook's $2 billion initial public offering
column108:
Michael Kors' $1.1 billion initial public offering and UPC's $1.25 billion combination high-yield notes and term loan offering. Our Investment Banking backlog decreased compared with the end of the third quarter but was higher than year-end 2010.

"
column109:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services
column110: which is comprised of FICC and Equities Client Execution
column111: Commissions and Fees and Securities services. Net revenues were $3.1 billion in the fourth quarter
column112: down 25% from the third quarter. Net revenue generation within FICC and Equities Client Execution declined as client activity was seasonally slower and macro concerns continue to weigh on sentiment. Full year net revenues of $17.3 billion for Institutional Client Services were down 21% relative to 2010
column113:
as a result of client risk aversion and difficult market-making conditions.

"
column114:
"

FICC Client Execution net revenues were $1.4 billion in the fourth quarter
column115: down 21% sequentially. Commodities and foreign exchange revenues increased relative to the third quarter
column116: although client activity levels within both businesses remained relatively muted. Our rates business decreased sequentially as macro trends remain in focus and client flows decreased into year end. Credit and mortgages remain challenging as activity levels declined across most products and a divergence between cash and derivative pricing impacted hedging and inventory management. For the full year
column117: FICC Client Execution net revenues of $9 billion were down 34% from 2010
column118:
as the challenging European backdrop led to reduced client risk taking.

"
column119:
"

In Equities
column120: which includes Equities Client Execution
column121: Commissions and Fees and Security Services
column122: net revenues for the fourth quarter were $1.7 billion
column123: down 27% sequentially. Equities Client Execution revenues were down 42% to $526 million due to decreased client activity
column124: particularly in derivative products. Commissions and Fees were $782 million
column125: down 23% from the third quarter on lower market volumes. Security services' net revenues of $385 million were down 6% sequentially given seasonally lower activity levels. For the full year
column126: Equities produced net revenues of $8.3 billion
column128:
"

Turning to Risk. Average daily value at Risk in the fourth quarter was $135 million
column129: higher than the third quarter
column130:
due to significantly greater volatility in the interest rate category.

"
column131:
"

Now I'll review Investing & Lending
column132: which produced revenues of $872 million in the fourth quarter. The firm's Investing & Lending activities across various asset classes
column133: primarily including debt securities and loans and equities -- and equity securities are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through funds as well as lending activities. Our investment in ICBC produced a $388 million gain in the quarter. Other equity investment generated a $384 million gain
column134: largely reflecting gains on public equity investments. Losses from debt securities and loans were $221 million
column135: driven by losses on relationship loans
column136: including the effect of hedges. Other revenues of $321 million consist primarily of operating revenues from our consolidated investment entities. For the full year
column137: Investing & Lending generated net revenues of $2.1 billion
column138: driven by $1.1 billion in gains from other equity investments and $1.4 billion of revenues from other investments
column139:
which was partially offset by $517 million in losses from ICBC investment.

"
column140:
"

In Investment Management
column141: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion
column142: up 3% from the third quarter
column143: as a result of $141 million in incentive fees generated from the firm's alternative asset products. Management and other fees were 3% lower sequentially at $1 billion. For the full year
column144: Investment Management net revenues were $5 billion
column145: relatively flat from 2010 levels. During the fourth quarter
column146: assets under management increased $7 billion to $828 billion
column147: largely due to market appreciation equities. On a full year basis
column148:
assets under management declined by 1%.

"
column149:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column150: which include salaries
column151: bonuses
column152: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column153: declined 21% to $12.2 billion for 2011 and translated into a compensation in net revenue ratio of approximately 42%. Within compensation and benefits expense
column154:
current year discretionary compensation declined significantly more than revenues.

"
column155:
"

Fourth quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.6 billion
column156: 5% lower than the third quarter. Brokerage clearing and exchange fees declined on lower equity client volumes. In addition
column157: we recognized the U.K. bank levy for the first 3 quarters of 2011 during the third quarter. These reductions were offset by approximately $170 million of impairments on consolidated investments within depreciation and amortization. We also made a $78 million donation to Goldman Sachs Gives
column158: our donor-advised charitable fund. Compensation was reduced to fund this contribution. This amount is in addition to prior year contributions made to Goldman Sachs Gives. For the full year
column159:
non-compensation expenses were essentially flat.

"
column160:
"

Total staff at year-end was approximately 33
column162: down 7% from year-end 2010. Our effective tax rate was 28% for 2011
column163: down from 30.3% for the first 9 months. The decrease in tax rate was primarily due to an increase in permanent benefits as a percentage of earnings and the mix of earnings. During the quarter
column164: we repurchased 9.2 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $908 million. For the full year
column165:
we repurchased 47 million shares for a total cost of approximately $6 billion.

"
column166:
"

The uncertain operating environment creates both challenges and opportunities for the firm. In the current environment
column167: the strength of our financial and competitive positioning provides protection against potential tail events
column168: as well as the flexibility to be proactive if opportunities arise. The challenges stemming from reduced market demand for risk capital requires a focused approach to our capital allocation process
column169:
and we continue to monitor the sizing of each of our businesses to ensure we're appropriately managing our resources.

"
column170:
"

The more muted operating environment has also intensified our focus on expenses. While it is not possible to cut expenses as a means to prosperity
column171: we understand the benefits of a proactive and disciplined approach
column172: particularly if the operating environment remains challenging. In the second quarter of 2011
column173: we launched an internal initiative to identify areas where we can operate more efficiently and originally targeted $1.2 billion in savings. We're currently targeting $1.4 billion in savings
column174:
and we'll closely monitor our expense run rate and make further adjustments as necessary.

"
column175:
"

The uncertainty facing the macroeconomic environment and reduced opportunity set for the financial services industry has increased the importance placed on franchise strength from the perspective of the depth and diversity of our firm's businesses as well as its relative competitive positioning. We believe our franchise is incredibly strong and growing
column176: particularly in its global scope. Our people remain a critical component in creating
column177:
maintaining and expanding our franchise and in our ability to create long-term shareholder value. The combination of our strong client franchise and our talented and dedicated global team favorably positions the firm to effectively navigate the current challenges.

"
column178:
"

Despite the difficult operating environment
column179: we believe that significant opportunities exist through the continued expansion of our global footprint and responding to shifting competitive dynamics stemming from reduced risk capacity in Europe. In the near term
column180: we remain committed to managing our capital expenses as efficiently as possible while maintaining our world-class franchise and our investment-critical initiatives. Over the longer term
column181: we remain committed to driving shareholder value by providing our institutional client base with unparalleled advice and execution
column182: coupled with the platform and the people to offer global
column183:
full-service solutions in an increasingly interconnected and complex world.

"
column184:
"

With that
column185: I'd like to thank you again for listening today
column186:
and I'm now happy to take your questions.

"
column187:
"

Research Division

So just to follow up on the comments that you made right at the end
column193: and I'm totally respectful of the need to maintain a very strong platform
column194: but clearly fit for you and for a lot of others is seeing a pretty sustained run of considerably lower revenue generation than when you put a lot of the infrastructure in place. And given some of the regulatory outlook
column195: lot of it
column196: granted
column197: is still uncertain
column198: but with Volcker and Basel III and everything coming in
column199:
I'm just wondering how you're thinking about balancing the infrastructure you have and where you might consider resizing.

"
column200:

David A. Viniar

"
column201:
"

Guy
column202: that's the -- that's one of the most critical questions and very difficult one to answer. We've all been doing this for a long time and we've seen downturns before. Every time you're in one
column203: it feels like it's never going end and that the world is different now. I wouldn't say
column204: for example
column205: that the environment feels worse than it felt in the fall of 2008 or necessarily after the tech bubble burst
column206: or necessarily after the fall of 1998. So is it cyclical? Is it secular? That's a very difficult question to answer. As you saw
column207: we try to be very disciplined on expenses. We cut headcount last year. We will continue to review the environment as we go forward. We'll continue to see where regulation openly comes out and what it will mean for the opportunities. And we'll try and balance exactly the things you said
column208: the strength of the franchise and the global opportunity set with the current environment
column209: and make sure we're sized appropriately. There's no scientific answer to it
column210:
though.

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column212:

Well
column218: again

Okay. So it's still something that we're considering. We're looking at the accounting treatment for just
column408: what I would call
column409: a portion of the relationship long commitments. As you mentioned
column410: it won't affect the current submission of CCAR at all
column411: but it is -- the consideration is being driven by the more owners capital treatment for the fact that the same assets held on mark-to-market versus a held-for-investment basis are different. I mean
column412: it's much more onerous for mark-to-market. So that's what driving even our consideration. You should know
column413: and I will use this word
column414: we are still fanatical believers in mark-to-market. Substantially
column415: all of our assets today are mark-to-market. Our risk is managed on a mark-to-market basis. And whatever we conclude on
column416: what I'll call
column417: a very small portion of assets
column418: just relationship lending
column419: those statements will still be true. Substantially
column420: all of our assets will be mark-to-market
column421:

column427:

column428: Howard
column431: a very hard question to answer. As you know
column432: the rule is written with 1
column433: 000 questions. So there's a lot that has to change before the rule is done. We want to make sure that the market-making rules are not written in such a way that they make it so onerous to -- for us
column434: and not just us
column436: to continue our market-making function and that liquidity in the markets dries up and it hurts the growth in the capital markets. It hurts overall growth. It hurts our clients. It hurts liquidity. It cost more to do business that the compliance regime is so onerous
column437:
and those costs have to be passed on. We just -- we want to make sure that nothing prevents free flow of capital and the growth of the U.S. capital markets.

you noted on the release that they were effectively minimal. What benefit did you get this quarter from some of the hedging that you said you did in the third quarter from -- on that exposure?

"
column828:
"

It largely didn't matter. Our spreads were pretty flat quarter-over-quarter. So with or without hedging
column829:
it was pretty much -- the whole amount was about $20 million. So it didn't really matter.

"
column831:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Mike Mayo with CLSA.

"
column832:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column834:
"

So you've had the best loan syndications in the industry
column836: in about a couple of decades. Is some of that activity reflecting a slot from the capital market to loans
column837:
or why are you seeing that?

"
column840:
I missed the beginning of what you said. We've had the best -- I didn't hear what you say is the best something in a few decades. I didn't hear what you said.

"
column841:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column843:
"

The best loan syndications in the industry in 2 decades. So my question is
column844:
are you seeing that in less fixed income or bond issuances or some of those bonds going to loans? Or do you have any color on that?

"
column846:
"

I'm sorry. I'm still confused. The best loan syndications in a couple of decades?

"
column847:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column850:
the loan syndication activity for the industry in 2011 was some of the highest you've seen in about 20 or 21 years.

"
column853:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column856:
are you seeing activity move from capital markets back to loans?

"
column859:
yes. I actually think that was largely structural. There was just a lot of cash available for loans. And so I think people took advantage of that. I don't necessarily think that's going to be a trend.

"
column860:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column862:
"

Okay. So you would expect -- no
column863: that's fine. Let me go to the capital question. Where are you leaning right now? Are you leaning toward having higher capital levels for a perception of greater stability of Goldman Sachs
column866:
let's buy back a lot more stocks because we're trading below book value?

"
column868:
"

You and I have talked a little bit about this before
column869: Mike. It's a very hard question
column870: and it's not a science. We sit here with our stock price where it is. And as I said to you
column871: I am relatively certain that at some point in the future
column872: we're going to wish we bought back a lot more stock at this price. Yet the flip side is it's a very tough environment
column874: we tend to be very conservative and want to hoard cash and hoard capital. And so we make the -- those 2 things you mentioned are offsetting thoughts that we have
column875:
and we just try and make the best decision we can in the environment.

"
column876:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column879: if you feel a teeny bit better about Europe
column880:
would that mean you'd lean a little bit more toward buybacks?

"
column882:
"

I should emphasize teeny in how much better I feel.

"
column883:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column886:
your revenue weakness recently. Are you saying none of that is due to secular factors? It's all cyclical. There's no structural changes that's hurting your revenues.

"
column888:
"

I never make -- I shouldn't use never. I don't like to use the word never. I don't make statements that bold
column889: and I couldn't say that. I think that we are clearly in a cyclical downturn. There is less activity. That is cyclical. That will come back. I have no idea when
column890: but it will come back. Over time
column891: there have always been secular changes in our business
column892: and I think we'll go through some secular changes now in how we deliver our services. I think the services that our clients want that -- you've heard us talk about this. The advice
column897: I think those services are still going to be the same services. I think there will be a cyclically higher demand for those services than there is now
column898:
and there might be some secular change in how those services have to be provided. And our job is to make sure that we're able to provide them in the way that we'll be able to and will be required going forward.

"
column899:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column901:
"

Let me try one last time. Your ROE target of 20%
column902: I know you don't have an ROE target now. Do you think you'll have one in the future
column903:
once you know what the capital rules are?

"
column907:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (USA) Inc.
column909:
"

And would the sole adjustment to that ROE target be based on the capital? So if you have to hold 1/4 more capital then your ROE would go from 20% down to 15%.

"
column912:
it would be a combination of changes in capital requirements and changes in what we view as the opportunity set going forward. So that's why I can't give you the number now.

"
column914:
"

Your next question is a follow-up from the line of Betsy Graseck with Morgan Stanley.

"
column918:
just a follow-up. You mentioned the sub-11% on 2013 for common Tier 1. What's your estimate for the 2012 year end?

"
column921:
I don't have that now. We'll get back to you on that as well.

"
column924:
"

Okay. Because I think in the past
column925:
you had said sub-10%. And just wondering if you're still there or not.

"
column927:
"

I'll come back to you. I don't think it's going to be far from that
column928:
but I'll come back to you.

"
column930:
"

Your next question is a follow-up question from the line of Roger Freeman with Barclays Capital.

"
column931:
"

Roger A. Freeman - Barclays Capital
column933:
"

Just a couple of quick ones. The repurchases
column934:
do you have any remaining authorization from last year that you can do in the first quarter?

"
column936:
"

Yes. We have a small amount remaining that we can do in the first quarter
column938:
"

Roger A. Freeman - Barclays Capital
column940:
"

Okay. And on the SIFI buffer. And I know it's not finalized yet
column941:
but do you have any reason -- is there any reason why you shouldn't expect 200 basis points for you?

"
column944:
we read in the paper that it was going to be 150 basis points. We don't know any more that than what we read in the paper.

"
column945:
"

Roger A. Freeman - Barclays Capital
column949: on VaR. The interest rate VaR
column951: that was up because volatility was up a lot. Did you actually -- did you reduce risk and interest rates
column952:
or did you increase for VaR just in the quarter?

"
column955: at the end of third quarter
column956:
I told everybody that you should expect our VaR to be higher in the fourth quarter because volatility was already up and our ending VaR was higher than it was in the third quarter. So we knew that this was going to happen because volatility was so much higher.

"
column959:
there are no further questions. Please proceed with any closing remarks.

"
column961:
"

I'd like to thank everybody for joining us for our fourth quarter earnings call. If you have any incremental questions
column962: please don't hesitate to contact us at Investor Relations. And otherwise
column963:
enjoy the rest of your day. Thanks. Bye.

"

this does conclude the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect.

column45: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs' First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Also
column46: this call is being recorded today
column47: Tuesday
column48: April 17
column50:
you may begin your conference.

"
column51:
"

Dane Holmes

"
column52:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column53:
Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call.

"
column54:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that by their nature
column55: are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column56: possibly materially
column57: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column58:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our fiscal year ended December 2011.

"
column59:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column60: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column61: capital ratios
column62:
risk-weighted assets and global core access. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column63:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column64: Inc.
column65: and may not be duplicated
column66: reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent. Our Chief Financial Officer
column67: David Viniar
column68:
will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column69:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column70:
"

Thanks
column71:
Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our first quarter results and then take your questions.

"
column72:
"

I'm pleased to report solid first quarter results for the firm. Net revenues were nearly $10 billion and net earnings were $2.1 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $3.92 and our annualized return on common equity was 12.2%. For Goldman Sachs
column73: our opportunity set begins with our clients. In the wake of the financial crisis
column74: our clients faced a series of challenges that accelerated in 2011. For both corporate and investment clients
column75:
shifting and often conflicting economic data created uncertainty about the outlook for the global economy.

"
column76:
"

Evolving clarity was complicated by the degree of interdependence among different regional economies. As would be expected
column77: these macroeconomic concerns were reflected in the global Capital Markets
column78: as market participants became increasingly concerned about the economic environment
column79: particularly related to the potential systemic risks presented in Europe. The situation was exacerbated by growing skepticism regarding the willingness of the global political infrastructure to address the economic risks confronting the system. These factors resulted in periods of unprecedented volatility asset values and bouts of prolonged illiquidity
column80:
often sparked by perception or conjecture rather than fundamental analysis or actual facts.

"
column81:
"

Ultimately
column82: economic uncertainty
column83: market volatility and systemic risk factors had a materially negative impact on market psychology in 2011. While macroeconomic challenges persist
column84: there have been some positive developments over the last few months. At the end of December
column85: the European Central Bank announced that it would enhance its long-term refinancing operation to provide term liquidity. By addressing potential funding risks
column86: the ECB materially reduced the markets concern that a systemic event could emanate from a European financial institution. In addition
column87: the market has seen steady progress in 2012 on resolving Greece's debt situation
column88:
providing greater comfort that there will be a difficult but organized approach to addressing sovereign issues within the euro area.

"
column89:
"

In response to these critical events
column90: Capital Markets rallied significantly in the first quarter of 2012. Credit markets improved materially
column91: experiencing tighter spreads
column92: higher activity levels
column93: increased new issuance and most importantly
column94: improved market liquidity. Global equity markets also rallied during the first quarter
column95: with the S&P 500 up 12%
column96: the FTSE up 14.2% and the Hang Seng up 11.5%. Volatility was materially lower as demonstrated by the VIX declining by 1/3. While there were positive developments
column97: announced M&A volumes remained light and equity volumes remain muted
column98:
reflecting the longer time required to improve CEO confidence and investor conviction.

"
column99:
"

Ultimately
column100: the more favorable operating environment
column101:
combined with the strength of our diverse global client franchise to create an improved opportunity set for Goldman Sachs in the first quarter of 2012.

"
column102:
"

I'll now review each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced first quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column103: up 35% from fourth quarter results. First quarter Advisory revenues were $489 million
column104: up 4% from the fourth quarter. Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced M&A globally for the year-to-date. We advice on a number of important transactions that closed in the first quarter
column105: including Hitachi Global Storage Technologies $4.8 billion sale to Western Digital Corporation
column106: Temple-Inland's $4.3 billion sale to International Paper
column107:
and Transatlantic Holdings $3.4 billion sale to Allegheny.

"
column108:
"

We're also advised on a number of significant announced transactions
column109: including TNT Express' EUR 5.2 billion sale to United Parcel Service
column110:
Tyco International's $4.9 billion merger of its flow control business with Pentair and Apaches $2.9 billion acquisition of Cordillera Energy Partners.

"
column111:
"

First quarter underwriting net revenues were $665 million
column112: up 72% sequentially. Equity underwriting revenues of $255 million were up 34% from a weak fourth quarter
column113: reflecting an increase in secondary offerings as IPO activity remained light. Debt underwriting more than doubled to $410 million reflecting higher industry-wide debt issuance. During the first quarter
column114: we participated in many noteworthy underwriting transactions
column115: including Priceline's $1 billion convertible offering
column116:
Seadrill's $1 billion secondary offering and Clear Channels $2.2 billion high-yield offering. Our Investment Banking backlog remained unchanged from year-end levels.

"
column117:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services
column118: which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column119: commissions and fees and securities services. Net revenues were $5.7 billion in the first quarter. Our FICC and equities client execution businesses produced significantly stronger results than during the fourth quarter
column120: driven by an overall improvement in market sentiment. FICC client execution net revenues were $3.5 billion in the first quarter
column121: improving significantly from a weak fourth quarter. This quarter's results reflected a broad contribution across our businesses and products. Our rates
column122: credit and mortgage businesses benefited from higher client activity levels following the LTRO
column123: the improved outlook for the U.S. economy and the orderly restructuring of Greece's debt. Our currency's business benefited from stronger performance in our emerging markets businesses. Commodity results reflected lower volatility levels
column124:
which drove fewer opportunities during the quarter.

"
column125:
"

Turning to equities
column126: which includes equities client execution
column127: commissions and fees and securities services. Net revenues for the first quarter were $2.3 billion
column128: up 33% sequentially. Equities client execution revenues doubled to $1.1 billion
column129: largely reflecting higher net revenues within our Derivatives businesses. Commissions and fees were $834 million
column130: up 7% from the fourth quarter on higher market values in Europe and Asia
column131: and higher volumes in options and futures. Securities services net revenues were $367 million
column132:
were down 5% sequentially.

"
column133:
"

Turning to risk. Averaged daily value at risk in the first quarter was $95 million
column134:
down 30% relative to the fourth quarter. Lower interest rate risk was driven by lower levels of volatility.

"
column135:
"

Let me now review Investing & Lending
column136: which produced net revenues of $1.9 billion in the first quarter. The firm's Investing & Lending activities across various asset classes
column137: primarily including debt securities and loans
column138: and equity securities are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through funds
column139: as well as lending activities. Our investment in ICBC produced $169 million in the quarter. Other equity investment generated net revenues of $891 million
column140: reflecting gains that were relatively balanced between public and private equity investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $585 million
column141:
largely driven by interest income and a more favorable credit market. Other revenues of $266 million were primarily driven by the firm's investment in consolidated investment entities.

"
column142:
"

In Investment Management
column143: we reported first quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column144: down 7% from the fourth quarter due to seasonally lower incentive fees. Management and other fees were consistent with the fourth quarter at $1 billion. During the first quarter
column145: assets under management decreased $4 billion to $824 billion. Outflows and money markets
column146: and to a lesser extent equity and alternative assets
column147:
were partially offset by $22 billion of market appreciation. Now let me turn to expenses.

"
column148:
"

In the second quarter of 2011
column149: we announced an initiative to reduce approximately $1.2 billion in run rate compensation and non-compensation expenses. We increased the program to $1.4 billion over the course of the year. We have largely implemented our announced expense reductions and continue to review means to further improve our operating efficiency. Compensation and benefits expense
column150: which includes salaries
column151: bonuses
column152: amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as payroll taxes and benefits was accrued at a compensation and net revenue ratio of 44%
column153: which is consistent with the firm's accrual in the first quarter of 2011. First quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.4 billion
column154: 8% lower than the fourth quarter reflecting reduced cost across a number of expense categories. Total staff at the end of the first quarter was approximately $32
column156:
down 3% from the end of 2011 and down 9% from the end of 2010. Our effective tax rate was 33.7% for the first quarter.

"
column157:
"

During the quarter
column158: we repurchased 3.3 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $362 million. These repurchases reflected the completion of our 2011 capital plan. Today
column159: we also announced an increase in our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.35 to $0.46 per share. While we expect share repurchases to continue to be the predominance of our capital management activity
column160: we have received shareholder feedback related to our dividend and therefore
column161: elected a modest increase. The first quarter brought several favorable developments in the operating environment for our businesses. We believe the probability of a tale event in the euro area has materially declined in the light of the LTRO. In addition
column162: the economy in the United States is showing signs of recovery. China
column163: while potentially slowing
column164:
still remains a strong economic growth engine.

"
column165:
"

Despite these improvements
column166: client sentiment remains fragile. In addition
column167: market developments in recent weeks including weaker U.S. economic data and wider spreads in certain peripheral European countries; remind us of the fragility of this economy. While debt financing markets are open and equity financing markets are improving
column168: M&A activity has not yet gained momentum. Volumes improved in certain fixed income markets
column169: but equity volumes remain under pressure and investor conviction is mixed. We believe in improving macroeconomic picture is the most significant driver of improved market psychology and a healthy
column170: stable Capital Markets over the medium term. In the near term
column171:
the current operating environment warrants a prudent approach to managing capital and liquidity levels and a continued focus on expense initiatives.

"
column172:
"

The last 3 years have brought a series of challenges for Goldman Sachs in the financial services industry
column173: as well as market participants more broadly. We're encouraged by the early signs of improvement in markets and the economy
column174:
but remain cautious given the complexity of risks and challenges. Everyone at Goldman Sachs remain steadfast in their commitment to serving our client franchise. We're keenly aware that the quality of our advice and execution in today's challenging market serves as the foundation for maintaining these long-term client relationships and ultimately meeting the needs of all of our stakeholders.

"
column175:
"

With that
column176: I'd like to thank you again for listening today
column177:
and now I'm happy to take your questions.

"
column178:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column179:
"

Operator

"
column180:
"

[Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from the line of Guy Moszkowski with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

"
column181:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column182:
Research Division

"
column183:
"

Let me just start with the expense initiatives that you alluded to. Obviously
column184: in the quarter
column185: as you also pointed out
column186: what you reported on the non-personnel side was -- indicated very strong cost management. You can look at some of those items and say
column187: well
column188: some of this is just discretionary spending being kind of stepped on temporarily in a -- in what's still kind of a weak revenue environment. On the other hand
column189:
you're telling us that you fully implemented your sizable cost-cutting plans. So I guess that's a roundabout way of asking for a little bit of guidance as to whether we should be straight-lining these levels of non-personnel costs.

"
column190:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column191:
"

Guy
column192: I'm always hesitant to give guidance on anything because things change. But I think that you can assume that most of those cost reductions
column193: many of which are related to people
column194: but non-comp expenses are attached to people
column195:
are in. And so I think that the numbers that you see are not a bad proxy. All other things being equal and no -- assuming no big changes in the environment for where things are going to run.

"
column196:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column197:
Research Division

"
column198:
"

Okay. That's helpful. I wanted to talk about the CCAR a little bit. Obviously
column199: your CCAR results highlighted something we've known for a while
column200: which is that your capital position is very strong. The shares have obviously rallied meaningfully in the first quarter
column201:
but they're still below tangible book. Maybe you can articulate your philosophy with respect to share buybacks relative to the share price and the degree of price sensitivity that you may show?

column202:

David A. Viniar

column203:
"

Well
column204: I'd always like to buy more when the stock price is lower
column205: and less when the stock price is higher. But I've never found myself to be a great predictor of our stock price. And so I'm not necessarily sure when the stock price is lower and when it's higher. We will -- we'll have a plan. We will moderate that plan

column207: as well as on the stock price. And we'll try to buy more at the lower stock price and less at the higher stock price
column208:
but I don't know for sure we\u2019ll be successful at that.

column209:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column210:
Research Division

"
column211:
"

And can you give us some sense of how to think about what authorization you may have received from the Fed as to how much you may buy back?

column212:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column213:
"

We didn't disclose it last year nor this year.

"
column214:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column215:
Research Division

"
column217:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column218:
"

I thought you would.

"
column219:

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column220:
Research Division

column221:
"

Can you tell us what your pro forma Basel III Tier 1 common and risk-weighted assets were?

"
column222:

David A. Viniar

"
column223:
"

I can tell you -- I can give you the ratio. I actually don't have it in front of me
column224: both the equity and risk-weighted assets. But with all the caveats of the rules not being done

column226: all of those
column227: those caveats take as a given. At the end of the quarter

column230: assuming just consensus estimates of earnings and passive roll-off suppositions
column231: so no active mitigation
column233:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column235:
"

Okay. Then final question for me is just about Investing & Lending. The outstanding levels of your I&L portfolios have been pretty constant. But going forward
column237: there's going to be limitations on the level of fund commitments and maybe some other limitations under Volcker. How should we think about the portfolio trajectories there
column238:
given some of these limitations and the expected runoff of your current portfolio holdings?

"
column239:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column240:
"

Look
column241: again
column242: hard to answer the question because the rules are far from final. But certainly
column243: some of our investments in hedge funds are going to come out. We've announced that publicly
column244: and our investments in equity funds are going to be limited to 3%. And so some of those -- some of the investments where we have a higher percentage will roll-off. And so in that way
column245: you could certainly see some of that portfolio come down. But until the rules are finalized
column246:
we don't know exactly where it's going to go.

"
column247:
"

Guy Moszkowski - BofA Merrill Lynch
column248:
Research Division

"
column249:
"

And just in terms of the potential capital relief as we see some runoff
column250: I think you've spoken to about $9 billion of capital held against that portfolio currently
column251:
is that still more or less right?

"
column255: that\u2019s the total capital held against that portfolio
column256: we don't expect that whole portfolio to go away
column257: so we don't expect all that capital to be released. And it's going to be dependent on the final rule set
column258:
how much happens and what the ultimate flows are.

"
column259:
"

Operator

"
column260:
"

Your next question comes from the line of Howard Chen with Cr\u00e9dit Suisse.

"
column261:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column263:
"

I was just hoping to get your latest thoughts on the competitive landscape in the sales and trading businesses. On one hand
column264: you've spoken about the exit of some competitors in big pockets of the business. Curious if you're seeing any improved share trends? And second
column265: on the flip side
column266:
are you seeing the competitive landscape heat up and any particular subclusters of thicker equities?

"
column267:
"

David A. Viniar

column523: give me more. It would be helpful

column528: the biggest thing that drives our risk appetite is our client flow. And what our clients are doing and how much they want to do and obviously
column530: we are likely to end up with more risk. They're not necessarily doing that much more because they are cautious as well. Second thing that drives our risk
column531: really
column532: is the traders on the lines view of their ability to analyze the situation. We talked a lot about this last year
column534: really
column535: what was driving markets last year was very largely political as opposed to economic. And so because we're good analysts and think we can try to evaluate the more likely economic outcomes
column536: and we're not always going to be right and we know that
column537: but at least we can analyze it in a situation where it's really politics and speeches and what people are saying more than economic outcomes that are driving the market. It's very hard for us to analyze risk and makes us extremely cautious about being left with any risk. Frankly
column538: it made our clients more cautious too and there was less activity
column539: so we saw all that last year. That's really the philosophy more than anything else. I think the YPF situation
column540:
I don't have much to say. I think it's an isolated incident in a certain location. I certainly don't think nor hope it's indicative of the rest of the world.

{"The Goldman Sachs Group Management Discusses Q2 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

The Goldman Sachs Group (NYSE:GS)

column43:
