Good morning. My name is Dennis
column44: and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Second Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. Also this call is being recorded today
column45: Tuesday
column46: July 17
column47: 2012. Thank you. Mr. Holmes
column48:
you may begin your conference.

"
column50:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column51: Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our second quarter earnings conference call. Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that
column52: by their nature
column53: are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column55: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column56:
please see description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our fiscal year ended December 2011.

"
column57:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column58: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column59: capital ratios
column60: risk-weighted assets and global core excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com. This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column61: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column62:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column63:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column64: David Viniar
column65:
will now review the firm's results. David?

"
column66:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column67:
"

Thanks
column68: Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our second quarter results
column69:
and then I'll take your questions.

"
column70:
"

Net revenues were $6.6 billion. Net earnings were nearly $1 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $1.78
column71: and our annualized return on common equity was 5.4%. Year-to-date
column72:
our annualized return on common equity was 8.8%.

"
column73:
"

Questions surrounding the stability of the global economy and its future prospects resurfaced in the second quarter. The situation in Europe remains a primary concern. Despite the systemic benefits of the European Central Bank's long-term refinancing operations
column74: the market refocused on the broader sovereign challenges that remain. In particular
column75:
client psychology suffered from continued skepticism regarding the mechanisms and political will required to address the complex series of issues facing European governments. The outlook for the global economy was further clouded by concerns about slowing economic conditions in the United States and China given weak economic data during the quarter.

"
column76:
"

The accumulation of these various macroeconomic concerns increased market uncertainty and reduced client activity. For example
column77: during the second quarter
column78: industry underwriting volumes declined significantly
column79: with debt and equity volumes down by 36% and 15%
column80: respectively. Market volumes also posted quarterly declines in various fixed income and equity products. While a challenging macro environment may translate into lower industry volumes
column81: our focus on our clients is unwavering as the advice
column82:
execution and Investment Management services that we provide to our global client franchise are more highly valued in a difficult environment.

"
column83:
"

The uncertainty has also led the firm to conservatively manage its risk profile
column84:
maintaining a high level of risk-adjusted capital and a significant liquidity cushion. We believe our continued focus on serving our global client franchise and managing our risk prudently is essential to the firm's ability to create shareholder value over the long term.

"
column85:
"

I'll now review each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced second quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column86: up 4% from first quarter results. Second quarter Advisory revenues were $469 million
column87: down 4% from the first quarter. Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A globally for the year-to-date. We advised on a number of important transactions that closed in the second quarter
column88: including Johnson & Johnson's $19.7 billion acquisition of Synthes
column89: Sara Lee's $7.2 billion spinoff of its international coffee and tea business and Austar United Communications' AUD $2.7 billion sale to Foxtel. We're also advisor on a number of significant announced transactions
column90: including Cooper Industries' $12.6 billion sale to Eaton
column91:
Walgreens' purchase of a 45% stake in Alliance Boots for $6.7 billion and Catalyst Health Solutions' $4.4 billion sale to SXC Health Solutions.

"
column92:
"

Second quarter underwriting net revenues were $734 million
column93: up 10% sequentially. Equity underwriting revenues of $239 million were down 6% from the first quarter
column94: reflecting weaker issuance activity. Debt underwriting increased 21% to $495 million
column95:
diverging from lower industry-wide issuance volumes due to our involvement in several significant transactions.

"
column96:
"

During the second quarter
column97: we participated in many noteworthy underwriting transactions
column98: including BTG Pactual's $1.7 billion IPO
column99:
IHS' $1 billion secondary offering and Chesapeake Energy's $4 billion bridge loan. Our Investment Banking backlog increased from the end of first quarter levels.

"
column100:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services
column101: which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column102: commissions and fees and securities services. Net revenues were $3.9 billion in the second quarter. Our FICC and equities client execution business produced significantly lower results relative to the first quarter
column103:
driven by macro concerns and weaker market sentiment.

"
column104:
"

FICC client execution net revenues were $2.2 billion in the second quarter
column105: down 37% from the first quarter as most businesses produced lower results. Our rates
column106: currencies
column107: credit and commodities businesses were negatively impacted by client risk aversion and lower volumes following more acute concerns about the situation in Europe and broader macroeconomic weakness. While volumes were also lower in mortgages
column108:
the business benefited from better asset price stability.

"
column109:
"

Turning to equities
column110: which includes equities client execution
column111: commissions and fees and securities services. Net revenues for the second quarter were $1.7 billion
column112: down 25% sequentially. Equities client execution revenues were 51% lower to $510 million
column113: reflecting higher levels of volatility and declining market volumes. Commissions and fees were $776 million
column114: down 7% from the first quarter on lower volumes. Securities services net revenues of $409 million were 11% higher sequentially due to seasonally stronger client activity. Turning to risk
column115: average daily value at risk in the second quarter was $92 million
column116:
down 3% relative to the first quarter.

"
column117:
"

Let me now review Investing & Lending
column118: which produced net revenues of $203 million in the second quarter. The firm's Investing & Lending activities across various asset classes
column119: primarily including debt securities and loans and equity securities
column120:
are included in this segment. These activities include both direct investing and investing through funds as well as lending activities.

"
column121:
"

Our investment in ICBC produced a loss of $194 million during the quarter. Other equity investments generated net losses of $112 million
column122: reflecting losses in public equities largely offset by gains in private equities. Net revenues from debt securities and loans included net interest income and net gains of $222 million. Other revenues of $287 million were primarily driven by the firm's investment in consolidated investment entities. In Investment Management
column123: we reported second quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion
column124: up 13% from the first quarter
column125: largely due to incentive fees related to the sale of our client's remaining investment in ICBC. Management and other fees were consistent with the first quarter at $1 billion. During the second quarter
column126:
assets under management increased $12 billion to $836 billion. Inflows and fixed income due to the acquisition of Dwight Asset Management were partially offset by $4 billion of market depreciation.

"
column127:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column128: which includes salaries
column129: bonuses
column130: amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items
column131: such as payroll taxes and benefits
column132: was accrued at a compensation to net revenue ratio of 44%
column133: which is consistent with the firm's accrual in the first quarter of 2012. Second quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.3 billion
column134: 4% lower than the first quarter
column135: reflecting reduced cost across a number of expense categories. Total staff at the end of the second quarter was approximately $32
column137:
relatively flat from the first quarter of 2012. Our year-to-date effective tax rate was 33.2%.

"
column138:
"

Many of the last several quarters presented challenging operating conditions
column139: with macroeconomic concerns taking center stage. As we've said many times
column140: our opportunity set begins with a client's decision to transact
column141: and the recent environment has damaged client sentiment and reduced overall activity levels. As a management team
column142: we recognize that we cannot control the macro environment. However
column143:
we remain committed to using all the appropriate levers available to us to improve returns without negatively impacting our client franchise or longer-term prospects.

"
column144:
"

We have a long history of adapting
column145: and we'll need to continue to allocate resources effectively to meet our clients' need to maximize returns. In a difficult operating environment
column146: we have 2 principal levers to enhance returns: expense and capital management. A year ago
column147:
we announced a $1.2 billion expense initiative. We subsequently increased the amount to $1.4 billion. We've met that target and continue to focus on improving operating efficiencies across the firm. We're currently targeting approximately $500 million in additional run rate cost savings to be achieved by year end.

"
column148:
"

During the quarter
column149: we repurchased 14.3 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.5 billion. We believe that we have sufficient flexibility to manage our capital levels appropriately for the remainder of the year. However
column150: the level of ongoing share repurchases will continue to be driven by our assessment of the risk to the broader operating environment
column151:
our earnings generation and the potential for more attractive opportunities to put our capital to work for clients.

"
column152:
"

In this environment
column153: we will continue to focus on helping our clients navigate the challenging market conditions. We will work to balance near-term uncertainties with longer-term strategic goals. We will invest for growth in attractive regions and businesses and reduce our commitment to businesses experiencing lower client demand. Doing this effectively is the key to protecting our global client franchise and thus
column154:
our ability to generate attractive long-term returns for our shareholders.

"
column155:
"

With that
column156: I'd like to thank you again for listening today. And now
column157:
I'm happy to take your questions

"
column158:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column159:
"

Operator

"
column160:
"

[Operator Instructions] Your first question is from the line of Howard Chen with Cr\u00e9dit Suisse.

"
column161:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column162:
Research Division

"
column163:
"

Just picking up where you left off the prepared comments
column164: with all that you're willing and trying to do to control expenses and capital management
column165:
we still have a 5% return on tangible equity. Just curious what else is in your mind and the partners' minds about getting back to kind of exceeding cost of capital and other than just waiting for a more vibrant macro environment?

"
column166:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column167:
"

Howard
column168: look
column169: I think you've heard me talk about this before. We're controlling the levers we can
column170: which are expenses and capital. We obviously don't want to go too far on either one
column171: because we think
column172: at some point
column173: the world will be -- will get better. But I think that all of those things will let us perform a little bit better in a tough environment. They're not -- we're not going to cut our way to prosperity
column174: and we're not going to cut our way to the appropriate levels of returns. And I think that we'll continue to do the best we can with our clients
column175: manage our expenses and manage our capital
column176:
but I would not expect that we're going to have acceptable ROEs in a macro environment like this.

"
column177:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column178:
Research Division

"
column179:
"

Understood. And then given the recent Fed
column180: 2.5 and Basel III NPRs
column181:
was just hoping you could give some thoughts on some of the Basel III guidance after you and the team incorporate some of these recent NPR rules.

"
column182:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column183:
"

Yes. What I would tell you is when we sit here today
column184: best estimate
column185: and these are still rough and all done manually
column186: if we looked at Basel III today
column187: it would be slightly below 8%. And if we roll forward
column188: and only just pure math add consensus estimate and largely
column189: the passive items like credit correlation
column190: mortgage securitization
column191: they're going to roll off
column192: by the end of 2013
column193: we'd get to slightly under 10%. And that's about 0.5% lower
column194: because of -- than we told you last time
column195:
because of some of those -- the new Federals and about 0.5% lower because of lower consensus estimates that have come out. So those are 2 things that have really changed since we spoke last.

"
column196:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column197:
Research Division

"
column198:
"

Great. And then finally for me
column199: $1.5 billion of share repurchase is pretty impressive this quarter. I think if -- I know there's a lot of variables in this. But if the stock does the same trajectory as it did last year
column200: i.e. it remains below tangible book
column201:
we saw you pick up share repurchase in the third quarter and then get a little quieter in the December quarter. Is that still a fair assumption to use? Or are there other things specific to this operating environment or valuation that we should be thinking about for this year?

"
column202:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column203:
"

I -- we can't give you a prediction. It's going to depend on a lot of things. And I -- again
column204: you've heard me talk about this before. It's a very big dilemma in an environment like this. We -- in an environment like this
column205: we are -- tend to be very cautious. We tend to conserve cash and conserve capital
column206: and yet
column207: we have a stock price trading well below tangible book. And I know when we look back in the future
column208: we're going to wish we'd bought back more at this price. And so it's a trade-off between caution in a difficult environment

I'm still struggling a little bit with the comp issue. I mean
column751: I think we've had this discussion
column752: but it's becoming more material now. I mean
column753: basically
column755: the capital that you have to have today more than has doubled. And I recognize we're kind of in a cyclically slow environment. But in the past
column756: you guys said
column757: \"Well
column759: relative to the peer group
column760: our ROT is better.\" So it justified like the comp ratio you were producing. But now
column761: your return on tangible equity is kind of in line or even below some of the peer group
column762: and you're still comping at like 44%. Now I recognize in the fourth quarter
column763: you tend to true that up so that the aggregate full year number tends to go in the lower 40s. But I mean
column764: at what point do you just recognize like that the business has changed because of the capital or maybe the revenue environment and that the new structural or normal comp ratio should be something materially lower
column765: like maybe in the 30s
column766:
so shareholders get appropriate return above their cost of capital?

column768:
"

Look
column770: I think it's a dangerous thing to compare comp ratios
column771: because you have a lot of very
column772: very differently structured firms. So I don't think you can compare comp ratio amongst firms. I think we're doing -- we're very cognizant of the returns that our shareholders get versus what our employees get. As you know
column773: the ratio itself has come down pretty meaningfully in the last several years. We'll see what it ends up being this year. We also live in a competitive environment. And we could cut comp very dramatically in one year
column774: and it would help our returns. But we live in a competitive environment. We still have people leaving for multiyear offers away from us
column775: some from our competitors
column776:
some from other industry participants. And so we try and balance those 2 things as best we can.

column777:

David A. Viniar

column792: you've heard me talk before about it

column794: some deals never get into backlog. Some deals that are in backlog don't get done. But I think it is an indication that we saw a little bit more activity in the first quarter
column795: and it was
column796: I'd say more M&A and debt focused than equity focused given how tough the equity markets were. And you're right
column797: we're seeing a small pickup in M&A volumes. We continue to see a very large number of discussions. I think some of that pickup are cross-border deals
column798: where people think that they can pick up assets cheap in various locations. But I think we're -- it's still a question of CEOs becoming more confident before we see a very big pickup in the merger business
column799: which is at historic lows. And so I think we're poised for that to happen
column800:
but it's not going to happen until CEOs become more confident.

column801:
"

Operator

Matthew H. Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

column810:

David A. Viniar

column811:

column817:
"

Matthew H. Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities
column820:
"

And then forgive me if you've already mentioned this
column821:

column823:
"

No. They're up a little bit up
column824: but they're still our gross exposure which
column826: is exposure only net of cash in U.S. Treasury collateral. But before any hedges
column827: it's still under $4 billion. And that after you take into account CDS hedging
column828: which are with banks outside of the country
column829:

"
column830:
"

Matthew H. Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

And then I guess within that
column834:
just one additional question on the commercial/high net worth business. Would there be loans that would be made in that business that would be included in the -- in future GIIPS exposures potentially? Or is it more focused on Asia?

column837: it would be there too. If we have clients in those areas

column840: maybe with collateral with very big haircuts
column841: we would certainly use the dollar funding capacity that we have possibly
column842:
because we have a lot of important clients in those regions for loans in those regions as well.

"

there are no further questions. I will now turn the call over to management for any closing remarks.

column1:
{"The Goldman Sachs Group Management Discusses Q3 2012 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

The Goldman Sachs Group (NYSE:GS)

"
column7:
"

David A. Viniar - Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President

"
column8:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz - Global Co-Head of The Securities Division and Member of Business Standards Committee

"
column10:
"

Glenn Schorr - Nomura Securities Co. Ltd.
column12:
"

Roger A. Freeman - Barclays Capital
column14:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column16:
"

Kian Abouhossein - JP Morgan Chase & Co
column20:
"

Michael Mayo - Credit Agricole Securities (NYSE:USA) Inc.
column22:
"

Brennan Hawken - UBS Investment Bank
column24:
"

Matthew H. Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities
column27:
"

Douglas Sipkin - Susquehanna Financial Group
column31:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column32:
and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Third Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call.

"
column34:
"

call is being recorded today
column36: October 16
column38:
you may begin your conference.

"
column39:
"

Dane Holmes

"
column40:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column41:
Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call.

"
column42:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that
column44: are uncertain and outside of the firm's control. The firm's actual results and financial condition may differ
column45: possibly materially
column46: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For a discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm's future results
column47:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our fiscal year ended December 2011.

"
column48:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column50:
risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column51:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column52: Inc.
column53: and may not be duplicated
column54:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column55:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column56: David Viniar
column57:
will now review the firm's results with Harvey Schwartz who will assume David's role at the end of January. David?

"
column58:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column59:
"

Thanks
column60:
Dane. I'd like to thank all of you for listening today. I'll give an overview of our third quarter results and Harvey will review our business performance.

"
column61:
"

Net revenues were $8.4 billion and net earnings were $1.5 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $2.85 and our annualized return on common equity was 8.6%. Year-to-date
column62:
our annualized return on common equity was 8.8%.

"
column63:
"

The third quarter operating environment included continuing concerns about the outlook for the global economy
column64: particularly as it relates to the situation in Europe. The uncertainty surrounding economic prospects has weighed on the psychology of corporate leaders and investors
column65:
negatively impacting the current operating environment in 2 principal ways.

"
column66:
"

Corporate client activity continued to be relatively weak in the third quarter. Industrywide
column67: announced M&A volumes declined 16% sequentially and IPO volumes were nearly cut in half. In addition
column68: New York Stock Exchange volumes were down 13% sequentially
column69:
while LSC volumes were down 23%.

"
column70:
"

An additional impact of economic uncertainty and weak investor conviction is the tendency for investors to transact in the most liquid and commoditized portion of the market. This dynamic is evident within both the FICC and equities franchises
column71:
as demonstrated by the significance of index product volumes in credit and equities.

"
column72:
"

Although client activity remains muted
column73: there were some favorable developments during the third quarter. The United States Federal Reserve announced a further increase in monetary stimulus
column74:
and the ECB stated that it would support the euro and was prepared to make outright purchases in the secondary bond market to address severe distortion in government bond markets.

"
column75:
"

Since the ECB's pronouncements
column76: Spain and Italy's 5-year CDS spreads have each tightened by over 200 basis points
column77: reflecting the market's diminished view that a tail event will emanate out of Europe. While these positive developments have created some optimism in the marketplace
column78: we as a management team remained focused on guiding the firm through a continued difficult operating environment. We are serving our leading client franchise
column79:
managing our risk profile prudently and being disciplined about capital usage and operating expenses.

"
column80:
"

Harvey will now review each of our businesses. Harvey?

"
column81:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column82:
"

Thanks
column83:
David.

"
column84:
"

Investment Banking produced third quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column85: down 3% from second quarter results. Third quarter advisory revenues were $509 million
column86: up 9% from the second quarter. Year-to-date
column87: Goldman Sachs ranked first in announced and completed M&A globally. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the third quarter
column88: including Amylin Pharmaceuticals' $7 billion sale to Bristol-Myers Squibb; NDS group's $5 billion sale to Cisco; and CGI Group's $3.2 billion acquisition of Logica. We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the third quarter
column89: including Nexen's $19 billion sale to CNOOC; Amerigroup's $4.9 billion sale to WellPoint; and Fraser & Neave's $4.5 billion sale
column90: with interest in Asia Pacific Breweries
column91:
to Heineken.

"
column92:
"

Third quarter underwriting net revenues were $655 million
column93: down 11% sequentially. Equity underwriting revenues of $189 million were down 21% from the second quarter
column94: reflecting weaker IPO activity. Year-to-date
column95:
Goldman Sachs was ranked first in global equity and equity-related and common stock offerings. Debt underwriting revenues decreased 6% to $466 million.

"
column96:
"

During the quarter
column97: we participated in many noteworthy underwriting transactions
column98:
including Whole Logic's $3.5 billion combination term loan and high-yield notes offering; Dollar General's $2.1 billion follow-on offering; and Seadrill's $1 billion high-yield note offering. Our Investment Banking backlog decreased slightly from the end of the second quarter levels but remains higher than the end of 2011.

"
column99:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column100: commissions and fees
column101:
as well as security services. Net revenues were $4.2 billion in the third quarter.

"
column102:
"

FICC Client Execution net revenues were $2.2 billion in the third quarter and included a DVA loss of $225 million. Excluding the impact of DVA
column103:
revenues were up 11% sequentially. Our rates business benefited from improved client risk appetite related to central bank activity during the quarter. Mortgages was aided by improving housing fundamentals and strong customer demand. Credit results reflected solid client activity levels. Commodities and currencies were both negatively impacted by continued low levels of volatility and volumes.

"
column104:
"

Turning to Equities which includes equities client execution
column105: commissions and fees and securities services. Net revenues for the third quarter were $2 billion and included $145 million in DVA losses. Excluding the impact of DVA
column106:
revenues were up 26% sequentially.

"
column107:
"

Equities client execution revenues increased 66% sequentially to $847 million
column108: reflecting a more benign market-making environment. Commissions and fees were $721 million
column109:
down 7% from second quarter on lower volumes. Securities services net revenues of $392 million were down 4% from the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column110:
"

Turning to risk. Average daily value at risk in the third quarter was $81 million
column111:
down 12% relative to the second quarter.

"
column112:
"

Let me now review Investing & Lending
column113: which produced net revenues of $1.8 billion in the third quarter. Our investment in ICBC produced a gain of $99 million in the quarter. Other equity investments generated net revenues of $824 million
column114: reflecting gains that were primarily driven by private equity investments. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $558 million
column115: largely driven by a more favorable credit market
column116:
with tightening credit spreads and interest income. Other revenues of $323 million were primarily driven by the firm's investment in consolidated investment entities.

"
column117:
"

Switching to Investment Management. We reported third quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column118: down 10% sequentially as the firm booked onetime incentive fees related to the sale of our client's remaining investment in ICBC in the second quarter. Management and other fees were consistent with the second quarter at $1 billion. During the third quarter
column119:
assets under management increased $20 billion to $856 billion due to market appreciation.

"
column120:
"

Now moving on to our expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column121: which includes salaries
column122: bonuses
column123: amortization of prior year equity awards and other items such as payroll taxes and benefits
column124:
was accrued at a compensation-to-net revenues ratio of 44%. This is consistent with the firm's accrual for the first half of 2012.

"
column125:
"

Third quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.4 billion. We continue to be focused on our cost-saving initiatives
column126: and year-to-date
column127:
our non-compensation expenses are running 10% lower than the first 3 quarters of 2011.

"
column128:
"

Total staff at the end of the third quarter was approximately 32
column130:
relatively flat with the second quarter of 2012.

"
column131:
"

Our year-to-date effective tax rate was 33.5%.

"
column132:
"

During the quarter
column133: we repurchased 11.8 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.25 billion. Today
column134:
we also announced an increase in our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.46 to $0.50 per share.

"
column135:
"

Now let me turn it back to David to make some concluding remarks.

"
column136:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column137:
"

Thanks
column138:
Harvey.

"
column139:
"

As a management team
column140: we are keenly aware of the fact that we cannot control the broader economic environment in which we operate. As we've said many times in the past
column141: the firm will perform at its best and our shareholders will benefit to the greatest degree when we're in a more robust economic environment. However
column142:
a difficult operating environment does not absolve us from our responsibility to manage everything that is within our control to create best-in-class returns over the long term.

"
column143:
"

We must be disciplined in managing both our operating expenses and capital levels. As it relates to operating expenses
column144: we have to balance lowering costs and maintaining high levels of client service. In the second quarter of 2011
column145: we announced a $1.2 billion expense reduction initiative. Since that initial announcement
column146: we've increased the target expense savings by nearly 60% to $1.9 billion. We believe that we've been able to undertake these initiatives without materially impacting our client franchise. And as a consequence
column147:
we should be well positioned to create operating leverage in an improved economic environment.

"
column148:
"

Regarding capital management
column149: we've been extremely focused on balancing the competing objectives of returning excess capital to shareholders with the prudence associated with maintaining conservative risk-adjusted capitalization in a difficult operating environment with undefined capital rules. Since the onset of the financial crisis
column150: our risk-based capital measures have remained at or near the top of the industry. While Basel III capital rules are not finalized and will not be fully phased-in for many years
column151: our best estimate from what we know today is that
column152: at the end of the third quarter
column153:
our Basel III Tier 1 common ratio would be approximately 8.5%. We expect that we will ultimately operate with a capital cushion in the proximity of 100 basis points versus our regulatory requirement.

"
column154:
"

We've remained committed to maintaining a conservative financial profile and have a deep appreciation for the strategic benefits
column155: both opportunistically and defensively
column156: that come with maintaining robust capital levels. While not wavering from that view
column157: we've been able to repurchase $9.1 billion of common stock since the beginning of 2011 and have reduced our basic share count by 11%. As Basel III rules have started to be finalized and we are closer to implementation
column158: we've begun to focus on optimizing our balance sheet in preparation for these changes. We've previously announced that we expected $88 billion of risk-weighted assets to passively roll off by 2015
column159:
and we have begun to roll out the necessary tools to facilitate a more active approach to mitigating risk-weighted assets.

"
column160:
"

We're committed to managing our operations
column161: with a focus on serving our clients effectively. As a result
column162: we manage our expenses and capital
column163: with the understanding that our shareholders have invested in this franchise
column164:
with the expectation that we will outperform over the long term.

"
column165:
"

With that
column166: we'd like to thank you again for listening today. And now
column167:
Harvey and I are happy to take your questions.

column581: we've been big supporters of clearing. We think it's fundamental to systemic risk reduction. So we've been big proponents
column582: moving clearing forward as quickly as possible. And against that backdrop
column583: we've been building and developing in our business the ability to provide client clearing and the tools and technology and appropriate staff. I'd say that it's probably too early to tell ultimately where we come out with pricing. Like a lot of things
column584: I think there'll be a fair degree of early competition. But we're really in the early innings of this so we'll have to see how the revenue model evolves. But I think the biggest issue is that it fundamentally makes the system safer. And I think -- over time
column585: again difficult to speculate
column586: I think -- as we get clarity around regulatory reform
column587: I think all of these pieces
column588: as they come together
column589: could contribute to greater volumes. So again
column590:
difficult to model the revenue outcome.

"
column591:
"

David

you mentioned that the backlog is down a little bit quarter-over-quarter. I guess I'm just curious as to -- if you can -- if you would provide some color as to what's driving that.

column599:

column600: it's still higher than it was at the beginning of the year and it's a very
column601: very slight -- it's a slight decline in the underwriting part

column604:

Got you. And then just last question for me. It feels like we get close to seeing a stronger M&A environment

column665: if somehow we can get past this with everyone feeling good

I think the political uncertainty out there has been a big part of what's kept the M&A calendar as low as it's been
column669: with the fiscal cliff

column675: if you saw some clarity

Good morning. My name is Dennis

and I will be your conference facilitator today. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call.

"
column45: this call is being recorded today
column46: January 16
column47: 2013. Thank you. Mr. Holmes

you may begin your conference.

column50:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column51:
Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our fourth quarter earnings conference call.

"
column52:
"

Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm's belief regarding future events that
column53: by their nature

column57:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our fiscal year ended December 2011.

"
column58:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column59: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column60: capital ratios
column61: risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com. This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column62: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column63:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column64:
"

Harvey Schwartz will now review the firm's results and David Viniar
column65:
and he will take -- make a few closing remarks. Harvey?

"
column66:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column67:
"

Thanks
column68: Dane. I would like to thank all of you for joining us today. I will give an overview of our fourth quarter and full year results
column69:
and then David and I will take your questions.

"
column70:
"

Full year net revenues for 2012 were $34.2 billion. Net earnings were $7.5 billion. Earnings per diluted share were $14.13
column71: and our return on common equity was 10.7%. Fourth quarter net revenues were $9.2 billion. Net earnings were $2.9 billion
column72: and earnings per diluted share were $5.60. The operating environment in 2012 was defined by a few significant trends: Substantial central bank activity
column73: improved economic data in the United States and continued political uncertainty. For example
column74: actions and commentary by the European Central Bank played a significant role in moderating concerns about a European linked tail event. At the end of 2011
column75:
the ECB announced that it would enhance its long-term refinancing operations to provide term liquidity.

"
column76:
"

The ECB further demonstrated its commitment during 2012 by affirming its support for the euro and its willingness to make outright purchases in the secondary bond market. In the United States
column77: the Federal Reserve also took steps to support markets and economic growth
column78: announcing further increases in monetary stimulus during the year. In 2012
column79: the U.S. economy posted stable to improving economic data
column80: particularly with developments in unemployment and housing. Over the course of the year
column81:
the U.S. economy added nearly 2 million jobs and the housing price index increased by 4% over the past 12 months.

"
column82:
"

Despite the systemic benefits of Central Bank activity and improved U.S. economic data
column83: our clients continue to struggle with the complex set of issues facing the global economy and the political backdrop. The most obvious recent example was the debate in the United States surrounding the fiscal cliff. These factors translated into mixed activity levels for our corporate client base. For example
column84: global debt issuance increased by 11% year-over-year
column85: with high-yield issuance increasing 38%. In contrast
column86:
global equity underwriting volumes were only up 1% and completed global merger and acquisition volumes actually decreased 18% in 2012 and remain very low as a percentage of market capitalization.

"
column87:
"

We experienced lower activity levels in most of our businesses and general risk aversion by our investment clients. This was offset by improving asset prices and lower volatility
column88: which created a more favorable market-making environment. Although equity and fixed-income asset prices trended up over the course of the year
column89: volumes generally declined given the previously mentioned factors. For example
column90: U.S.-listed equity volumes declined 18% in 2012. And as we all know
column91:
the S&P 500 declined by 13%.

"
column92:
"

While macroeconomic challenges persist
column93: our leadership teams remain focused on enhancing our returns. Drivers of our long-term success include focusing on our clients
column94:
prudently managing our risk profile and being disciplined about capital and expenses. I'll now review each of our businesses.

"
column95:
"

Investment Banking produced fourth quarter net revenues of $1.4 billion
column96: up 21% from the third quarter. The increase was due to higher equity underwriting revenues following a weak third quarter and continued strength in debt underwriting. For the full year
column97: Investment Banking net revenues were $4.9 billion
column98: up 13% from 2011 due to a robust environment for debt issuance. Within Investment Banking
column99: fourth quarter Advisory revenues were $508 million
column100: flat with the third quarter. Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A for 2012. We advised on a number of significant transactions that closed during the fourth quarter
column101:
including Kraft's $36.1 billion spinoff of its North American grocery business; Walt Disney's $4.1 billion acquisition of Lucasfilm; and Dollar Thrifty's $2.3 billion sale to Hertz. We also advised on a number of important transactions that were announced during the fourth quarter: Ralcorp Holdings' $6.8 billion sale to ConAgra; the $4.5 billion sale of eAccess to Softbank; and Gambro's $4 billion sale to Baxter International.

"
column102:
"

Fourth quarter underwriting net revenues were $897 million
column103: up 37% sequentially as issuance improved relative to the third quarter. Equity underwriting revenues of $304 million increased 61% compared to the third quarter
column104:
reflecting increased fuel activity. Goldman Sachs was ranked first in worldwide equity and equity-related and common stock offerings for 2012. Debt underwriting revenues increased 27% to $593 million due to our involvement in several significant transactions and a favorable new issue environment.

"
column105:
"

During the fourth quarter
column106: we participated in noteworthy underwriting transactions
column107:
including AIG's $6.4 billion sale of its remaining stake in AIA; AvalonBay Communities' $2.2 billion follow-on offering; and Clear Channel Outdoor's $2.7 billion high-yield offering. Our Investment banking backlog increased compared with the end of the third quarter. It was also higher than year end 2011.

"
column108:
"

Let me now turn to Institutional Client Services
column109: which is comprised of FICC and equities client execution
column110: commissions and fees
column111: and securities services. Net revenues were $4.3 billion in the fourth quarter
column112: up 4% from the third quarter. Net revenues within Institutional Client Services improved as the fourth quarter included an approximately $500 million gain from the sale of our hedge fund administration business. Full year net revenues of $18.1 billion for Institutional Client Services were up 5% relative to 2011 and included a $714 million DVA loss. Excluding the impact of DVA
column113: revenues were up 13% year-over-year and benefited from an improving market environment with tighter credit spreads
column114:
higher equity prices and lower levels of volatility.

"
column115:
"

FICC Client Execution net revenues were $2 billion in the fourth quarter
column116: including a DVA loss of $79 million
column117: and were down 8% sequentially as certain businesses reflected seasonally low levels of activity. Credit revenues increased significantly as client activity was supported by a favorable market backdrop
column118:
which included a relatively benign macro environment. Robust primary issuance and tighter credit spreads also helped.

"
column119:
"

Currency revenues also increased. Commodities revenues were higher compared to weaker third quarter results
column120: although absolute levels of client activity remained pretty low. While rates and mortgages were lower sequentially
column121: both businesses were strong contributors to the franchise. For the full year
column122: FICC Client Execution net revenues of $9.9 billion were up 10% relative to 2011. Excluding the impact of DVA
column123: revenues were up 20% compared to 2011
column124: as markets in 2012 were less turbulent and benefited from an improved backdrop in Europe
column125:
modest growth in the U.S. and strong central bank activity.

"
column126:
"

In equities
column127: which includes equities client execution
column128: commissions and fees and securities services
column129: net revenues for the fourth quarter were $2.3 billion
column130: up 18% sequentially and included $47 million in DVA losses. Excluding the impact of DVA
column131: revenues were up 12% relative to the third quarter. Equities client execution revenues decreased 10% sequentially to $764 million
column132: reflecting fewer client-driven opportunities in our cash market-making business. Commissions and fees were $722 million
column133: roughly flat with third quarter levels. Securities services net revenues of $818 million reflected the $500 million gain on sale that was previously mentioned. For the full year
column134: equities produced net revenues of $8.2 billion
column135:
consistent with 2011.

"
column136:
"

Turning to risk. Average daily VaR in the fourth quarter was $76 million
column137:
down from $81 million in the third quarter.

"
column138:
"

Now I'll review Investing & Lending
column139: which includes both direct investing and investing through funds across various asset classes
column140: as well as lending activities. Investing and lending produced net revenues of $2 billion in the fourth quarter. Our investment in ICBC produced a $334 million gain in the quarter. Other equity investments generated $789 million in gains
column141: reflecting realized and unrealized gains on private equity investments and mark-ups related to public equity investments
column142:
as equity markets were stronger in Asia and Europe.

"
column143:
"

Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $485 million
column144: largely driven by tightening credit spreads and net interest income. Other revenues of $365 million consists primarily of operating revenues from our consolidated investment entities and are largely offset by equivalent expenses. For the full year
column145: Investing & Lending generated net revenues of $5.9 billion
column146: driven by a $408 million gain on our investment in ICBC
column147: $2.4 billion in gains from other equity investments
column148: $1.9 billion of net revenues from debt securities and loans
column149:
and $1.2 billion of other investments.

"
column150:
"

In Investment Management
column151: we reported fourth quarter net revenues of $1.5 billion
column152: up 26% from the third quarter
column153: primarily as a result of $344 million in incentive fees generated from the firm's alternative asset products. Management and other fees were 5% higher at $1.1 billion. For the full year
column154: Investment Management net revenues were $5.2 billion
column155:
up 4% from 2011 levels and stronger incentive fees.

"
column156:
"

During the fourth quarter
column157: assets under supervision increased $14 billion to $965 billion
column158: largely due to net inflows of $15 billion into other client assets
column159: mainly as a result of Advisory mandates. Total assets under management were essentially unchanged. On a full year basis
column160: assets under supervision increased 8% as other client assets received $39 billion of net inflows. We ended the year with $111 billion of other client assets. Assets under management increased 3%
column161:
reflecting net market appreciation and was partially offset by outflows.

"
column162:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column163: which includes salaries
column164: bonuses
column165: amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as benefits
column166: increased 6% to $12.9 billion for 2012 and translated into a compensation-to-net-revenues ratio of 37.9%. It is important to note that our lower compensation ratio in 2012 is
column167: in part
column168:
a byproduct of our efficiency efforts that began in early 2011.

"
column169:
"

Fourth quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.9 billion
column170: 24% higher than the third quarter. Other expenses were significantly higher
column171: reflecting net provisions for litigation and regulatory proceedings of $260 million
column172: an increase of approximately $200 million over the third quarter. Based on the provision taken this quarter
column173: combined with previous reserves
column174: we have fully accounted for the independent foreclosure review settlement. The fourth quarter also included a $157 million donation to Goldman Sachs Gives
column175: our donor advised charitable fund. Finally
column176: depreciation and amortization increased by approximately $100 million
column177: driven by impairments to certain investment entities and our New York Stock Exchange designated market maker rights. For the full year
column178:
non-compensation expenses were down 4%.

"
column179:
"

Total staff at year-end were approximately 32
column181: down 3% from year-end 2011
column182: and 9% from year-end 2010. Our effective tax rate was 33.3% for 2012. During the quarter
column183: we repurchased 12.7 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.5 billion. For the full year
column184: we repurchased 42 million shares for a total cost of $4.6 billion. Historically
column185: our financial success has been a function of broad and deep client relationships
column186: our best-in-class people
column187:
our disciplined approach to locating financial and human capital and a culture of collaboration and partnership. The value of this partnership is highlighted in challenging market environments and drove our results in 2012.

"
column188:
"

Looking forward
column189: we believe that we are well positioned to expand our client franchise globally. For corporate clients
column190: we will continue to leverage our strong M&A
column191: equity and debt underwriting positions. For investing and other institutional clients
column192: we will continue to rely on the quality of our content and execution. We will remain very disciplined in our approach to expenses
column193:
balancing near-term benefits to our margins against longer term revenue opportunities.

"
column194:
"

As we gain greater clarity on regulatory changes
column195: particularly capital requirements
column196: we will respond accordingly. For example
column197: given the Basel III capital changes that we incur as an owner of our own reinsurance business
column198: we are considering a potential sale of the majority stake in the business. We have strong risk-adjusted capitalization
column199: which provides protection to shareholders against tail events. In addition
column200: our capital levels also create opportunities. First
column201:
it positions the firm to help our clients navigate an uncertain economic event. It also allows us to provide capital where capacity is diminished. We are committed to effectively deploying our capital and maintaining dry powder to meet future client needs.

"
column202:
"

We will also return capital to shareholders when appropriate returns aren't available. And our capital trends in 2012 reflected our measured approach as our estimated Basel Tier 1 capital ratio increased from approximately 8% to nearly 9%
column203:
despite returning $5.5 billion to shareholders via share buybacks and dividends.

"
column204:
"

We are encouraged by the early signs of improvement in the markets and economy but remain cautious given the complexity of the risk and challenges. The quality of our advice and execution in today's challenging markets serves as a foundation for maintaining long-term client relationships and ultimately meeting the needs of all of our stakeholders.

"
column205:
"

Everyone at Goldman Sachs remains steadfast in their commitment to serving our client franchise. We have a deep appreciation for our responsibility to all of our constituents: clients
column206: shareholders
column207: regulators
column208: our employees and
column209: of course
column210:
the broader financial system. We believe that there's a shared interest among our constituents to manage the firm in a way that supports economic growth and sustainability. Our firm is fully committed to filling that responsibility.

"
column211:
"

With that
column212: I'd like to take a moment to thank David on behalf of the firm for his significant contributions to Goldman Sachs over his 32-year career. There is no doubt that our clients
column213: employees
column214: regulators and shareholders have all benefited from his unwavering commitment
column215: sound judgment and devotion to the firm's culture and principles. As a personal note
column216: I really want to thank you. You've been a tremendous partner
column217: David
column218: and not only during this transition. I truly can't thank you enough. I look forward to working with you as a member of our Board of Directors. For those of you who aren't keeping track
column219:
this is David's 55th consecutive earnings call. It is only fitting that he provide some closing comments. David?

"
column220:
"

David A. Viniar

"
column221:
"

Thank you
column222: Harvey. As many of you know
column223: I spent my entire career at Goldman Sachs. So it's all I know. I always believed that it was a special place. That is a perception which has been validated over the last several years given my experiences during this period of stress. I witnessed the strength of our client franchise
column224: the quality and dedication of our people and the commitment of our shareholders. It was an honor to be asked to join the Board of Directors. I look forward to continuing to serve as a steward for shareholders in that role. It is a responsibility that I take with full confidence in the strength of the client franchise
column225: the financial health of the company
column226: and the caliber and devotion of our people. I would also like to thank all of our shareholders
column227: debt investors and research analysts for their support of the firm and me
column228: personally. I leave knowing that I am turning the role over to Harvey
column229:
who has the skills and judgment to warrant that same level of support.

"
column231: again
column233:
and now Harvey and I are happy to take your questions.

"
column235:
"

Operator

"
column237:
"

[Audio Gap]

"
column238:
"

Your first question is from the line of Howard Chen with Cr\u00e9dit Suisse.

"
column239:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column240:
Research Division

"
column241:
"

I think everyone would acknowledge 2012 was a pretty tough year for the industry
column242: but yet when all is said and done
column243: the firm posted nearly 11% return on equity. Just given where revenues and where you decided to accrue comps
column244:
can you just discuss the significance of that 11%? Is that in a threshold ROE that we should think about that you don't want to fall below in a challenging environment?

"
column246:
"

So what I would say about 2012
column247: obviously
column248: as you mentioned
column249: certainly some elements of the marketplace were particularly challenging. What put us in a position to achieve the ROE
column251: were the steps we took over the last 2 years in terms of managing expenses and being quite disciplined. But in terms of what we're able to achieve in the future
column252: we're going to have to see what the market opportunity brings to us. But this was a year where
column256: the competitive dynamic. And as I said
column257: we benefited from the steps that we took over the past 2 years. But quite frankly
column258: I don't think  -- while we'll be pleased with the performance of the environment
column259:
it's not particularly aspirational. We'd like to do better.

"
column260:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG
column262:
"

Okay. And then switching gears
column263: Harvey
column264: with respect to Investing & Lending
column265: you noted the improved realization environment and mix
column266: as many of your investments have been in the ground for a few years now
column267: I was hoping you could provide us some thoughts on how you think about the realization pipeline
column268:
give us a little bit more detail on that appetite to sell today if markets were cooperative.

"
column269:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column270:
"

So the ability to monetize
column271: as you know

The CFTC obviously pushed back timing of some of the OTC reforms with respect to central clearing
column505: at least to -- pretty close to the middle of the year. And I know this is kind of a narrow question
column506: but I'm just interested in how you think about it. All else equal
column507: would you expect that revenues in FICC from or broadly from OTC Derivatives transactions would be higher in the first half as a result of just that change
column508:
or is not -- that not the right way to think about it?

"
column509:

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column510:
"

I think it's a good question. I think that the only case study we have is really history. And when you look back over history
column511: history is proving that -- a couple things: One
column512: it's proven that rule changes
column513: and the ultimate impact on market structure
column514: incredibly difficult to predict. I would say -- and I didn't really feel this way about a year ago. I thought that the rule delays or uncertainty around rules
column515: I didn't think was having an impact in terms of client activity. I do think as we get more clarity on rule certainty
column516: it may ultimately impact client activity to the positive. Now having said that
column517: I wouldn't trade off that delay for bad rule-making
column518:
and I think the CFTC and other regulators have been pretty thoughtful about taking the steps to delay rules because the single most important thing is that the market has an opportunity to adapt because we just -- we don't want to increase systemic risk while the regulators are trying to put the rules in place. So I think all these delays have been quite thoughtful.

column1214: one of your closest competitors sheared a number of jobs in the last few days. And what was intriguing was
column1216: something like a 6% reduction in their investment banking staff
column1217: but something like 15% in Asia. And I was just wondering
column1218: you obviously had another quarter where you were very tight on staff numbers. But is Asia the market you're still investing in? Or is it one where maybe you're also thinking
column1219: \"Have we perhaps overlicked the pudding at this stage
column1220: \" and we need to also look at our staffing there
column1221:
as you obviously are in the developed markets?

"
column1223:
"

No. As we look at it today
column1224: we think the growth markets broadly
column1226: look quite attractive. And we're comfortable with our level of investment. Having said that
column1227: again -- I'll caveat that. And of course
column1228: if the world got much brighter or turned the other way
column1229:
then we'd adjust. But we feel pretty comfortable.

"
column1235:
"

Great. I'd like to thank everybody for joining us for our fourth quarter 2012 conference call. If you have any questions
column1236: please feel free to contact us in the Investor Relations group. And otherwise

this does conclude the Goldman Sachs Fourth Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect.

"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column42: Director of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our first quarter earnings conference call. Today's call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm\u2019s belief regarding future events that
column44: are uncertain and outside of the firm\u2019s control. The firm\u2019s actual results and financial condition may differ
column45: possibly materially

column47:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our year ended December 2012.

"
column48:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column49: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column50: capital ratios
column51: risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures that is posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com. This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column52: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column53:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column55:
Harvey Schwartz will now review the firm\u2019s results. Harvey?

"
column56:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column57:
"

Thanks
column58: Dane
column59:
and thanks everyone for dialing in today. I will walk you through our first quarter results and then take your questions.

"
column60:
"

Net revenues were $10.1 billion
column61: net earnings $2.3 billion
column62: earnings per diluted share were $4.29 and our annualized return on common equity was 12.4%. Overall
column63: a solid result. As we\u2019ve talked about in the past
column64: client activity levels are generally correlated to the broader macroeconomic environment. This certainly proved to be true in the first quarter as activity levels were mixed as the quarter progress. Early in the quarter
column65: continued positive development from U.S. economy
column66: specifically in housing and unemployment drove increased client activity and greater risk appetite. In January U.S. new home sales grew by almost 15% month-over-month
column67:
one of the largest month-over-month increases in the last two decades.

"
column68:
"

The U.S. nonfarm payroll report for February came in significantly higher than expectations with 236
column69: 000 jobs created versus expectations of a 160
column70: 000. In addition to driving increased client activity and risk appetite
column71: these economic developments help support driving asset values. Most notably the S&P 500 was up by 10% and key credit indices
column72:
such as the LCDX and high yield CDX reached higher by more than 50 basis points. This created a back drop to generally improve liquidity and a more favorable environment managing client flows.

"
column73:
"

However
column74: later in the quarter
column75: market sentiment was mixed at political uncertainty in Europe and U.S. began to resurface. The Italian election and the situation in Cyprus added further complexity to the European outlook. Specifically its events like these that create uncertainty for market participants who struggle to understand the mechanism and approach for resolving sovereign issues within the Eurozone. Likewise in the U.S.
column76:
our clients' focused on the potential negative impact to sequestration and the continued impacts related to budget negotiations.

"
column77:
"

In aggregate
column78: as the quarter progressed
column79:
these concerns impacted both client activity and risk appetite. Client activity levels were mixed across our investment banking businesses during the quarter. Debt underwriting activity continued at the robust pace we experienced in the fourth quarter as corporate issuers took advantage of the low interest rate environment and strong investor demand.

"
column80:
"

Equity underwriting activity improved sequentially with higher issuance activity
column81: but is still relatively muted by historic standards. And announced M&A volumes were down 37% sequentially. Macroeconomic uncertainty has been an understandable and consistent theme following the onset of the financial crisis and had quite naturally led many of our clients to approach strategic decisions with greater caution
column82: as CEO confidence is such an important input to M&A and IPO activity
column83: continued improvement in the macro environment will be a key driver of opportunity in these businesses. Regardless of the macro uncertainty
column84:
our people remain focused on serving our clients by providing them with superior advice and execution and of course the capital necessarily to meet their goals.

"
column85:
"

I'll now run through each of our businesses. Investment Banking produced first quarter net revenues of 1.6 billion
column86: up 12% from the fourth quarter. First quarter advisory revenues were 484 million
column87: down 5% sequentially. Year-to-date
column88: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide completed M&A. We advised on a number of important transactions that closed in the first quarter
column89: including the 21 billion Swedish Krona sale of Ahold stake in ICA to Hakon Invest. The $3.3 billion sale of select SuperValu assets to an investor group led by Cerberus Capital Management
column90:
and the $2.4 billion sale on McGraw-Hill Education to Apollo.

"
column91:
"

We're also an advisor on a number of significant announced transactions. These include the $23.3 billion sale of Virgin Media to Liberty Global
column92: the $6.7 billion sale of Repsol's liquefied natural gas assets to Royal Dutch Shell
column93: and the $2.6 billion acquisition by Orix Corporation of a 90% equity stake in Robeco Group. First quarter underwriting net revenues were 1.1 billion
column94: up 21% sequentially
column95: a record debt underwriting quarter with revenues up 17% to 694 million. In particular
column96:
this reflects significantly higher net revenues from leverage finance and commercial mortgage-related activity.

"
column97:
"

Equity underwriting revenues of 390 million were up 28% from the fourth quarter
column98: reflecting an increase in IPO activity and secondary offerings. Year-to-date
column99: Goldman Sachs ranked first in global equity and equity-related common stock offerings and IPOs. During the first quarter
column100: there were several noteworthy transactions. Sinopec's 3.1 billion private placement ArcelorMittal\u2019s $4 billion dual-tranche equity and mandatory convertible offering
column101:
and Intelsat\u2019s $3.5 billion high yield offering. Our Investment Banking backlog declined modestly from year-end levels.

"
column102:
"

Let me now turn to institutional client services. Total net revenues were 5.1 billion in the first quarter. These businesses produced stronger results in the seasonally weak fourth quarter
column103: driven by an overall improvement in activity levels and market sentiment. FICC Client Execution net revenues were 3.2 billion in the first quarter
column104:
significantly better than the fourth quarter. This quarter's results reflected a broad contribution across businesses. Rates reflected generally higher activity levels as clients reacted to the improved economic outlook at the beginning of the quarter.

"
column105:
"

Our credit business experienced solid client activity and a favorable market environment with strong issuance trends and generally tighter credit spreads. Mortgages continued to benefit from strong client demand
column106: relatively limited new supply
column107:
and improving prices. Our currency business reflected higher levels of client activity. And finally commodity results improved from what was a relatively weak fourth quarter.

"
column108:
"

Turning to equities
column109: net revenues for the first quarter were $1.9 billion. Excluding the $500 million gain from the sale of our hedge fund administration business in the fourth quarter
column110: results were up 7% quarter-over-quarter. Equities client execution revenues were 809 million
column111: up 6% sequentially; commissions and fees were 793 million
column112: up 10% from the fourth quarter on improved market volumes and generally higher market values in Europe and Asia. Excluding the one-time gain in the fourth quarter
column113: security services net revenues of $320 million were roughly flat sequentially. With respect to risk
column114: average daily VaR in the first quarter was $76 million
column115:
consistent with fourth quarter levels.

"
column116:
"

Let me now review Investing & Lending. We produced net revenues of $2.1 billion in the first quarter. Investing & Lending includes direct investing
column117: investing we do through funds
column118: as well as lending activities. These activities occur across a diversified set of asset classes including both equity and debt. Other equity investments generated net revenues of $1.1 billion
column119:
primarily reflecting gains from private equity investments.

"
column120:
"

This strong performance reflects higher global equity prices during the quarter as well as increases in fair value driven by company specific events. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $566 million
column121: driven by continued tightening of credit spreads as well as interest income. Our investment in ICBC produced a $24 million gain in the quarter
column122:
other revenues of $375 million were driven by the firm\u2019s consolidated investment entities.

"
column123:
"

Switching over to investment management
column124: we reported first quarter net revenues of $1.3 billion
column125: down 13% from the fourth quarter due to lower incentive fees. Management and other fees were consistent with the fourth quarter at $1.1 billion. During the first quarter
column126: assets under supervision increased $3 billion to $968 billion
column127: primarily reflecting net market appreciation and net inflows in both fixed income and equity assets
column128:
partially offset by outflows and money market assets.

"
column129:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column130: which includes salaries
column131: bonuses
column132: amortization of prior-year equity awards
column133: and other items such as payroll  taxes and benefits was accrued at a compensation  to net revenue ratio of 43%
column134: which is a 100 basis points lower than the firm\u2019s accrual  in the first quarter of 2011 and 2012. Over the past two years
column135:
we\u2019ve focused extensively on cost reduction and efficiency efforts.

"
column136:
"

From the headcount perspective
column137: total staff at the end of the first quarter was approximately $32
column139: down 1% from the end of 2012 and 10% from year-end 2010. First quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.4 billion
column140: significantly lower than the fourth quarter due largely to lower other expenses. In the fourth quarter
column141: other expenses included higher litigation and regulatory expenses and higher charitable contributions. Non-comp expenses was essentially unchanged from the first quarter of 2012
column142:
and our effective tax rate was 33% for the first quarter.

"
column143:
"

In terms of capital
column144: there are a number of items to cover with you. During the quarter
column145: we repurchased 10.1 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.5 billion. These repurchases reflected the completion of our 2012 capital plan. We also recently amended the terms of our warrant agreement with Berkshire Hathaway to acquire  net share settlement on October 1<sup>st</sup> of this year. At the end of the first quarter
column146: our Basel 1 Tier 1 common ratio was approximately 12.7%. This includes the revised market rich framework that became effective on January 1<sup>st</sup>. Our estimated Basel III Tier 1 common ratio was approximately 9%
column147: of course with all the caveats that the rule has not been finalized. During the first quarter
column148:
the Federal Reserve announced that it did not object to our proposed capital actions that as required by the Federal Reserve we will resubmit our capital plan by the end of the third quarter incorporating certain enhancements to our stress test processes. We intend to work closely with the Federal Reserve to implement these enhancements.

"
column149:
"

Before I take questions
column150: let me close with a few summary thoughts. As I mentioned earlier macro uncertainty continues to be a meaningful consideration for the global marketplace. While the environment is slowly improving
column151: there will clearly be bumps along the way. So despite an improvement in the outlook some uncertainty remains. Another uncertainty that has occupied investor\u2019s minds is the potential impact of regulatory reform on our industry. While everyone would like clarity
column152: it's natural for these rules to be developed over multi-year timeframes
column153:
especially given the complexity and the potentially significant ramifications for the global economy. As a firm we remain a constructive participant in these discussions.

"
column154:
"

We understand the importance of creating a safe financial system while meeting our client needs and supporting global economic growth at the same time. In light of the continued macro uncertainty
column155: we\u2019ve continued to stay focused on managing the firms risk exposures
column156: capital usage and our expense base. It has allowed our people to be principally focused on serving our clients. We believe the combination of our operating discipline and our steady investment in our client franchise has us well positioned competitively. In addition
column157:
it has provided the firm with the opportunity to generate significant operating leverage as the environment improves.

"
column158:
"

Regardless of the operating environment
column159: we will continue to rely on the strength of our client relationships
column160: the diversity of our businesses
column161: the caliber of our people
column162:
and the adaptability embedded in our culture to deliver superior results for our shareholders.

"
column163:
"

With that
column164: I'd like to thank you again for listening today
column165:
and I'm now happy to take your questions.

column356: so maybe like on the collateral management side
column357: just trying to figure out because it seems like there's going to be some users that there will be more incentive to try to use an alternative if they don't have the hurdles like hedge accounting
column358:
but I don't know if on the dealer side if there's something that you can provide to kind of ease that burden?

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column360:
"

Yeah
column361: I think that when -- first of all
column362: I would say the following. We in the industry have lived with uneven requirements in terms of whether its margin or a capital standard and so some of these things are going to run like this. I think as we get the full view of everything that's out there
column363: I think that the regulatory community and all of our as participants will then have to view the extent of which there's differences and understand whether or not those incentives are actually the right incentives in terms of reducing systemic risks because remember
column364: the overarching objective here is to reduce systemic risks and that's again I'd go back to my earlier comment about clearing. So you don't necessarily want to have significantly different collateral requirements for essentially the same type of risks
column365: because then you can get some unwanted incentives. Now having said and putting that aside for a moment
column366: our clients are driven by the long-term incentive goal so they're going to make the best choice they can for executing and at times
column367:
collateral maybe a more significant component of their thought process; other times other issues will guide how they execute.

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

column369:
"

column370: makes sense. And then just on the market share opportunity

column383: executing blocks of equities. column703:
but it did look like you guys had one of your better quarters in a while with respect to some long-term flows and I\u2019m just wondering if there was anything you guys could attribute that to? Thanks.

column704:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column705:
"

Sure. In terms of capital no there is nothing there and with respect to -- asset management we obviously continued to stay very focused on performance and improved performance always attracts client flows and we\u2019re still missing that.

Douglas Sipkin - Susquehanna Financial Group

I wouldn\u2019t extrapolate 2012 into 2013

great. Thanks a lot.

column734: all the market participants
column735: obviously we all have a huge obligation
column736:

Frederick Cannon - KBW

Jeffrey Harte - Sandler O'Neill + Partners

L.P.

column823:

column827:
I think it was down to 76% this quarter and that is coming mostly by drop \u2013 a decline in implied volatility in the market place.

column828:

Eric Wasserstrom - SunTrust Robinson Humphrey

column831:
"

column838:
"

That\u2019s too hard for me to predict

column859:

Christoph Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.

column866:
"

James Mitchell - The Buckingham Research

column868: good morning. Just one follow-up on the derivatives reform

column870:
how do you think of \u2013 how should we think about that impact this quarter?

column872:
"

So this is again one of these things that\u2019s really
column873: really difficult to predict and so we\u2019ll monitor and -- one other things that we\u2019ve learned in terms of regulatory changes and market structure changes is that
column874: the key is lessen our predicting effort outcomes and more about responding to them. And so we have a long history of adapting and so as these rules become [live]
column875: we're going to have to adapt as our clients. And we'll have to adapt better than our competitors. Historically
column876:
we've been good at that but we'll have to deliver in the future.

"
column877:
"

James Mitchell - The Buckingham Research

"
column878:
"

Fair enough. Maybe taking a little bit of a longer term view as you get more prepared for and moving things to clearing and increasing electronification of FICC
column879: do you see offsets here? What's your view on how expenses react to greater electronification and should that offset

most people's view of declining revenues in that type of environment?
