column884: difficult to predict so I think it's better to look at history of the guide. The electronification of FICC has been obviously happening for a number of years. You go back to early part of 2000 with the advent of trade web and government bond and then simultaneously the foreign exchange markets. So
column885: electronification is not new to us
column886: even FICC and obviously equities broadly. And so it's for us
column887: the electronification I think is a bit of a muscle memory issue and of course as you know
column888: we think we have some competitive advantage given than we have one platform in (inaudible) which when will it become final and as markets become more electronic
column889: a lot of this is about speed and ability to adopt new procedures and respond because that's what our clients need. And so with respect to the forward
column890: obviously there's some operating efficiencies that can be gained. You may get new revenue development and new products
column891:
but I think those things are much harder to forecast. You really have to look at our experience in terms of how we're done it.

column892:
"

James Mitchell - The Buckingham Research

column893:
"

So I guess if we look at equities

column895:
moved to commission you had less volatility and better returns. Do you think that that's a logical outcome for fixed income as well?

"
column899: I think if you look at the case study and we didn't -- and Dane I think can walk you through more specific examples offline. But if you look just at us
column904:
I think our history is good but we have to execute.

"
column905:
"

James Mitchell - The Buckingham Research

{"Goldman Sachs Group Inc (GS) Management Discusses Q2 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (NYSE:GS)

"

Harvey M. Schwartz - EVP and CFO

"

Dane E. Holmes - Director
column10:

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse AG

"
column12:

column14:

column26:
"

Good morning. My name is Dennis
column27: and I\u2019ll be your conference facilitator today. I\u2019d like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs Second Quarter 2013 Earnings Conference Call. After the speakers\u2019 remarks there will be a question-and-answer period. (Operator Instructions) Also this call is being recorded today
column31:
you may now begin your conference.

"
column33:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column34: Head of Investor Relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our second quarter earnings conference call. Today\u2019s call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm\u2019s belief regarding future events that
column36: are uncertain and outside of the firm\u2019s control. The firm\u2019s actual results and financial condition may differ
column38: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm\u2019s future results
column39:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our year ended December 2012.

"
column40:
"

I\u2019d also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column41: particularly
column42: as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column44: risk-weighted assets and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures and regulatory capital ratios that are posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com. This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column45: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column46:
reproduced or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column47:
"

Our Chief Financial Officer
column48:
Harvey Schwartz will now review the firm\u2019s results. Harvey?

"
column50:
"

Thanks
column51: Dane
column52:
and thanks everyone for dialing in today. I\u2019ll walk you through our second quarter results and then take your questions.

"
column53:
"

Net revenues were $8.6 billion
column55: earnings per diluted share $3.70
column56: our annualized return on common equity 10.5%. For the first half of the year our return on common equity was 11.5%. All in
column57:
a solid outcome and what continues to be a dynamic market environment.

"
column58:
"

On our earnings call last quarter
column59: we discussed how the evolving economic outlook impacts client activity. Narrowing economic data and substantial central bank actions during the quarter caused our clients to continually reassess their expectations from global growth. As a result
column60:
our clients risk appetite in activity levels fluctuated over the course of the quarter.

"
column61:
"

At the beginning of the quarter
column62: our clients remained focused on the European economic outlook. As the quarter progressed
column63: solid economic data out of the U.S. began to moderate economic concerns. Client activity
column64: risk appetite
column65: and asset prices improved as a result of the increased confidence in the U.S. economy. Macro concerns emerged again towards the end of the quarter and refracted \u2013 reflected in lower activity levels and risk appetite in certain businesses. In addition
column66:
the market volatility created more challenging periods within the capital markets for managing client flows.

"
column67:
"

As I previously mentioned
column68: central banks around the world were particularly active during the second quarter. This activity was a key driver of market sentiments during the quarter. In Japan
column69: the Central Bank undertook unprecedented monetary action to stimulate their economy. During the second quarter
column70:
the yen declined by approximately 5% versus the U.S. dollar and 7% versus the euro.

"
column71:
"

The marketplace tried to weigh the potential near-term benefits for the Japanese economy against the relative headwinds for other parts of the world. In the U.S.
column72:
commentary from the Federal Reserve about potentially tapering its bond buying program led to a significant rise in interest rates. Market participants continue to debate the timing and impact of tapering on both the market and economic activity.

"
column73:
"

Clients were also concerned with the potential slow down in China during the quarter. Ultimately our clients are assessing the broader global economy
column74: specifically whether a recovering U.S.
column75:
will offset potentially slower growth in other economic regions.

"
column76:
"

I\u2019ll now run through each of our businesses. Investment banking produced second quarter net revenues of $1.6 billion
column77: roughly consistent with the first quarter. Second quarter advisory revenues were $486 million
column78: consistent with the first quarter. Year-to-date
column79: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advised on a number of important transactions that closed in the second quarter
column80:
including News Corporation approximately $9 billion spin-off of its publishing business. Hess\u2019s 2.1 billion sale of its Russian subsidiary to Lukoil and Siemens 1.7 billion British pound acquisition of Invensys Rail.

"
column81:
"

We are also an advisor on a number of significant announced transactions. They include Canada Safeway\u2019s CAD$5.8 billion sale to Sobeys. Springer Science and Business Media\u2019s \u20ac3.3 billion sale to BC Partners and Lender Processing Services $4 billion sale to Fidelity National Financial.

"
column82:
"

Second quarter underwriting net revenues were $1.1 billion
column83: relatively consistent with a robust first quarter. Debt underwriting revenues were very strong at $695 million and represents a record quarter. While the pace of commercial mortgage related activity slowed
column84: leverage finance activity remains strong. Equity underwriting revenues of $371 million were down 5% compared with the first quarter. Year-to-date
column85:
Goldman Sachs ranked first in global equity and equity-related common stock offerings and IPOs.

"
column86:
"

During the second quarter
column87:
there were several noteworthy transactions. Apple\u2019s $17 billion first ever debt offering. Valeant Pharmaceuticals $9.6 billion debt and equity financing and J.C. Penney\u2019s $2.3 billion term loan. Our Investment Banking backlog was consistent with first quarter levels.

"
column88:
"

Let me now turn to institutional client services. Total net revenues were $4.3 billion in the second quarter. FICC Client Execution net revenues were $2.5 billion in the second quarter
column89: lower than the first quarter
column90:
but higher than the second quarter a year-ago. This quarter results continue to reflect a broad contribution across businesses and reinforce the benefits of having a diversified franchise.

"
column91:
"

While activity levels in our currency business remains strong as clients reacted to increased volatility
column92: particularly in Asia
column93: resulting other businesses were lower than the first quarter. As you would expect during the period of increasing interest rates and widening credit spreads
column94: client risk appetite declined at rates
column95:
credit and mortgages and inventory management was a bit more challenging during the later part of the quarter. Commodity results increased relative to the first quarter as volatility remain low in many of our core products and client activity was lower as a result.

"
column96:
"

Turning to equities
column97: net revenues for the second quarter were $1.9 billion
column98: down modestly from the first quarter. Equities client execution revenues were $638 million
column99: down 21% sequentially; largely reflecting the impact of the sale of our reinsurance business. Commissions and fees were $836 million
column100:
up 5% from the first quarter due to improved market volumes.

"
column101:
"

Security services net revenues of $376 million were 18% higher sequentially due to seasonally stronger client activity. With respect to risk average daily VaR in the second quarter was $81 million
column102: up 7% from first quarter levels due to higher volatilities mainly in currencies. Adjusted for volatilities
column103:
VaR was relatively unchanged quarter-on-quarter.

"
column104:
"

Let me now review Investing & Lending. We produced net revenues of 1.4 billion in the second quarter. Investing & Lending includes direct investing
column105: investing due to funds as well as lending activities. These activities occur across a diversified set of asset classes
column106:
including both equity and debt.

"
column107:
"

Equity securities generated net revenues of 462 million
column108: primarily reflecting gains from private equity investments. This increase in fair value was driven by company-specific events and strong corporate performance. Also
column109:
we sold our remaining stake in ICBC during the quarter.

"
column110:
"

The net gain over the quarter was a modest $7 million. Net revenues from debt securities and loans was 658 million
column111:
driven by company-specific events and interest income. Other revenues of 295 million were driven by the firm's consolidated investment entities.

"
column112:
"

Switching to Investment Management
column113: we reported second quarter net revenues of 1.3 billion
column114: roughly consistent with the first quarter. Management and other fees were 1.1 billion
column115: up 4% sequentially. During the second quarter
column116:
assets under supervision decreased 13 billion to 955 billion primarily reflecting net market depreciation and fixed income assets.

"
column117:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense which includes salaries
column118: bonuses
column119:
amortization of prior-year equity awards and other items such as payroll taxes and benefits was accrued a compensation to net revenues ratio of 43% which is consistent with the firm's accrual in the first quarter.

"
column120:
"

Second quarter non-compensation expenses were 2.3 billion
column121: 5% lower than the first quarter
column122: largely due to the sale of our reinsurance business. Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 27%
column123: driven by earnings that were permanently reinvested abroad. Year-to-date
column124:
our effective tax rate was 30.4%.

"
column125:
"

On capital we repurchased 10.5 million shares of common stock for a total cost of 1.6 billion during the quarter. Our basic shares outstanding were 468 million at the end of the second quarter
column126: down close to 6% over the last four quarters. At the end of the second quarter
column127: our estimated Basel III tier 1 common ratio under the advanced approach was approximately 9.3% and reflects the final Basel III rules that were issued by the Federal Reserve on July 2nd. Obviously
column128:
we are still reviewing the final rule but this is our best estimate subject to change depending on regulatory clarifications.

"
column129:
"

Now
column130: over the quarter
column131: we took a number of strategic actions to bolster our capital position. As you will recall
column132:
we announced the potential sale of a majority stake in our reinsurance business even the Basel III capital charges that we incurred as a 100% owner of the business. We completed the sale of our reinsurance business in the second quarter. The sale includes our Basel III capital ratio by approximately 50 basis points and reduced the firm's balance sheet by $17 billion. This benefit was partially offset by implementations of the final Basel III rule set.

"
column133:
"

Now
column134: at 9.3% we are close to having achieved our previously-stated target of the 8.5% requirement plus an approximate 100 basis point buffer. Regarding the leverage ratio
column135: we also received the NPR last week. Even it's in the proposal stage
column136: it's hard to speculate on how it will ultimately be finalized. However
column137: we have significantly reduced our leverage since 2007. Since then we've reduced our assets by roughly 180 billion while increasing our equity base by over 80%. As a result
column138: we feel reasonably well positioned for the new leverage requirements at both the holding company and the bank's subsidiary. But once again
column139:
it's a proposal so we will work with the regulators over the coming months.

"
column140:
"

Effectively managing the firm requires us to comply with a variety of different regulatory measures. Just as we've improved our Basel III capital ratio
column141: we will have to continually adjust to any new regulations as they are finalized. As we have said in the past
column142: a high level of risk-adjusted capital not only provides protection against tail events to all of our constituents
column143:
it also creates the foundation for capturing opportunities.

"
column144:
"

With higher risk-adjusted capitalization
column145: we are better positioned to help our clients navigate on uncertain economic environments and we can provide them with risk capital where capacity is diminished. An essential part of our role as managers on behalf of you
column146: our shareholders
column147:
is to manage our capital effectively and efficiently in order to generate superior long-term returns.

"
column148:
"

Now in closing
column149: we are cautiously optimistic about the outlook for the operating environment. Nevertheless
column150: we remain vigilant regarding expenses and risks. Given the dynamic nature of the marketplace it's natural for people to become somewhat short-term focused. However
column151:
everyone at Goldman Sachs remains keenly aware that our success will be measured over years as opposed to weeks or months.

"
column152:
"

To that end
column153: we are going to continue to invest in deepening and expanding our client franchise
column154: building relationships that will pass the test of time. We will continue to invest in our people
column155:
recruiting and retaining a group of professionals who are committed to providing solutions to our clients and driving value for our shareholders.

"
column156:
"

With that
column157:
I'd like to thank you again for listening today. And I'm now happy to take your questions.

"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column794:
"

Good morning
column795:
Harvey. Thanks for taking my questions. Just a couple of quickies I think. Your long-term unsecured debt at least according to the press release is down roughly 5 billion quarter-over-quarter. How are you thinking about debt levels going forward and have you changed your thinking at all on OLA and how that will affect your debt balance going forward?

"
column796:
"

Harvey M. Schwartz

"
column797:
"

So
column798: just Orderly Liquidation Authority just for everyone dialing in
column799: obviously any wall set that conceptually is designed to create order
column800: in principal
column801: we don\u2019t have any issues with. We haven\u2019t seen the detail in the weeds on that. And it gets back to what I said earlier
column802: we\u2019re not going to adjust the capital structure of the firm based on a discussion or where we kind of guess things will come out. That\u2019s not the way we\u2019re going to think about or manage the capital structure. So
column803: no changes and now at best we can tell. Again
column804: these are all in discussions
column805: so we don\u2019t have details. So as best we could tell given the amount of debt we have at the Holdco
column806: one might say that we\u2019re reasonably well positioned
column807: but again
column808:
really big caveat on that. We haven\u2019t seen any details.

"
column809:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column810:
"

Let me come at the same question from a different direction. Are your capital markets team and debt underwriting looking positively at that idea or is that \u2013 or they of the same opinion?

"
column812:
"

I think we need more details. There is \u2013 we\u2019ve seen a lot of views in the marketplace.

"
column813:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column814:
"

Let me switch the question to activity levels across your broad geographic groups; Europe
column815: Asia
column816: U.S./North America
column817:
were there any meaningful improvements in activity level maybe outside the U.S. this quarter that helped the revenue side of things or were there any areas of particular weakness?

"
column820: certainly the activity levels in Japan and when I say Japan I don't necessarily mean specifically Japan geographically but activity that's driven around Japan. So
column821: given the global nature of our clients one of the most important things that we need to do across the entire firm is make sure that we connect geographically in a way to deliver content. So it might be clients in Europe that are very focused on events in Japan
column822:
same as the U.S. So a lot of capturing that is making sure that they content mechanism works and a transmission mechanism works. And so I'll say Japan was a driver certainly of increased activity but not just isolated to Japan that's not on benefits.

"
column823:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column824:
"

And would you characterize Europe as still being a little bit below Asia and the U.S. in terms of activity levels given the economic conditions there?

"
column826:
"

I mean that's fair. I think there's more upside in Europe and I think there's more upside specifically \u2013 and again
column827:
this could play out over many years. I think there's more upside specifically for U.S. based firms like ourselves Goldman Sachs.

"
column828:
"

Matthew Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column834:
"

Your next question is from the line of Chris Kotowski with Oppenheimer. Please go ahead
column839:
"

Christoph Kotowski - Oppenheimer & Co. Inc.

"
column840:
"

Hi. My questions were asked and answered. Thank you.

"
column846:
there are no further questions. Do you have any closing remarks?

"
column848:
"

No. We'd like to thank everybody for dialing into the call. Obviously
column849: if people have any questions they should feel free to direct them to us in the Investor Relations department. Otherwise
column850:
enjoy the rest of your day and the week. Thanks.

"

this concludes the Goldman Sachs Second Quarter 2013 Earnings Conference Call. You may now disconnect.

column1:
{"Goldman Sachs' Management Discusses Q3 2013 Results - Earnings Call Transcript": ["

Goldman Sachs (NYSE:GS)

"
column7:
"

Harvey Schwartz - EVP and CFO

"
column12:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse

"
column15:
"

Michael Carrier - Bank of America Merrill Lynch

"
column20:
"

Matt Burnell - Wells Fargo Securities

"
column22:
"

Douglas Sipkin - Susquehanna Financial Group

"
column23:
"

Fiona Swaffield - RBC Capital Markets

"
column29:
"

Good morning. I would like to welcome everyone to the Goldman Sachs third quarter 2013 earnings conference call. This call is being recorded today
column32:
you may now begin your conference.

"
column34:
"

Good morning. This is Dane Holmes
column35:
director of investor relations at Goldman Sachs. Welcome to our third quarter earnings conference call.

"
column36:
"

Today\u2019s call may include forward-looking statements. These statements represent the firm\u2019s belief regarding future events that by their nature are uncertain and outside of the firm\u2019s control. The firm\u2019s actual results and financial condition may differ
column38: from what is indicated in those forward-looking statements. For discussion of some of the risks and factors that could affect the firm\u2019s future results
column39:
please see the description of risk factors in our current annual report on Form 10-K for our year ended December 2012.

"
column40:
"

I would also direct you to read the forward-looking disclaimers in our quarterly earnings release
column41: particularly as it relates to our Investment Banking transaction backlog
column42: capital ratios
column44:
and Global Core Excess. And you should also read the information on the calculation of non-GAAP financial measures and regulatory capital ratios that are posted on the Investor Relations portion of our website at www.gs.com.

"
column45:
"

This audiocast is copyrighted material of The Goldman Sachs Group
column46: Inc. and may not be duplicated
column47: reproduced
column48:
or rebroadcast without our consent.

"
column50: Harvey Schwartz
column51:
will now review the firm\u2019s results. Harvey?

"
column52:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column53:
"

Thanks
column55: and thanks to everyone for dialing in today. I\u2019ll walk you through our third quarter results
column56: and then take your questions. Net revenues for the quarter were $6.7 billion
column57: net earnings
column58: $1.5 billion
column59: earnings per diluted share
column61:
and our year to date annualized return on common equity was 10.4%.

"
column62:
"

While there were some headwinds in the third quarter
column63: our year to date performance remained solid
column64: in what continues to be a challenging macro-environment. On last quarter\u2019s call
column65: we talked about how market participants were trying to assess the outlook for the global economy
column66:
specifically whether a recovering U.S. economy could potentially offset slower growth in other economic regions.

"
column67:
"

In addition
column68:
the shifting commentary on monetary policy was leading our clients to question the potential economic and market impacts of reduced quantitative easing. These discussions continued in the third quarter. Ongoing uncertainty around the economic outlook and the traditional seasonal slowdown drove a significant reduction in client activity during the quarter.

"
column69:
"

This reduction in nationwide client activity obviously impacted the opportunity set in many of our businesses. In investment banking
column70: equity and equity related volumes declined 27% quarter over quarter. Debt [unintelligible] volumes declined 10% versus the prior quarter
column71:
and completed M&A volumes declined 36% sequentially.

"
column72:
"

Within our institutional client services businesses
column73: most product areas also experienced reduced levels of client activity. For example
column74: within credit products
column75: investment grade and high-yield volumes declined sequentially by 13% and 19% respectively when looking at trades data. In U.S. equity markets
column76:
stock buy-ins were down 13% to an average daily volume of 5.8 billion shares.

"
column77:
"

However
column78: activity improved in September with our investment banking clients. Announced M&A volumes increased significantly
column79: and overall backlog improved to its highest level in five years. During the quarter
column80: we also saw continued positive trends within our investment management business. Assets under supervision reached a record level
column81:
aided by $17 billion of net inflows.

"
column82:
"

I\u2019ll now run through each of our businesses. Investment banking produced third quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion
column83: down 25% from the second quarter. Third quarter advisory revenues were $423 million
column84: down 13% from the second quarter
column85:
reflecting a decline in industry-wide completed M&A transactions.

"
column86:
"

Year to date
column87: Goldman Sachs ranked first in worldwide announced and completed M&A. We advise on a number of important transactions that closed in the third quarter
column88: including Softbank\u2019s $21.6 billion purchase of a majority stake in Sprint
column89: Bausch & Lomb\u2019s $8.7 billion sale to Valeant
column90:
and Apache\u2019s $3.75 billion sale of selected assets to Fieldwood Energy.

"
column91:
"

We\u2019re also an advisor on a number of significant announced transactions. They include Vodafone\u2019s U.S. $130 billion disposal of its U.S. group
column92:
whose principal asset is its 45% interest in Verizon Wireless; Applied Materials\u2019 merger with Tokyo Electron for a combined value of $29 billion; and Grohe\u2019s $3.9 billion sale of a majority stake to Lixil.

"
column93:
"

Third quarter net revenues were $743 million
column94: down 30% from a strong second quarter. Equity underwriting revenues of $276 million were down 26% compared with the second quarter
column95: driven by a decline in industry-wide activity. Year to date
column96:
Goldman Sachs ranked first in global equity and equity-related common stock offerings and IPOs.

"
column97:
"

Switching over to debt
column98: underwriting revenues were $467 million
column99: and represented a 33% decline relative to a record second quarter. During the third quarter
column100: there were several noteworthy transactions: BHP Billiton\u2019s $5 billion debt offering
column101: Schaeffler\u2019s $1.3 billion sale of a portion of its equity stake in Continental\u00a0
column102:
and ADT\u2019s $1 billion high-yield offering.

"
column103:
"

Let me now turn to institutional client services. Total net revenues were $2.9 billion in the third quarter. Fixed client execution net revenues were $1.2 billion in the third quarter
column104: substantially lower than the second quarter
column105:
clearly not a good quarter for FIC. The significant decline in revenues was driven in part by seasonally slower activity levels seen across the industry and a more challenging macro-environment.

"
column106:
"

While rates were up relative to a weak second quarter
column107: activity levels remained muted. Revenues within currencies decreased significantly relative to the second quarter
column108:
on difficulty managing inventory and reduced activity levels.

"
column109:
"

Commodities decreased significantly versus the second quarter under challenging market making conditions and also lower client activity levels. Revenues within credit decreased significantly on lower volumes. Mortgage results decreased sequentially as clients became more risk averse given the potential for tapering in the U.S.

"
column110:
"

Turning to equities
column111: net revenues for the third quarter were $1.6 billion
column112: down 13% from the second quarter. Equities client execution revenues were $549 million
column113: down 14% sequentially. If you adjust for the sale of our Americas reinsurance business in the second quarter
column114:
revenues essentially flat.

"
column115:
"

Commissions and fees were $727 million
column116: down 13% from the second quarter
column117:
again reflecting lower market volumes. Security services net revenues of $340 million declined 10% from the seasonally stronger second quarter.

"
column118:
"

With respect to risk
column119: average daily volume in the third quarter was $84 million
column120:
up 4% from second quarter levels.

"
column121:
"

Let me now review investing and lending. We produced net revenues of $1.5 billion in the third quarter. Investing and lending includes direct investing
column122: investing we do through funds
column123:
as well as lending activities.

"
column124:
"

These activities occur across a diversified set of asset classes
column125: including both equity and debt. Equity securities generated net revenues of $938 million
column126:
primarily reflecting gains from private equity investments.

"
column127:
"

This increase in fair value was driven by company-specific events like IPOs
column128: strong corporate performance
column129: and higher equity prices. Net revenues from debt securities and loans were $300 million
column130:
primarily from interest income. Other revenues of $237 million include the firm\u2019s consolidated investment entities.

"
column131:
"

Switching to investment management
column132: we reported third quarter net revenues of $1.2 billion. Management and other fees were $1.1 billion
column133: 1% lower sequentially. During the third quarter
column134: assets under supervision increased $36 billion to a record $991 billion. Net market appreciation of $19 billion was primarily in equity assets
column135:
while $17 billion in inflows were concentrated in fixed income assets.

"
column136:
"

Now let me turn to expenses. Compensation and benefits expense
column137: which includes salaries
column138: bonuses
column139: amortization of prior-year equity awards
column140:
and other items such as payroll taxes and benefits was accrued at a compensation to net revenues ratio of 41% year to date.

"
column141:
"

This is 200 basis points lower than the firm\u2019s accrual in the first half of the year. The lower compensation accrual reflects year-to-date revenues and better visibility on expected compensation levels as we approach the end of the year.

"
column142:
"

Third quarter non-compensation expenses were $2.2 billion
column143: 4% lower than the second quarter
column144: largely due to the sale of our reinsurance business and lower brokerage
column145: clearing
column146:
and execution costs.

"
column147:
"

Year to date
column148:
our effective tax rate was 30.3%.

"
column149:
"

On capital
column150: we repurchased 10.2 million shares of common stock for a total cost of $1.65 billion during the quarter. Year to date
column151: we have repurchased 30.8 million shares for a total cost of $4.77 billion. Today
column152:
we also announced an increase in our quarterly common stock dividend from $0.50 to $0.55 per share.

"
column153:
"

Moving on to regulatory capital ratios
column154: our Basel III tier one common ratio on a fully loaded basis is 9.8%
column155: up 50 basis points from the second quarter
column156: driven by a reduction in risk. The risk-weighted assets are approximately $590 billion
column157: $345 billion in credit risk
column158: $165 billion in market risk
column159:
and about $80 billion in operational risk.

"
column160:
"

Our estimate for the proposed supplementary leverage ratio under U.S. rules is approximately 5% for the firm and approximately 6% for the bank. This is our best estimate
column161: subject to change
column162:
depending on regulatory clarifications.

"
column163:
"

Like all other proposed regulatory requirements
column164: we will work closely with our regulators as we evaluate and finalize the proposal. We believe it is our obligation to support safety and soundness within the financial services industry and the global financial system. As it relates to how we\u2019ll run the business
column165: similar to other regulatory metrics
column166:
the supplementary leverage ratio will be an important input.

"
column167:
"

Clearly
column168:
concerns about the global economic outlook created a more difficult operating environment for our clients in the third quarter. These challenges were amplified by the seasonal slowdown traditionally impacting client activity in July and August.

"
column169:
"

However
column170: we don\u2019t build client relationships or build businesses for a quarter. Client relationships and operating businesses require years
column171: often decades
column172:
of investment to build the durability that ultimately creates long-term shareholder value.

"
column173:
"

Across the globe
column174: our investment banking clients seek our advice on their most important strategic decisions. Corporate
column175: government
column176: and institutional asset management clients look to our execution and risk management capabilities across a variety of products and regions. We are entrusted to provide investment management services and offer investment products across all major asset classes through a diverse set of institutional and individual clients
column177:
making us one of the largest asset managers in the world.

"
column178:
"

Our clients often value our advice and services the most when the outlook is less certain
column179:
and when finding solutions becomes more challenging. The U.S. government shutdown and the debate in the United States surrounding the government debt ceiling has become a concern for our clients.

"
column180:
"

The political complexity involved in finding a long-term solution has created uncertainty about the world\u2019s economic outlook
column181: and as we have all seen
column182: has weighed heavily on market sentiment. Now that the political impasse looks to be resolved for the near term
column183: we\u2019re hopeful that greater certainty will drive improved client confidence and activity levels. Having said that
column184:
a long term solution is critical to the sustained recovery for the economy.

"
column185:
"

These fluctuations have not distracted us from focusing on the long term drivers of our business
column186: so as a management team
column187: we are focused first and foremost on our clients
column188: building deep
column189: meaningful relationships and providing solutions to their daily challenges. We are focused on conservatively managing our financial profile and being prudent allocators of capital. We are also focused on being efficient operators
column190:
while at the same time providing world-class service to our clients

"
column191:
"

In the end
column192: we are focused on creating long term shareholder value for you
column193:
our shareholders.

"
column194:
"

With that
column195: I\u2019d like to thank you again for listening today
column196:
and I\u2019m happy now to take your questions.

"
column197:
"

Question-and-Answer Session

"
column198:
"

Operator

"
column199:
"

[Operator instructions.] Your first question is from the line of Howard Chen with Cr\u00e9dit Suisse.

"
column200:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse

"
column201:
"

I was hoping to come back to your commentary on FIC. Understanding all of your peers\u2019 business mix is different
column202: but the relative revenue performance this quarter is pretty wide. So I was just hoping you could add a bit more color on how you would attribute that gap to your relative business mix
column203: the positioning issues you noted
column204:
and maybe just more challenging comparables.

"
column205:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column206:
"

As I said a few minutes ago
column207: clearly a difficult environment for FIC
column208: and we\u2019re not happy with the results. So having said that
column209: with respect to business mix
column210: I think there could be something there in terms of how different franchises are positioned. Certainly as we\u2019ve discussed with you in the past
column211:
our FIC business may be somewhat more weighted towards institutional asset managers.

"
column212:
"

If I back up for a second
column213: if you remember on last quarter\u2019s call
column214: somebody asked me a question about how I thought the market would respond to the potential changes in monetary policy
column215: and the discussion really is around how data-centric people would be. And of course we came into the summer with less certainly around monetary policy
column216: and then there were events in the Middle East
column217:
and then of course people actually couldn\u2019t get data with the government shutdown.

"
column218:
"

So I think there could be something in that. So
column219: I think the whole market environment is not good for that particular client base. However
column220: I don\u2019t want to sound defensive. Again
column221:
just not a good quarter for us in FIC.

"
column222:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse

"
column223:
"

And then you specifically mentioned foreign exchange in your commentary. Can you talk a bit more on what exactly happened in the quarter in that business
column224:
and are you able to size the potential facilitation issue and the impact it had on the quarter?

"
column225:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column226:
"

In terms of the currency business
column227: obviously it was a business I highlighted
column228: where it was challenging market making conditions and certainly from an inventory perspective. You know
column229:
we look at various metrics.

"
column230:
"

I mean one metric I could point to
column231: for example
column232: would be the VAR schedule in the earnings release. And as you can see
column233: basically from the first quarter to the second quarter
column234: there was a lot of activity in the franchise
column235: and risk had picked up in foreign exchange
column236:
and then you\u2019ll see quarter over quarter it\u2019s a pretty significant drop in the currency line. And that\u2019s virtually all driven by risk reduction.

"
column237:
"

In terms of the franchise itself
column238: this I will say
column239: we look at a variety of metrics like you would think
column240: all the numbers we can. We look at our own internal numbers
column241: sales activity
column242: where we can get transparency into the market. But there\u2019s nothing in that data that would tell us that when we look at the metrics
column243: client engagement looks consistent with those kind of volumes. So
column244:
franchise feels good. We just had a tough quarter.

"
column246:
"

And then shifting gears to the comp accrual
column247: it\u2019s pretty unusual to see the firm change the accrual in the third quarter. So
column248: I was just hoping to better understand what\u2019s different this year. Is the message that in this still challenged backdrop
column249:
your desire is to not fall below a certain return threshold?

"
column253: the comp accrual is based on our best estimate for where we think we\u2019ll end up for the end of the year
column254: but of course we still have a quarter to go. I think as it relates to compensation expense
column256: it\u2019s obviously the firm\u2019s largest expense
column257: and so this process
column258:
no different. This I want to be clear with everyone. No difference in terms of philosophy in the way we\u2019re approaching compensation.

"
column259:
"

So it\u2019s still all the same things we go through in terms of the pay for performance culture that we drive
column260: and so we\u2019ll look at all the components
column263: as I mentioned. And of course shareholders and ROE and the way we incorporate that in our thinking
column264:
that\u2019s always of course an important meaningful component of it.

"
column265:
"

Howard Chen - Cr\u00e9dit Suisse

"
column267: with a few more months since the initial proposals have been out
column268: I was hoping you could just update us on your thoughts on supplemental leverage ratio
column269:
where the firm may sit today and potential mitigating actions.

"
column270:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column271:
"

As I said before
column272: under the U.S. rules
column273: which are proposed
column274: we\u2019re at 5% for the hold co and 6% for the bank. We had time obviously in the quarter to analyze the proposed rule. And again
column275: I caveat this that it\u2019s a proposed rule
column276: will likely change. And of course
column277:
it\u2019s not effective until 2018.

"
column278:
"

But I think you should assume that that\u2019s a somewhat conservative estimate
column280: and in terms of mitigating actions
column281:
too early for us to really be thinking heavily about mitigating actions. We want to see how the rule evolves. We\u2019ll engage the regulators.

"
column282:
"

And the way we incorporate this
column283: for a lack of better language
column284: it will be how we incorporate this into our toolkit will be no different than we do with other regulatory metrics. Just like we talked about at your conference earlier in the year
column285:
which is actually rolling out some sample tools has proved to be fortuitous in terms of giving people an example of how we\u2019ll deploy it. But it\u2019s pretty early in the process. We\u2019ll see how it evolves.

"
column286:
"

Operator

"
column287:
"

Your next question is from the line of Glenn Schorr with ISI. Please go ahead.

"
column288:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column289:
"

Maybe we could talk about I&L for a second. I wonder if you could provide any update on capital and RWA in I&L
column290: not sure if you feel like breaking out equity versus MES. But I\u2019m thinking down the process of
column291: is there a natural annual runoff rate or realization rate in I&L
column292: and if all that capital generation that you have
column293:
if you\u2019re finding opportunities to reinvest it back in?

"
column294:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column295:
"

Really excellent question. We haven\u2019t broken down and disclosed the allocation by those segments in terms of the capital. And I think it\u2019s clear if we think about the capital allocation in terms of sort of the conventional market credit
column296: etc. In terms of the way we\u2019re managing the capital deployment
column297: as you\u2019ve seen
column298: we\u2019ve been in somewhat of a harvesting mode
column299: because that\u2019s what the market opportunity has provided. As we\u2019ve talked about before
column300:
we\u2019ve stayed very disciplined in terms of return characteristics.

"
column301:
"

As it relates to capital itself
column302: as you know
column303: the investments in funds are deductions from capital under the Basel III ratios. Now
column304: there are transitional provisions
column305: so for example under the transitional provisions
column306: our Basel III capital ratio would be about 100 basis points higher than the 9.8
column307:
but I\u2019ve been quoting you the fully loaded. That is the way I would think about it.

"
column309:
"

So from that standpoint
column310: given that the market\u2019s providing you harvest opportunities
column311: but not the same level of investing opportunities
column312: there is a natural runoff. I don\u2019t want to put words in your mouth
column313: but the production of the business unit or line item in general has been great
column314:
but there should be some natural shrinkage until there\u2019s a reinvestment mode. Is that not a right way to think about it?

"
column315:
"

Harvey Schwartz

"
column316:
"

I would think about it no differently than we\u2019ve approached it in the past
column317: which is there will be cycles when reinvestment opportunities for us and our clients seem more attractive
column318: and there will be parts of the cycle where harvesting is more attractive. We happen to be slightly more in a harvesting cycle. But recently
column319: actually
column320: we\u2019ve seen some good investment opportunities. They tend to be a bit more geographically based
column321:
given some of the geographic differences and stress around the world. But that\u2019s no different in terms of philosophy and I think the way to think about how we operate the business.

"
column322:
"

Glenn Schorr - ISI

"
column323:
"

Just shifting gears for a second
column324: you just alluded to Howard\u2019s question a little bit
column326: the biggest users of gross balance sheet within FIC
column327:
and you guys were early and pushing down Basel III requirements out on to the desk. Is it way early on leverage? I\u2019m just curious on how the leverage focus even is going to start impacting yours and others\u2019 balance sheets.

"
column329:
"

Again
column330: too early to tell in terms of how we\u2019ll incorporate it as an operating metric. But at this stage
column331: based on what we know - again
